[b]Neo Review of Tales of Symphoina[/b]

The story for the time of releases still good to even to this day. The characters development throughout the journey helps the story building. There was moment where the character personality could’ve been better but overall its quite good.
The battle system is dated especially compare to the recent Tales games e.g. If you’re coming from a game like Tales of Berseria might make the battle system feel sluggish.

Tales of Symphoia for the PC is ported from ps2 and not from the GameCube, so players will not experience the 60fps instead they do get the cut content that was only exclusive to PS2 copy. The game is still playable and does the job however, the game will occasionally stutter at the beginning but eventually becoming less noticeable overtime. The game does come with some glitches the ones I experience are:

Raine bunny outfit has a graphical glitch only when you use the outfit in battle.
At some point I don’t remember where the voice does mix up e.g. Genis may sound like Raine.
Stuttering but most of the time the game ran smoothly

I do recommend this game on PS3 instead of PC  because it includes the squeal Tales of Symphonia Dawn of New World which I personally meh.

148512162.review:
My, My. 

I've played the Steam version on both a toaster desktop and a high-performance laptop. I didn't experience any game-breaking performance issues aside from having to manually set the game up to work with a controller during initial setup personally. That aside, people keep forgetting this game was originally made for consoles. While capping the FPS at 30 has clearly pissed off a lot of people, it was easy for me to see why. With consoles, things are fixed. It's a lot more varied with all the different kinds of PCs and video cards there are out there. The 30 FPS cap was likely for stability reasons but performance wise, I've seen no difference from the Gamecube version which I've owned since 2007.

Moving on. If you never played a "Tales of" game before, this is a good intro to the series. It was the first 3D "Tales of" game and though it lacks a lot of the polish Tales of Vesperia has in terms of features and mechanics, its deep and engrossing story is why it's one of the top 5 games in the series overall (It's in my top 3 personally). Back in the day, Tales of Symphonia is why many JRPG fans owned a Gamecube. Its storytelling, world building and character development go a long way in making up for the game's biggest flaw which is also why each playthrough has minimum 45 to 60 hours: The Dungeon areas. 

Symphonia's biggest issue is how the development team decided to extend the game's playtime: Putting time-consuming elaborate puzzles for you to figure out in order to proceed as possible. The Balacruf Mausoleum (Sylvarant),  Meltokio Sewers (Tethe'alla), the Palmacosta Human Ranch (Sylvarant), the Asgard Human Ranch (Sylvarant), the Temple of Ice (Tethe'alla), both Renegade Bases, the Temple of Lightning (Tethe'alla), Derris Kharlan (both visits), The Toize Valley Mine (Tethe'alla), Latheon Gorge (Tethe'alla), The Temple of Darkness (Tethe'alla) and Ymir Forest (Tethe'alla) all take a few hours to get through due to the mechanics. Thankfully, after you pass through Ymir Forest for the first time you can skip going through it again when traveling to/from Heimdall.

The three biggest offenders of those listed are Ymir Forest, the Meltokio Sewers and the Tethe'alla Rengade Base. The Temple of Darkness and the Temple of Lightning get (dis)honorable mentions though. They make every New Game+ painful. Why would you play through the game multiple times? Well there 8 possible endings, each involving one of the 8 possible party members. 

One party member will permanently leave your party depending on if you see a certain ally's scene in Flanoir. Anyone who's played a console version before knows which two party members I'm referring to. If you meet that certain ally in Flanoir, the next boss battle you have will be against the ex-party member. In exchange, the ally permanently joins your party for the rest of the game. 

I mentioned this earlier but there is a New Game+ which has become a series staple for almost 20 years now. You can use the Grade Shop when loading Clear Data to carry over certain things from your previous playthrough from items to money to Artes (called Techs in Symphonia) to XP Boosts among other things. Grade is earned at the end of battle though a multiplier is applied on higher difficulties. Grade spent before each NG+ is refunded back to you for the next so after a few playthroughs, eventually you will be able to get everything you want. A few Grade Shop items are exclusive to each other such as XP Boosts and Half EXP for example. 

Would be nice if they added a Dungeon Puzzle Skip Perk to the Grade Shop. Honestly I'm annoyed Namco Bandai never thought to add this to ANY of the re-releases. More so given you can skip certain puzzles in most of the games released after Symphonia after you fail a few times. Oh, well.

All that said and in closing. Would I recommend this game? Hell yes absolutely. Would I recommend this on Steam? If you don't have a console version already, definitely. Get it on sale if you can help it though I bought it full price myself.

148346743.review:
Pros:
- Diverse playable characters with different fighting styles, back stories, and personalities that developed really well throughout the story
- The main story has lots of plot twists that does not feel forced
- Battle System and character equipment are rich in customization
- World building is great
- New game+ mode after beating the game where some content in your previous playthrough can be passed on (although I haven't done this)
- You don't need to grind for a casual playthrough

Neutral:
- there is a LOAD of side quests
- no tutorial on how to get/activate some techs
- the game is a real slow-burner
- graphics are a bit outdated

Cons:
- Combat can be repetitive after mastering all techs and combos, and memorizing fight patterns
- Dungeons suck so much without a guide. (half the game is beating dungeon puzzles that increasingly gets complex). [b] you will spend more time in dungeons compared to when fighting bosses [/b]
- You walk at a horrendous speed in towns and dungeons without a characters specific ability you need to equip (this is also true in overworld exploration, only that there is no cure aside from riding a pet or a vehicle)
- Camera is fixed and cannot be controlled (although, you kinda get used to it)

Overall, the game is a solid pick for its time. Intriguing story and well-made world building, diverse cast, combat and customization, good for casual players. Although, I would say that people expecting a quick game should not play this game, as it is not quick even if you played it casually.

7/10.

148187556.review:
1. It is a nightmare for a completionist. 
- You have to beat the game at least 5 times to get all the titles. You have to grind exp, cooking level, pallets, casino chips for dozens of hours. 

2. Some of the dungeons were incredibly annoying (level design/puzzles). Overall, it took me ~75h to beat the game with the detailed guide. 

3. Endgame optional bosses are almost impossible to beat unless you'll farm exp for lvl 100, but there are no places to farm that much exp, so you'll have to buy an upgrade once you beat the game, which will allow you to get x10 exp, but in order to get that upgrade, you have to farm 3000 grade points, while you are receiving 0.5 - 1 grade point per battle. So you have to farm the grade points (dozens of hours), so it will be easier to farm exp points. Love farming, great concept! They simply do not respect your time at all.


Did I enjoy the story/characters - yes.
Did I enjoy the game - no. 
Do I recommend it to others - no.

147970363.review:
It's actually been awhile since I rightfully sat down and finished a Tales series and the last one I ever played with that much fervor would be Vesperia.  Since Symphonia was my first brush into the series, it actually lit a fire in me that I honestly hadn't felt in a long time with this series.  I had others like Abyss, and Legendia and even tried my hand at Phantasia, Innocence and Destiny. Combat-wise, it's smoother than other Tales games I've played before by far.  Puzzle-wise, in a word, formidable. They weren't brain racking but some made you had to think out of the box while others not so much. Now I clocked in this for 75 hours (4 hours recording parts, minus the grinding sessions) and it has fed my need to play another entry in the series. While most people have their favorite entries of this series, I recommend this if you grew up around the PS2/GC era just so you know that iconic ARPGs still exists and still very much playable. 

But as per usual, your taste may vary.

145890968.review:
If you only play one Tales game in the franchise, play this one. Every JRPG trope is present here in its finest form.

Symphonia brought the Tales series into the 21st century. It influenced every Tales game that came after it, and many other RPGs. It tells a nuanced story about alienation and discrimination, and it pulls no punches.

This is a polished masterpiece. Everything from the gameplay to the story to the block puzzles bring fresh delights. There’s an overwhelming amount of content here, and a single playthrough can easily take over 100 hours, 

Symphonia sets the standard for character-driven RPGs. A colorful, charming exterior hides deep, dark, emotional storytelling with weighty themes that’ll stick with you.

On a technical note: the game runs beautifully on the Steam Deck, but I’ve heard there are frame rate issues on PC. And one of the achievements is bugged, so if you’re an achievement hunter, Steam may be the wrong platform for this gem. 

Whichever platform you choose to play it on, this one is worth it. After 20 years, Symphonia still sings. We need more games like this one.

144740184.review:
This review will be based on technical aspects of the game as well as gameplay. 

Technical: First of all, I do not recommend this game on PC. However, despite it's many reported issues on PC, many of which I've experienced myself, this game runs flawlessly on the Steam Deck. For me, the game was practically unplayable on PC. It would crash to a black screen upon opening the game and trying to play the intro video. Maybe 1 in 10 times I could get to the main menu, but would experience crashes any time I tried to change settings. 

On Steam Deck this was an entirely different experience. Right out the gate it worked flawlessly. Smooth 30fps (locked, even on PC), resolution can be changed without crashing, and videos have no issue playing and don't crash the game. I had been looking for a reason to use my Steam Deck more often. A game that runs so poorly on even the strongest PC's was actually perfect for what I wanted. So I play this exclusivel on the Deck. 

Gameplay: Although I'm not new to the Tales series, this was a title that I missed growing up. So I'm glad to get to experience it with fresh visuals, but I can't speak to the differences between this port and the original release.

Hands down, the game is fun. I can see where this laid the foundation for following 3d Tales games in the series. Combat is responsive, although it can be a bit repetitive. This is however alleviated by a fairly robust roster of enemy types. 

Exploration is the most tedious part, and isn't much rewarding beyond unlocking the ability to ride your mount in specific areas of the map, each of which must be unlocked individually. Early in the game, exploring the map to reach your next destination could turn off some players to the game. 

Slogging through the tedious exploration is rewarded with great story segments, character to character dialogues and monologues, and unique, often element specific instances to explore. The story is similar in ways to Tales of Arise, and that's a compliment. It's well story-driven.

TL;DR: Get this game if you intend to play it SOLELY on the Steam Deck. Especially if you can snag it on sale.

142319644.review:
I remember being a Nintendo kid, playing platformers and collect-a-thons for most of my early life. However, after being reintroduced to JRPGs via Pokemon and Paper Mario I started seeking out more JRPGs to play. To my utter disappointment I came to find out there was basically nothing on the N64 and Gamecube and I didn't own any Sony systems. So as any enterprising young adult on the internet is want to do, I turned to emulation. I started diving head first into the SNES library and came across this fan translated game that looked "So cool!' - Tales of Phantasia. 

I remember playing Phantasia from dawn till dusk for days on end until I beat it. I started looking up things about it and realized it was part of a series of games. I was unfortunately disappointed as i realized I was without many options. Most of them were on the PS1 and my computer couldnt' handle emulating that at the time. Then I found out a game had just recently come on the Gamecube called Tales of Symphonia and it was a prequel to Phantasia that I loved?! The starts aligned just for me. 

I begged my dad to take me to the local Best Buy so I could pick up the game - and I did. I immediately fell in love. Tales of Symphonia was to the Tales franchise that Final Fantasy VII was to it's respective series - it put the series on the map outside of Japan. While Symphonia has aged poorly in some places there is no denying that it is by far the most important Tales game in the franchise - again, just like FFVII. 

Also, for those on the fence about this version, you are far less likely to run into any issues playing this port than you are to run into any. Don't be fooled by the volume of people complaining about this game. The amount of people having issues are a vast minority compared to those who have no issues. It's hard to see that taking a quick glance at the reviews or the community forum because it is far more likely for people to review/discuss their complaints than there are for those to discuss having no issues withe the game. 

Do yourself a favor and give this game a try. There are better Tales games out there nowadays, but by no means is Symphonia worse for their existence. It is a vital part of the franchise, a game that had it not been the critical success that it was, may have doomed the franchise into complete obscurity or perhaps even it's existence.

142112083.review:
Please, please, PLEASE make sure you download the TSFix located in the guides section if you buy this game. My recommendation would likely slip into a "maybe" category without it. Shout out to the awesome mod developer who worked hard to fix Bamco's lazy port of this game. With that said:

Ah, Tales of Symphonia. In my opinion it's one of the "Golden Era" Tales games. Nostalgia certainly played a role in deciding to replay this game in more than 10 years, but there is more to this game than that. That being said, age certainly is this game's greatest enemy and is a good place to start in helping others decide if they want to invest the 40+ hours to complete:

Cons:

-Port is awful. Don't need to spend too much time on this one. Get the TSFix and this becomes irrelevant. 

-Character animations are super rigid. I'd find myself laughing at dramatic moments when I knew I shouldn't be because most character animations just look so unnatural. 

-Sound design is very inconsistent. A crackling fire might sound more like a wagon with a misshaped wheel, or walking through grass more like a crumpling bag. Even a lot of voiced lines (reference English Dub) feel like they could've used a few more takes.

-Battle system doesn't feel anywhere near as robust as modern Tales games. It's much more guard intensive with a slower pace and shorter combos with a longer time frame to get genuinely interesting. 

-TOO MUCH BACKTRACKING. Whether it's in the overworld, in dungeons, or even in towns on sidequests, you're going to backtracking a bunch with only a few opportunities to quick jump (no fast travel). This is literally the biggest replay killer for this game in my opinion and I see why it took 10+ years for me to replay this game. Some dungeons get flat-out tedious. 


So why might you want to play this game even today?

Pros:

-Strong cast of characters. This definitely comes down to preference but I've always liked Symphonia's cast. You have the typical hero from the early 2000's that, of course, dual wields, the tragic--yet air-headed--heroine, the MAGIC elf boy, big sis teacher (yes!), tsundere ninja (oh yes), pervert knight, handsome edgelord that's ALL business, and an adorable lil' lumberjack that looks 12 but is 28 in an attempt to piss off virtue-signaling Reddit users years before Reddit existed (yes...?). This game also has a fun feature where you can decide your "partner" (someone you get unique scenes with) depending on choices you make. The game ships Lloyd/Colette hard, but I went Lloyd/Sheena this time and I love it. Villains and side characters are a bit of a mixed bag, but there are plenty of good ones (including the main villain). 

-The story is solid. It might not win any awards, but it's like coming back to a Saturday-morning cartoon you used to enjoy. It's genuinely interesting, it's fun, and it doesn't go off the rails like some modern games (something that seems consistent with the "golden era" Tales games). The pacing isn't always on point, but I'd rather take a hiccup in pacing than feeling like the game gets tired of its own themes.

-The battle system is fun. As mentioned above, it's not as good as modern Tales games, but it's still fun to set up your characters, choose your party, and play around with technique/combo setups. 

-Soundtrack is great. Though other elements of sound design have their issues regarding consistency, the soundtrack does not. 

-Aside from a strange sequence of about 6 dungeons that are very tedious (about 2/3 through the game) the  overall dungeon design is very good; maybe the best in the series (Abyss might be better: Less tedious, but slightly less creative). Most have great themes, puzzles, and boss fights. You really can't go wrong and I hope they bring this level of dungeon variety back to the series in the future. 

-Cel-shaded graphics have aged well. Symphonia has always stood out amongst Tales games due to this and I wouldn't mind seeing it again. Not everyone is a fan of the chubby lil' chibi character models, but the colors and shading help the world pop in ways that Zestiria, Beseria, and Arise failed to in my mind. Even Abyss (my personal favorite in the series) doesn't stand out quite like Symphonia. It's...really kind of special in that way...maybe the nostalgia is getting to me...haha. 

This game sat in my Steam library for AGES and figured I'd never play it. When I finally installed it on a whim I almost gave up playing due the shoddy port and initial issues with the TSFix (if you tab out, or use another monitor you need to make sure to click back on the screen with Symphonia on it until the cursor disappears otherwise you might get awful lag like me). I'm glad I didn't give up. I genuinely enjoyed returning to this game, even with its flaws. It doesn't hurt that it often goes on sale for $5, so if you're interested, give it a shot!

141706805.review:
I know this will not be a popular take, but I did not find Tales of Symphonia to be particularly fun because it did not age well, and I have no nostalgia attachment to the game.

The first issue I have with the game is that it did not age well. Now I am not by any means discounting how good of a game it could have been when it came out back in the early 2000s... but unless you are playing it for nostalgia value, I don't think someone can genuinely enjoy the mechanics and graphics of the game in 2023. If I had given this review in the early 2000s, I think it would look dramatically different.

Additionally, like earlier games, there is little to no directional guidance, which led me to unlock the seals backwards (in terms of difficulty). Now I am okay with this, but it is frustrating dying all the time to a higher level region, only to realize I was doing it backwards and cake-walking the earlier region. Call me spoiled by modern games, but I no longer have the patience to retry the same thing over and over when it is just about grinding a few more levels. Moving around across the map was quite annoying, and sometimes random mob combat is just unavoidable.

The one redeeming factor was that the story remained interesting with multiple twists. However, since I got really bored after 10+ hours or so, I did not beat the game. I did however Google up on the story, so I am familiar with how it goes. Although I do question some parts of the story, I can see why people liked the story.

Overall, if you have any nostalgia attachment to the game, it will continue to give you that warm and fuzzy feeling playing it. But otherwise if you are like me, a random gamer playing this in 2023 who did not play it back in the days... I feel like there is a better than not chance you will not enjoy the game that much.

140002847.review:
A Timeless Classic That Defines the RPG Genre

Tales of Symphonia is a game that stands the test of time and continues to captivate players with its immersive world, compelling characters, and an epic narrative that explores themes of sacrifice, friendship, and the consequences of one's actions. As a fan of RPGs, I can confidently say that Tales of Symphonia is a true masterpiece that has left an indelible mark on the genre.

One of the standout aspects of Tales of Symphonia is its deep and engaging storyline. Set in a world where two factions, Sylvarant and Tethe'alla, vie for control, the game delves into complex political struggles, religious conflicts, and the fate of the world itself. The narrative is richly woven, filled with plot twists, and supported by well-developed characters who undergo personal growth and transformation throughout the game. The emotional depth and thought-provoking themes explored in the story make it an unforgettable journey from start to finish.

The real-time combat system is where Tales of Symphonia truly shines. Combining fast-paced action with a strategic element, battles are fluid and exciting. The ability to control a single character in combat while the AI controls the others allows for dynamic teamwork and coordination. The "Artes" system, which enables characters to unleash powerful special attacks, adds a layer of strategy and customization. Furthermore, the multiplayer option allows friends to join in and experience the adventure together, enhancing the game's replay value.

The world of Tales of Symphonia is beautifully realized, with lush environments, diverse landscapes, and intricate dungeon designs. The hand-drawn art style has a timeless charm, and the character designs are both distinctive and memorable. The music, composed by Motoi Sakuraba, is a masterpiece in itself, perfectly capturing the emotions of each moment and immersing players in the game's atmosphere.

The game's length and depth are worth mentioning, as Tales of Symphonia offers countless hours of gameplay. Side quests, hidden areas, and optional content provide additional challenges and rewards, making it a game that encourages exploration and thorough exploration of its rich world.

It's important to note that the Steam version of Tales of Symphonia does suffer from a few technical issues, such as occasional frame rate drops and controller support hiccups. However, the overall experience remains largely unaffected, and with the help of community patches and mods, most of these issues can be addressed.

Tales of Symphonia is a timeless classic that has set the bar high for RPGs. Its gripping storyline, memorable characters, and addictive combat system combine to create an unforgettable gaming experience. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or new to the world of Tales, this game is an absolute must-play. Prepare to embark on an epic journey that will leave you longing for more even after the final credits roll.

137369962.review:
Tales of Symphonia is one of my favorite games of all time. I have so many great memories playing this game on the GameCube and still load up my old save from time to time to see my progress. After buying other Tales games and playing through Vesperia and Arise (i'm not finished yet with Vesperia) I wanted to write a review after seeing some odd reviews from steam and some of the community. 

First off i'm not fluent or very knowledgeable on PC lingo or anything so you know. But this is a game made in 2003..its had remasters and hd remakes in the past as well so I understand if some fans have favorites ports. I also realize you can just steal it online which is fine if you don't wanna spend money on an old ass game. One thing i had seen the most is the contempt hate for how it looks "Oh its so clunky" or "its gross to look at on my 7000 40 monitor" or whatever. ITS FROM 2003 FOLKS please shut the fuck up. if you hate shitty graphics don't play it that's all. If graphics in a video game mean so dearly to you than the nostalgia or a good story with well written characters DO NOT PLAY IT. Second thing is the FPS. I will say it again because honesty these people need a good shower and need to touch grass but 30fps is playable when it comes to an older title. Please enlighten me on why 30fps is bad because I can't tell how it is honesty and I think you are just a bunch of piss babies that need to touch grass. as long as my frames don't die on me to the point where I can't see its playable. 

Now that that's out of the way let me tell you about this masterpiece of a game. Symphonia starts you out with 3 characters, 4 if you really want to jump the gun but let's start with the main 3. Genis Sage, genius kid with a smart mouth. Colette Brunel, timid girl with a huge heart but is also very clumsy. And then Lloyd Irving, cunning, brave, dumb as hell, but always ready to show everyone what he's got. These 3 are wonderful and full of life when you play the game and get to know them, and I can say that about the rest of the cast. Not one has a weak story line you can go through and watch to see how they grow and change  from being around Lloyd's intrepid heart. A classic story that was told back then remastered into a wonderful nostalgic trip to your childhood. I would definitely recommend this game if you want to sit down after work, school or just a long day to relax and play for a couple hours and enjoy the combat and story. I have 4 playthrough's including new game +. Is it clunky and kinda hard to get the hang of if it's your first game? yes, is the story long and repetitive? yes, and the combat as well? yes. But that's what makes it good. a classic 3d-ish style of an RPG that you can have fun with. watch a video about combos or some dungeon run to see if it is for you. And remember its an old title so these uptight gremlins with their high standards can stuff it. The game is not bad whatsoever. I have had 1 crash and that was because I tabbed in and out multiple times so it froze. No lag problems and a nice smooth controller scheme. But play on controller, it will feel so much better if you do that. If you want to comment feel free because i would love to talk about this game with others and if you want to criticize me feel free.

Unskippable cutscenes mean I don't think I would get anything out of new game+ and considering how much I loved the game as a kid, it saddens me a little to give it the thumbs down, but I just have different wants and needs from a game now than I did when I was 8. 

Pros: 
Nostalgic, decent story, enjoyable memorable characters, bright and colorful 

Cons: 
repetitive battle strategies, story drags near the end of the game, more convoluted than I remember it being, game drags itself on too long on some plot threads that are just not very exciting or fun tbh. 

I get why I liked symphonia as a kid, and I don't blame people for liking it now but as far as ported oldie JRPGs go, this one just feels old and sluggish when compared to some of the re-releases of recent.

134251113.review:
Tales of Symphonia is a classic, 20 years old now (with the original Gamecube version), and definitely lives up to its status.  This is my first play, while I'm catching up on RPG history I missed.

Graphically, the character models, towns, and dungeons look good.  There are fixed camera angles, which are mostly used very well.  The stylized artwork makes the lower resolution of them still look good and timeless.  Overworld graphics are a different matter altogether, terrain looks really dated, and you have a very short draw distance, and finally poor camera angles in many places in the world.  I only had one graphical glitch, which only happened in a single room of a late game dungeon.  The terrain textures did not load or render correctly, mixing in a bunch of black lines over the terrain.  I don't know if this was a game bug, or if it was due to the Proton compatibility layer allowing it to run on Linux.

The sound and music are great and memorable.  Voice acting in English isn't used outside of a few major cutscenes and certain full motion videos.  Skits are not voiced, but stilled tied to the timing of the Japanese audio so you cannot speed them up or wait to read them/progress the dialogue at your own pace.

Controls on the overworld are clunky and not too great, you turn slow, you move slow, and the camera issues make it even harder.  Controls in town, dungeons, and combat are perfectly fine and work really well.  You occasionally get caught up on objects in dungeons, especially narrow passages at angles, but there were only a few places I ever got completely stuck.  Combat controls are excellent, feeling far better than some Tales games released a decade later!  Movement is a little slow (but can be sped up with Ex skills), but attacks, blocking, and all are very responsive with the risks you'd expect in an action RPG.

The characters are also quite memorable, there are no characters that I'd consider truly bad.  That said some aspects of a few characters, namely Zelos and Raine, are a bit uncomfortable to experience today.  [spoiler]Stop hitting your 12 year old littler brother Raine![/spoiler].  Each character has a good role to fill in the story and can be a workable party member for you.  Nobody aside from Raine seems to completely overshadow anyone else in a combat role.  As always with Tales games, the skits do a lot of character development and filling in what the main story glosses over.  They're really effective at making you like your companions.  There are also a number of special interactions that can be triggered on the overworld, these can be very valuable in controlling the hidden stat "affection", which determines the outcome of several events late game.

The story is solid, with the themes of discrimination, religious zealotry and scapegoating, conforming and rejecting the roles placed onto you by society covered heavy-handed but still well.  There are a lot of twists and turns, and changed expectations throughout the story which kept it interesting.

The main negative aspect is the dungeon design.  While it's nice to have puzzle dungeons in RPG's at times, there are a massive number of them (most of the dungeons), and it got very tiring toward the middle of the game.  In addition, encounters during puzzles are really annoying!  A few dungeons also have very confusing paths with many branches all looking the same.  A few times it was easy to miss what was intractable or that there was an exit in a place as it blended too much into the background.  I also had one game crash [spoiler]when starting Sheena's duel boss fight in one of her sidequests[/spoiler], but going through it again didn't crash so it may have just been a one time thing.  Since this is a 2003 game and still lives off classic game rules, there aren't autosaves so you'll need to manually save as much as possible.

Overall, Tales of Symphonia lives up to its status as a classic, and even with the few negatives (dungeon design, poor overworld look and movement, some aspects of characters), it's well worth a play today and still feels good to play today.  Strongly recommended!

I'm glad this game exists on Steam so I can play it again, just like all those years ago on the GameCube. 
This game means a lot to me personally, and to a lot of people. But I'll say this...
There's already not a lot of Tales Of games on Steam.

Symphonia, sure. Vesperia, absolutely. Zestiria, Berseria, Arise- Makes sense. 

Tales of Hearts R should not dead and gone on the Vita.
Tales of Graces F, Tales of Xillia, and Tales of Xillia 2 shouldn't be lost forever in PS3 hell.
Tales of the Abyss shouldn't be confined to the now-defunct Nintendo 3DS, or PS2.
Tales of the Heroes: Twin Brave has a lot going for it and deserves a port of its own.
Tales of the World: Radiant Mythology 1,2, and 3 are FAR too good to be forgotten and ignored.
Divisive as it is, I don't care; Dawn of the New World touched me in so many personal ways that I have a deeper connection to it than any other game I've played in the series. If even for me and me alone, I can't stand that game being lost to the Wii/PS3.

Please. PLEASE. Do not let these games die on the platforms they were released/re-released on when there's an entire audience missing these games, or not knowing they exist.
It's cool that Symphonia is getting a second re-release, but...
Please bring these games to Steam. Please.

132976137.review: After downloading and noticing the stutter and going to the effort of trying to install the patch (which for some reason wouldn't work) I discovered; at least on my laptop with a GTX 1650 GPU; an easy solution to at least the performance issues of the beginning. Just find the game's exe file and go into properties. Change the compatibility to Windows Vista. Tada! No more FMV stutter or intro stutter. You an even keep rumble on.

132748130.review:
A classic JRPG gem from...20 years ago! Sadly, as well-known as this game is (sometimes, the only one people know from this franchise), it hasn't aged that well. Many mechanics and "features" that it introduces as "new" or "redesigned" have long since become obsolete in the world of video games.

Nevertheless, in many aspects, Tales of Symphonia shines in its simplicity. No ultra-complicated equipment or leveling systems, a basic synthesis system for weapons and equipment, a non-convoluted storyline, simple yet addictive combat, tons of hours of side-content (bosses, sidequests, costumes, bonus dungeons, New Game+), and you can also grab a friend or two to fight alongside you.

Not a perfect game by any means, but a solid choice for any avid JRPG/Anime RPG fan that hasn't tried it out yet. 

*Fair warning though*: if you're the kind of completionist that wants EVERYTHING, be warned: this is the kind of game that requires not only extreme patience but also multiple playthroughs to be 100%. This is mostly because of story-related titles that are a once-per-playthrough choice between characters, and the easiest to miss content I've seen in video games (in one sidequest, the cutoff point is within the same screen it's triggered). It doesn't help the game has unskippable cutscenes (it's a 40+ hour game from 2003).

132069997.review:
A tale for the ages. 

Story:

The story follows on Lloyd. Your friend Colette has been chosen to set out on a journey to replenish the world of Sylvarant of it's mana and so you decide to help her out on the trip across the land, but you quickly find things are much more complicated as not only your world is danger, but another world too. 

The story of Tales of Symphonia is basically the typical JRPG romp. You're a young noble adventurer/warrior who sets out to save the world and then things turn really complex with plenty of twists and turns and grand scale. That's not to say that's bad, cause the story here is genuinely captivating and I got really hooked to see it through to the very end, but as far as it stands, there's really not much to stand out here.  

Graphics:

While I really like the vibrant and colorful design of the characters and the world itself, the game has some issues with the visuals. So I'll begin with the positives, which of course I have to give it to the character designs, while they are incredibly anime, I genuinely loved each of the characters designs and they all really stood out from one another. The world too has plenty of interesting locales you visit, from your starting village in the middle of the forest and some crazy sci-fi bases later down the line.

However the PC port looks rather muddled. I've played the vanilla as I wanted to experience the game in it's original form and I have to say that for those who really want the experience to look the best it can, you need to mods. Textures look really blurry, a lot of character models look rough around the edges, especially the NPC characters, there's definitely some notable aging in these areas. 

Audio:

One thing I cannot fault here is the voice acting which is absolutely phenomenal. Every single person on this cast is pretty notable voice actor and they all knock it out of the park, although I always hear Robin whenever Lloyd speaks, but even then I can't really fault it. so two thumbs up. The other sound design is also really good, especially the music. 

The music is a great collection of simple music for exploration and action packed music when you're in combat. I generally really liked the combat music and especially the tracks that are used in boss fights as they really nail add to the epic atmosphere. Sound effects do sound a bit rougher, like they aren't properly remastered as they sound a bit muffled, like your weapon swings, but it's not that big of a problem. 

Gameplay: 

I have to admit that as far as JRPG's go, my knowledge does not go beyond Persona. So when I first played Tales of Symphonia I was surprised by it. Now the basic gist is all here, exploring the world, getting into combat encounters, levelling up and getting better gear for you and your party, but the combat is what makes this special. 

Once you land yourself into combat, you and your assembled team get into a brawl and the best way I can really describe it is that it's like a fighting game, but a lot slower where you really think about the combos and moves and of course magic spells. It's very simple on paper, but I have to admit that I had my ass handed to me quite a bit until I really got a hang of the combat and then I found the game to be a fair enough challenge. 

The world exploration is pretty fun and I found the enemy encounters don't detract from the overall pacing as you're usually not getting into fights every second unlike some other RPG's where you can't move two steps without getting into a fight, which really makes the pacing of the game flow much better. Of course you will need to slow down and level up, but the combat is fun enough that I kind of wanted to get into combat, but when I felt like I was properly levelled I could just run away. 

Each so called "dungeon" of the game also has some light puzzles you have to solve to progress and there's of course other activities and side quests to take up if you really want to take a break from the main quest and break up the tedium of combat + story all the time. However the side quests are really uninteresting and just mostly unfun and I found myself ignoring most of them and the puzzles themselves are rather easy, but tedious due to the movement. 

The biggest negative of the game I can only come up with is the difficulty spikes which are random. For the most part I think the game is pretty fairly challenged, it was neither a breeze, but I never found myself barely scraping by, but there are particular fights that come in once in a while that will really be really difficult, be it because of the really difficult moves of bosses etc. 

Verdict:

Tales of Symphonia is a great RPG and I can see why so many people love it and regard it so well. It's definitely aged a bit, but it's still standing tall even after all of this time, however the PC port doesn't do it many favors. For fans of the genre, this is definitely a must. 

Final Rating:
8.5/10

Pros:
+ Story is grand in scale and is pretty engaging 
+ Combat is pretty fun 
+ Great voice acting
+ The soundtrack is great, especially during the final section 

Cons:
- Side activities aren't interesting and mostly boring
- PC port isn't the greatest 
- Graphics have started to show their age 

If you liked this review please consider joining https://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog and https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews

131551196.review:
Excellent world building, amazing characters (except for Zelos, fuck him), a simple yet deep combat system and a story that at first looks simple and even childish, but that actually goes into mature topics such as racism, xenophobia, slavery, discrimination and even social justice... all ruined by tedious dungeon puzzles and backtracking (not only in dungeons but also on the overworld).

Don't get me wrong, I REALLY enjoyed my 24 hours with this game, but since [spoiler]Te'the Alla[/spoiler], the biggest issues it had gone mask off. The puzzles in the first part of the game were fun, fair and creative, but since coming to the said place I mentioned earlier, they weren't hard, they were just tedious, VERY tedious.

Basically, you got a dungeon with multiple parts of a puzzle, this wouldn't be a problem if the design of the puzzle itself was tailored for the dungeon's layout, but no, you gotta backtrack multiple times if you don't know what to do, and god forbid you got stuck... cuz enemies are gonna deplete your MP and/or items, and believe me, the enemies DO get much beefier from this part onwards.

Call me what you want, but I don't like using walkthroughs and that stuff to complete a dungeon, in fact, I solely think that if you need them to advance... then something's going wrong, and this is EXACTLY what happens with Symphonia's dungeons (or rather, mid game ones).

Even if I didn't beat the game, I can confidently say that I had a blast with it, for me it's a 9/10, beautiful game ruined by its own age, Bamco, give it a proper remake (not a shitty remaster) the next time... *sigh*

129566204.review:
If you are a fan of JRPGs and absolutely love them, you'll like this game. If you just want a good JRPG, honestly don't bother with this one.

It's not a BAD game. The UI, the voice acting, the story and the graphics are all 'OK'. One of the main characters is voiced by Matthew Mercer (he's in pretty much everything, of Critical Role fame). The plot, characters and story, while perfectly fine, are nothing special, pretty much what you'd expect from a JRPG. Some people would say cliché, though.

The one thing that put me off this game was the GOD AWFUL COMBAT. It's just absolutely terrible. There's barely any strategy to it, it's a button masher, you can only move backwards or forwards. Friendly AI is dumb: they'll run into enemies and stand there even if you set their behavior to ranged. 

The main thing to do is run, get a few hits in, then back away. This is because basic enemies hit like trucks and will kill you or your party members with a few hits while they themselves are damage sponges and they don't have real patterns to their attacks. Sometimes they get staggered, but only god knows how or why. So you run in and hope you can do a combo before the enemy just does an attack and halves your HP.

But then doing combos is janky. Controls are not the most responsive and any hit by any enemy will interrupt you. Sometimes knock you away or stun you. Blocking only lowers damage taken. Enemies will sometimes block and immediately attack, sometimes they won't.  And this game LOVES to take away party members from you for one reason or another. So the best strategy is to just avoid enemies.

Healing/sustaining is a chore. You can heal with items in or out of combat, or pay money at an inn. Items are not cheap, though. So you'll want to spend a lot on healing items, but the game doesn't give you a lot of gold. So get grinding.

Save points are few and far between, they won't heal you either. So get ready to repeat a lot of dialogue and cinematics, because you'll die in a dumb, non-optional fight where you are outnumbered and the AI is stupid and there's not a lot you can do. You want better equipment? Well, get grinding, because it's not cheap either and most of your money should go into resting and healing items.

One example of this horrid system:
There's a low level enemy very early in the game. It's apparently almost immune to physical attacks (there's no way of knowing unless you Google it). So having any character go into melee with it is not gonna work. According to fans, the trick is to just control your mlee guy and have him do nothing but block the enemy attacks while the others are set on AUTO doing magical ranged attacks. If you try to melee this enemy in the meantime, you're just gonna die because like I said, enemies can just attack without interruption but they WILL interrupt you. So then the enemy will just casually walk up to the other NPCs and kill them one by one. Oh, and your NPCs will just run out of mana for their spells before killing this guy anyway, walk up to melee it and die. "Oh, just avoid that enemy!" What a FUN and smart battle system. 

You can always just set everyone in your party to AUTO and hope they can finish the fight without dying or taking too much damage.

Honestly everything in this game is ok, but the incredibly bad and boring combat mechanic just craps on it. There is no strategy involved, it's not engaging in any way, it's not fair or well-balanced. Sustaining your party is frustrating, getting gear/items/money is a chore and the controls are wonky.

I recommend it only if you're a fan of a later game and are feeling curious about history, and the game is on discount, which usually is
It's great as a learning experience if like me, you're interested in how the series did things before Tales of Berseria, or should I say Besteria?, the thing is that since Berseria is a one-up in every aspect, that means playing this game after Berseria is a huge downgrade
It has nice details and a lot of moments where you go "ah, so this is how that mechanic used to play..." only to realize "well, it sure was an upgrade..." and immediately start wishing you were playing Berseria
Personally, the story didn't attract me enough, and the dungeon puzzles were a pain in the low-lower back for me (I ended up dropping the game before the fight with Bolt because of the drag that was finishing that dungeon)
I really missed some Berseria mechanics such as if you whore a gear or weapon piece for enough battles you would obtain a permanent ability, which gave meaning to even the most empty, easy, and meaningless of battles; without that mechanic I felt I was wasting my time on most fights, especially against poisonous enemies I would just run because I knew I was sure to win but also would lose at least one antipoison item, and running away was not a challenge, more like a chore

127718156.review: Al ser un jugador antiguo de la saga tales, para mi este ha sido uno de mis favoritos, por desgracia no lo pude jugar cuando salió y lo puede llegar a probar cuando salió para la Ps3 le tengo cierto cariño, a diferencia de otros jrpg tiene sus puntos buenos como sus puntos malos, pero la diversión nunca se acaba, tiene un contenido muy basto a pesar de su antigüedad, los personajes son carismáticos a su estilo, la historia puede que empiece lento pero a medida que avances la historia evoluciona de una forma excelente pero tiene sus puntos válidos, la banda sonora es una maravilla como las mismas voces en japones. En cuanto a los combates, muchos dicen que la dificultad esta desbalanceada ya que el modo guerrero sería el modo normal, pero al usarlo el juego se complica, a mi opinión si ustedes quieren jueguen en novato, pero otros jugadores que le gusta sacar los logros (Como a mi) Lo encontramos un reto que al final del juego nos dejó una sensación de satisfacción, mas al saber que tiene un modo experto para sacar un logro más. Recomiendo jugarlo en pc en 2022, la verdad es que no, yo lo tengo en Ps3 y lo compre en pc cuando salió en oferta, tampoco digo que es una mala compra, pero si lo compran este año o el próximo, no esperen una jugabilidad como la de ahora, tampoco una dificultad que se adapte a lo que se escogió en la configuración, tampoco una cámara cómoda en el mapa mundial. Pero si no les importa esas fallas, pasaran muy buenas horas de grata diversión con Lloyd y sus amigos, los puzles y el diseño de niveles, como las armas mismas y los ataques son arte para los ojos. No hago muchas reseñas y tampoco se hacerlas bien, pero a lo que quiero llegar, si quieren jugar este juego pero no tienen las otras consolas que también tienen esta maravilla, cómprenlo por steam cuando este en oferta.

127078118.review:
Bueno, después de acabar el juego es hora de empezar la reseña. En primer lugar:

Este es un gran juego cegado por uno de los peores ports que he visto en mi vida. El juego original de la Gamecube va a 60 fps, aquí lo han rebajado a 30 fps con caídas de fps que me parecen penosas. He tenido crasheos en momento muy importantes y he tenido que instalar un fix de la comunidad para intentar arreglar estos errores tan penosos.

Claramente y después de el tiempo que ha pasado, me queda claro que aunque la gente se haya quejado a Bandai le importa tres pimientos este port, más aún al anunciar el "remaster" para consolas (remaster entre comillas, puesto que no han hecho literalmente nada, sigue a 30 fps, va como el ojete).

Dejando atrás el penoso esfuerzo que ha hecho Bandai, tengo que hablar del juego en sí.

Es un gran juego, mi segundo Tales Of favorito por detrás del Berseria. Me ha encantado la historia y le he cogido bastante cariño a los personajes.

El gameplay me ha sorprendido bastante para bien, es muy entretenido y ha envejecido realmente bien para la época en la que se creó.

Los puzzles son variados y tengo que reconocer que algunos son MUY coñazos, además de que es facilísimo perderse en este juego si no te miras una guía.

Por lo demás, tengo que decir que es un gran juego, me parece imprescindible jugarlo, aunque si decides jugarlo debes saber de antemano el port tan lamentable que te vas a encontrar. Una pena, porque este juego es impresionante. Aun así, te recomiendo jugarlo.

125085462.review:
I definitely see, after experiencing this as my first Tales game (blind in 2022,) why the series has earned so many sequels. There is a ton of charm, great characters, and a LOT of thematic exploration between:
- Bigotry and discrimination
- Loss
- Moral dilemmas
- Trust and betrayal
- Selfishness and selflessness
- Family and friendship
- History and mythology

I can't say for sure Toby Fox experienced this game, since I just outright don't know, but I feel some story topics feel very similar to ones seen in Undertale. They're obviously not _unique_ plot points, but as a fan of both, I did notice them. 

My favorite character is Genis. He feels kind of like this game's Tails, only a lot more snarky and sometimes mean-spirited. The focal characters of this game all have some level of growth and development over the game in a refreshing manner, the growth feels earned and the dialog skits really help to progress the interpersonal feelings. 

This game feels as big as I imagine it was back in the day of its release. It has a lot of content to explore for a person seeking various monsters, characters, scenes, challenges and story.

So, for the few downsides I DO have:

The smaller sticking point because a single playthrough isn't going to be affected, but is meaningful to someone interested in the experience: I believe a full 100% completion takes 8 or even 9 playthroughs at minimum, which, even if you bulldoze through all the plot, seems like it could take an exceptionally long time.

Likewise not a mandatory experience, but the red light green light is everyone's least favorite thing in the history of ever. Like, it's so bad it is basically a deciding point on if you're going to 100%, and if you don't know what you're doing you have to do it twice.

For the amount of farming you do need to do to 100%, some of the areas can get really boring.

The dialog in a couple places kind of beats you on the head or repeats itself a bit, but not cripplingly.

There are a couple typos even though the game has been out for something like 20 years, even though this definitely has modernizing touches to it.

Sometimes the cost to do moves other than your basic ones can be annoying enough that you don't feel like doing anything but hacking through multiple battles in the same area. 

Only a couple characters are really playable as a main due to how things like casting and attack speed control.

A couple of plot points seem hinted at, but never really... come to anything? 

Other than that, though, it's really a very fun and compelling game, and worth the price tag. If you never experienced this when it was new, you really should.

124203084.review:
"Hey thirty something gamer! Did you play Tales of Symphonia when you were younger?"

"Uh... yes?" 

"Would you replay it to scratch that nostalgic itch for the low low price of $5 on sale?"

"Sure."

"Will you groan and complain like a petulant child if it isn't 60fps?"

"No, I'm an adult and can deal with that."

"Then boy do I have a deal for you!"

Seriously. If you're even looking at buying this game, it's probably because you enjoyed it when it first came out. I played all the way through and didn't give two craps that it was a supposedly "inferior version", and I didn't notice a single thing that ruined the experience. Trust me, you won't notice the locked 30fps unless your precious eyes can't handle any fps under 60. A SMOOTH fps rate is far more important than a HIGH fps, and this game's got that. There are a few hiccups in the voice acting direction despite a knockout performance from the full cast for the most part, but that's not new. The only failings of this port are the failings of the original Symphonia; it is a product of its time and sometimes the gameplay can swing between overly simplistic (seriously, there's STILL no free run button?) and obtusely weird (why they didn't make mystic artes easier to use and access in the updated PS2 version, or hell, this one, is a mystery to me).

BUT. If you liked the original, you'll like this release. The story and characters are still some of the best in the series, even if some reveals feel like they're broadcasted on full blast to a well read adult. The gameplay is simplistic but with enough depth that you can get one or two full playthroughs in and still be entertained and find out new tricks. IMO, the only Tales game that outshines this one as of this date is Vesperia.

124070624.review:
Summery at the end. ~

I played this game many, many years ago on Gamecube and was instantly hooked: I especially enjoyed the characters, lore and story, as well as being able to play with friends during battles. I played through the whole game at least ten times (since I had more time on my hands, compared to now) and still had fun figuring out active skills ("Techs", which are divided in two groups, and each character can only learn one group or set of "Techs" at a time) and passive skills ("EX Skills", which are based on equipable gems that can be swapped), as well as through all the endgame bonus content and dungeons.

When the Remaster (or rather, slight graphical overhaul) got announced for PS3, I played it again - and to be honest, I was a little scared that a gaming gem of my past would turn out as a mediocre, overhyped piece of garbage when compared to newer, more modern games, or that my taste just changed during all these years. 

But on the contrary: I understood much more from the nuances in the stories, was able to appreciate characters and their motivation even more and also figured out many new and improved character builds and team compilations - in a game that I played a ton already, mind you.
Sure, the gameplay might get somewhat repetitive, but since there are a couple of characters to choose from (which all play differently) and you also can play with friends, it is more than enough to keep you entertained for a whole playthrough, or maybe two. 

Speaking of that: the main storyline takes roughly 50-70 hours to beat, and the game features an NG+ mode as well. 

In terms of presentation... well, Tales of Symphonia had its roots on Gamecube (and later PS2, which is also the version on Steam/PS3 is based on) and it shows. Thankfully, the style aged comparatively well and the music/voice acting is and was very good, but there could have been done more. They also included the bonus content from the (Japan exclusive) PS2 release. 

There are also some oldschool design choices that were pretty much part of classic JRPGs, like being able to miss major sidequests or hidden treasures, strong weapons and the like, which could be unwelcome during this day and age, but I think it makes the world feel more "alive" and authentic (compared to everything in it waiting and sitting there for the player to make sure he/she sees or stumbles over everything) and it also makes exploration and returning to former locations much more rewarding, as well as giving a good reason to start a new playthrough via New Game+.

In summery:
- great and engaging story and characters that can be enjoyed by all ages, with twists and turns
- a world that feels alive and changing
- somewhat spammy and repetitive gameplay that gets broken up by character and build choices
- acceptable graphics... at best
- good music and voice acting
- bonus content you might not have experienced, if you played the version on GC
- high replay value (for me at least)


I can recommend it wholeheartedly if you are into JRPGs and/or action based combat.

123245651.review:
Still a great classic game from a couple of decades ago now.  I mainly play other versions via emulation a bit more and have played this game over 5 times now start to finish, but this one is still solid with the latest patches applied.  

If for whatever reason you've listened to others and decided to hate this version for the 30fps lock that Bamco was to lazy to change from the PS2 port that all future versions were based on, I can understand, but I still recommend giving it a chance.  You can use Special K's ToSfix  (easy method) or Cheat Engine (will take more effort) to apply a  speed hack to increase the speed by 1.3x and it'll give you a nice brisk bump without making everything weird like a 2x speed and such would.  I think the content changes from the GC version are worth it and make the GC version obsolete, but if you really must, the GC version is out there.

All in all, a solid RPG with lovely characters, nice storytelling, side content, and decent gameplay for its time and alright now.  If you're interested in other Tales of titles on Steam, they're all worth a try too (be warned that Zestiria has some camera issues in battle).

122470695.review:
Like some JRPGs, this game doesn't stand against the test of time. The gameplay feels outdated especially during combat. The controls are very clunky and feels unresponsive. Maybe it was intended to be that way but there are better games with clunky controls that actually works.

The worse part is some enemies in this game, especially bosses love spamming the same attack. My assumption is that the bosses attack pattern is purely based on RNG, but if you get unlucky enough you'll get the boss to spam you its 1-shot attack every single time. It's still defeatable but it gets really frustrating when you see not even your allies have enough brain cells to avoid the attack despite me setting them to "Don't Pursue" in the Strats. Perhaps it's a poorly written RNG, or maybe it works differently on a PC with better CPUs?

Overall not a game I would not recommend it at anyone, even current generation Tales fan cause this game is just too old for what it is.

Graphically the game is alright for its age and while I don't think it matters, some people are upset the port is locked at 30 FPS. A lot of reviews rave about the combat, but the 2D movement on an open plane feels awful to me. Most of the combat is incredibly easy but the first shrine boss devolves into spamming items just to stay alive even with two healers. The AI also feels questionable at best even after trying different strategy commands. My favorite part is when Raine stands there doing nothing regardless of the commands she's set to. The basis of the story is fine especially if you look at the overall synopsis, but the actual dialogue is painful to listen to at times bordering on cringe. To many JRPG enthusiasts this may be a gem, but to me it feels rough and unpolished.

120804023.review:
Game is about 20 hours longer than it has any right to be. The game just wouldn't [i]end[/i]. Having finished Berseria within the last year, I thought that would comfortably be the worst Tales game I played, but this gives it a run for it's money for sure. I can't say how good this game might've been at the time it came out, but it has not aged well at all. Some of the most boring and lazily designed dungeons I've ever experienced. Rampant copy and paste tunnels and rooms.

Story: Mediocre/10 
Bland story that dragged on too long imo. If my understanding of what a half-elf is supposed to be is true, a decent amount of the story and motivations just don't make sense. 

Characters: 4/10
Personally the only characters I somewhat liked were Raine, Genis and Regal. Colette was fine, but just the personification of good. Nothing really to say about her other than that. Lloyd was just a protagonist. The other characters weren't terrible but not worth mentioning. Found myself ignoring the character conversation popups near the end. Also, most of the villains weren't threatening or memorable.

Music: 2/10 Not a [i]single[/i] background track stuck out to me. After 65 hours of playtime. Let that sink in.

Graphics: Cut Slack/10 
The game isn't exactly new, so I can't complain too much here. I'm sure the graphics were solid at the time.

Combat: 5/10 
Took a bit of getting used to but honestly not a bad as I originally thought. The fact that you could only move forward and back in relation to an enemy you're targeting gets really annoying though. Also, I must be an idiot or something, but only a few characters unlocked a mystic art? Not sure what's up with that.

tldr: 60 something hours down the drain I guess.

120623220.review:
To make this short and sweet. If you are a fan of tales games and never played this before, it is a story worth visiting.

While the story and game-play start slow, it picks up, and the character development just continues to grow.

This is an action RPG to the extent, with 3D combat, but it isn't the same as other Tales titles. It is important to note that while combat is 3D, the character can only move side to side. While this may seem annoying at first. It is functional, and combat is still pleasant.

The pace is well done, and if anything, most modern day games could learn from the plot and character development.

If you are a fan of Tales or action RPGs, and can look past the age, this game is a gem.

119824820.review:
A Charming fantasy adventure with plenty of clever plot twists.

The combat is accessible, but deviously dynamic behind the scenes. A stellar and recognizable English voice acting cast elevates the outdated aesthetics. But the Japanese Voices are much more prominent in the countless, optional, "slice of life" skits.

Symphonia is a pivotal game in the franchise as it's on the cusp of the early 3D entries, with few experimental "gimmicky" features. It's the buffer entry. Later games benefit from better graphics and art styles, and older entries will appeal to 16 bit 2 graphics better. Despite this, the game keeps pace with a well written story, made in an era before the modern robotic Shonen anime mannerisms.

A highlight entry in the franchise, one worth experiencing for first time players in the Tales Series with iconic characters.

Symphonia has been 1 of if not my top game for pretty much my entire life. Just recently finished another playthrough of the game and I found myself still getting choked up and shedding tears at some of the more emotional moments due to the fantastic voice work despite having seen these exact scenes countless times they still just hit perfectly.

Despite my love for this game I am not blind to it's flaws.

T and S type system is just plain stupid and you really should be able to just get every Tech without compromise. 

Terrible limitations on Mystic Artes makes glitches the only way to even use them viably.

Combo routes are definitely aged especially compared to newer games that typically offer complete freedom on combo game.

But honestly those are my only true gripes with the game even after MANY years of playing it.

If you are on the edge in your decision to play it then I say absolutely give it a go!

118891573.review:
Time to play the first tales of game represented in smash (by a mii costume)

+I am pleasantly surprised to say the combat was really fun. The tech combos you can pull off with some EX-skills you can get + the macros so you can use your teammates effectively. I did really only use Lloyd and Zelos for the most part but all the characters are fun.

+On that note, it is nice to see another Tales of game where there is no powercreep. You can use any character you so desire as long as you properly build and invest them. That being said it is highly encouraged to use everyone to build techs anyway. Exp is not a problem at all as everyone even those not in your party get it so I actually didn't need to grind at all in this game.

+The story of this game was excellent. I am honestly surprised I can say this story might even rival Vesperia's story for me. The way they tackled racism and sacrifice was well-executed. A fair amount of twists and turns in the story yet not linear and not predictable for the most part. Of course a lot of moral dilemmas in classic Tales fashion will be found. Definitely not your average hero saves the world story.

+I really just want to say the way they tackle stuff like discrimination, human experimentation, following dictators due to fear, etc. They felt very realistic and thus makes the events of the world more understandable even if we can't necessarily relate them to our daily lives.

+The characters are truly what makes the game for me. From the main duo of Lloyd and Colette to the funny antics of Sheena and Zelos to the discrimination Genis and Raine had to endure and the excellent backstories of Kratos, Presea and Regal. All of the cast were great and I am happy to say none of them were annoying and all were appreciated. Their relationship clearly grew as the game progressed and it was nice to see their dynamic throughout the game.

+Bonus that Lloyd Japanese VA is the same as Kamina from Gurren Lagann. Very inspiring.

+On top of the main cast, the antagonists and NPCs were well fleshed out and you can truly understand their motives. It is hard to talk about antagonists without spoiling the game but I can say just cause they are antagonists doesn't necessarily mean they had harmful intentions. This game really made it feel like every choice had its consequences.

+The dungeons were very creative. None of the dungeons were linear and they really required you to think to solve them. Some may be frustrating but I really appreciate the amount of effort put into these. The dungeons really didn't feel like you just find the way while beating all the enemies along the way. Definitely a big upgrade from the dungeons of the last Tales of game I played (Zestiria).

+The world was well-made. The many locations all felt unique and it truly felt like I was exploring the world when the many places I visited were different.

+This is the first Tales of game I played that does NOT have weapon skills. I personally disliked the weapon skill mechanic but just assumed it was part of the series. I am much much much happier with the EX skills given in this game as they are not only nongrindy but also don't rely on RNG. The EX skill system also lets you really customize your characters and play them the way you want. Some characters need some EX skills however (Raine with Concentrate) but for the most part you are free to build your characters however.

-Visually this game is not very good. I found the character models ugly and the anime scenes to be subpar. On this note of peripherals, the sound design was just annoying. I hated it when my characters had to walk on sand. The SFX of choice was just not good.

-I can't believe I have a game I like yet I didn't really like the music. The OST of this game was not standout and left much to be desired. I normally take notice to the OST of games but this one is just mid.

-No character swap-ins meaning theres only 4 characters when you go in a fight. No free-run so you can only move towards or away an opponent. Swapping controlled characters has no hotkey and you have to open the menu everytime to do it. There's a lot of dated mechanics with the combat despite being really fun.

-Clunky controls on the boat when you get it. Noishe didn't really add to much. Dodging enemies in the overworld and dungeons was extremely hard so you had to take almost every fight. Traversing didn't feel really nice also. It didn't help that the overworld felt a bit too big.

-I did mention how the dungeons felt very creative but and none were the same but some puzzles (the temple of darkness for one) were very frustrating and required a lot of backtracking. At least it did requires some brain power but the frustration was evident with a few of the dungeons.

-The tutorial system sucks. Just lots of textboxes and no showing so it is easy to forget some mechanics in the game.

Overall, great game and I definitely can see why some people say it's their favorite Tales of game. The narrative and characters really drive this one home.

116902072.review:
I first played Tales of Symphonia back in 2003 when it came out in the US, and it was the best game of my childhood hands down! For me, it takes first place over all the other JRPG favorites everybody talks about (like Final Fantasy, Dragon Quest, Persona, etc). I'm so happy there's a PC version and I've been able to start replaying it, and it's everything amazing I remembered it as (and better)! 

The cel shaded graphics are beautiful, nostalgic, and adorable at the same time. Honestly the whole game looks like a watercolor painting to me, with all the soft pastel colors and anime-like, yet realistic design. It's amazing how over time the graphics aged so gracefully. Also, the music is A+++! Dreamy and memorable for every town, and catchy and exciting for the battle themes.

Story wise, you can't beat Symphonia! Each character in your party has an incredible design and backstory, and it's both hilarious and intriguing seeing how they develop and interact. And despite the cuteness of the game, the story tackles deep social issues like religion, race, class, and politics in a way that really makes you think like no other games do. Without spoiling too much, it's great for both kids and adults and you can learn a lot from it. I also love the fantasy setting and Norse lore mixed in. 

Gameplay wise, Tales games are always exciting and unique! Live action fighting while your party members help you out. Your friends or the whole family can each control a party member too, which makes it a really fun bonding experience! Still not a lot of RPGs like this where the whole family can enjoy together, which I think is an incredibly special aspect of the game.

Overall! if you're an rpg fan and hesitating, don't hesitate anymore! Definitely the best Tales game in the series for me, and the best JRPG I've played. So much nostalgia, the world just doesn't make games like this anymore I swear haha!

115494127.review:
Este juego, es uno de esos juegos el cual, he tardado años en acabarlo, 2 y medio de hecho, y no porque tenga una duración exagerada, de hecho, el juego dura unos 60 horas. Nada mal. Sin embargo, uno de los motivos por el cual he tardado tantos años en acabarlo, es porque los personajes, no son precisamente, agradables, no en el sentido que son antipáticos, sino que tienen rasgos que los hace difícil sobrellevar. 
Por decirlo plena y clara, Lloyd (el personaje principal) es un pedante y se queja por todo, Collete (protagonista femenina principal), es una tonta que va dispuesta a ser el sacrificio, Genis es un sabiondo y la profesora, pues tiene fetiche por cualquier cosa que tenga más de 50 años y el único medio-normal es el mercenario (excepto que es el típico mercenario callado, misterioso y tajante). 

Con esto,  que sea una historia tipo peregrinación y el hecho de encontrar a semi-elfos nazis con toda la lista incluida de villanos de turno, pues si, no es algo que sintiese ganas de seguir jugando, sin olvidar lo lioso que es el combate en el inicio. 

Bien, eso puede parecer que el juego, es malo, pero de hecho, tras forzarme a jugar un poco más (en parte, gracias al finalizar Phantasia), he descubierto que el juego no era tan malo como pensaba, de hecho, incluso me ha gustado y me parece un buen JRPG que no puede faltar en la biblioteca. De hecho, al final, me había incluso olvidado de los semi-elfos nazis (que si bien, son importantes, en realidad son usados por unos cuantos, y tienen su finalidad), ya que la trama de Lloyd y cierto personaje cercano importante (que no diré, porque son spoilers de mid para  lategame) y como interactúan ambos, está bien hecho, y después, está el hecho de que sabe mezclar perfectamente la frase de "para que uno viva, otro tiene que sufrir". Aparte, los personajes, mejoran (excepto la profesora.... que no se ve un cambio, ni positivo ni negativo) y la trama tipo peregrinación, deja incluso de tener importancia, por lo que cambia a uno en el cual, hay que salvar a Collette (unas cuantas veces, de hecho, y no solo físicamente) para luego, intentar descifrar lo que sucede y finalmente aprender las motivaciones del villano principal. Eso no quita que haya algunos momentos que flojea un poco, como cuando se sacrifica un personaje con tal de salvar el grupo y Lloyd sobreactua a pesar de que cuando lo conocimos, al principio, acabamos peleándonos contra él, yo me quedé en plan "¿esa muerte tengo que tomarlo como algo importante ?" o cuando en un momento dado, hay como una fiebre (metafóricamente hablando) que hace que todos los personajes principales  deseen sacrificarse, uno detrás de otro en cuestión de minutos y "mueran" para que aparezcan a salvar el prota en el momento más oportuno. Pero de todas formas, sus pros, los considero mayores que sus contras.

Si al adquirir este juego, sientes que no es lo tuyo, animo que intentes pasar de los 10/20 horas, porque es un juego, algo duro de llevar, sobre todo, al inicio, y si a pesar de todo, sigue resistiéndose, prueba la versión de Tales of Phantasia (que es lo que yo hice antes de jugar a este), que aunque es más antiguo, lleva mejor la historia, sus personajes e incluso, su antagonista principal cosa que Symphonia, aunque no malo, de hecho, me ha gustado, si que flojea un poco en esos 3 aspectos.

Muy buen juego en conclusión. De una cosa mal que hace, 3 los hace bien.

115105571.review:
Great game, bad port. It's Gamecube Tales of Symphonia with more bell and whistle at the cost of half the frame rate and polish.

The game still plays great at 30 fps, but I dare you to play this game a bunch at then look at Gamecube footage. It's so smooth that I would rub my face with it. Lack of polish will stare at your face pretty much each time you boot the game. Why does the main menu music stops playing when getting in the load save file menu? That didn't happen before. Also, why does the voice acting is so quiet for every new ability added since the PS2 version? And that's only the most obvious example. It's a real shame.

Honestly, even though I bought this game at 5$, I still feel a bit ripped off seeing how much Namco doesn't care about this game, just like most Japanese publisher do about their old catalog (it's that right Square?). I still think it is worth the purchase thanks to steam save cloud and what not, but I can't fault anyone who decide to emulate the GameCube original instead.
