115093451.review:
I have tales of Vesperia and zesteria on steam as well and they are also very nice games but I haven't beat them yet. Only other tales games I beat besides this one are phantasia and destiny. Phantasia was the first tales game I played way back on SNES. An old friend recommended it to me, and even tho he beat it, I never could beat that game till recently. Its a great game and on SNES its comparable in graphics to chrono trigger, final fantasy 6, and breath of fire 2. Which is really good, TOP actually amazed me back in the day, how good the graphics and magic were. But it wasn't an easy game, long and super grindy. But it got me into the series, so I decided to start with this one on steam. It sometimes goes for 5$ on sell. For the price its one of the better jrpg deals you can get on pc. So if you wanna test the series out but don't want to buy a snes/psx/ps2 then this is the best option on pc for a good price. If you enjoy it then you'll probably enjoy the higher priced ones like zesteria/vesperia. Vesperia seems closest in tradition to symphonia imo, cept with much better cell shading. Symphonia was a game I saw way back on Gamecube and wanted it but never got a chance to. I had  zelda the windwaker back then and was really sold on cell shading. Also loved jet grind radio. Having it now, I really didn't expect it to be so good. At the time I was just interested in any good rpg on gamecube because GC didn't exactly have a lot of jrpgs. This game is heavy, heavier than most Final fantasies even. If you buy this game, be ready for a long playthrough just to beat the game might take you 40-80 hours depending on how you play. With extras, unlocks, alternate costumes, and achievements, damn I've heard anywhere from 300-1000 hours not joking. That's how frickin huge this game is...
So yea worth 5$ on sell imo. I would look at this as kinda like an elder scrolls game don't buy it with a complete it mindset. Get it for the fun and gameplay. I beat it once and going through it again for some of the other stuff like optional bosses and items. Its really a good game, and has a great postgame as well with tons of little things to do. You can get to around lvl 250 also I've heard. I've yet to scratch the surface in what all you can do but I have beat the main game 1 time and its nice, great ending, great characters, good music too. Just that expect more light and quirky than epic over the top godmonster like final fantasy. That's whats kind of the appeal here its more like a fun anime cartoon with a lot of silly humor than serious. Altho there is some serious stuff its never to the point of other rpgs, or even other tales games (lot of the earlier tales were way more serious).  

The dungeons can also be a bit complicating and there's always some complex puzzle to do so just letting you know you might get stuck a bit at times. I kept pushing on cause I really liked the characters and storyline. The summon volt in particular was a very rough dungeon. But its an extremely rewarding game and when you finish it there's a lot to do with the new plus features. There's all kinds of other little things like cooking recipes and stuff, but really this is an epic jrpg and not light in anyway so don't buy this thinking it'll just be an easy grind game its not its very complicating and challenging. 

Even more so than the older tales games, like phantasia. Not to say phantasia is light either but compared to this it is... But if you wanna test out the tales games for a good price, love cell shading, like child hood friendship story lines and coming of age romance, and a good battle system, can't go wrong here I really enjoy it. Just don't expect to complete the game without a LOT of effort.

113423240.review:
I am writing this review as someone who has never played a tales game before. 

I just beat tales of symphonia and it was....good and bad. I would say 6/10 

It takes the classic formula of a jrpg and adds a nice, real time battle system to it . The gameplay is fun and simple enough to get the hang of yet takes time to master. The progression throughout the game means not much grinding is required. the levelling system/ tech system is alright. nothing innovative. "use x move 50 times to unlock y". the whole T/S made not much sense and I ignored it pretty much and still made it to the end with no real difficulty. This game will not challenge you (maybe the end game content...but even then is grinding a challenge? Not for me thanks)

Now, many on here who are fans of the story i feel are looking at this through nostalgic glasses. The story starts of like your classic jrpg trope boy from village on path tp save the world. But from this it goes down a series of extremely convoluted paths and obvious tropes . Add a few twists in you could see coming a mile away. Add that to the last 20% of the game where I had NO idea what was going on by the end and it gets the story wrapped up by even more bs that I honestly had to google for an explanation. (which even though was honestly unsatisfactory)

Some of the writing is cringe inducing honestly. it is a dated game though and it is forgiven and on the whole the writing was decent enough. A very nice moral story that they sometimes take a stick and beat you with. But I liked the message at least 

You can play it again on a sort of new game +...but why would you . it does have endgame content but beyond a couple of bosses and an arena, there is nothing else really to do. 

Still I would recommend it on sale I suppose. It fixed an itch and for the first 80% of the game I was having fun. The ending though...sheesh....just run through it. its not like you won't absolutely smash every boss with zero effort anyway. 

I'd say 6/10 maybe? I do want to try another tales game though, I think this installment has laid some serious groundwork done and I can see why the future installments are spoken highly of. I wanted to start at the beginning.

113313538.review:
[h1]THE GOOD[/h1]
+Despite being able to feel its age, I found the combat of Symphonia to be just as fun as the more recent titles in the series, such as Tales of Arise.
+A story that manages to be long without overstaying its welcome. Each plot point comes and goes at just the right pace.
+Every main character is highly likeable, and they go through a ton of interesting character development.
+Timeless art direction that still looks great.
+Plenty of side content which is genuinely just there if you actually want to do it.

[h1]THE BAD[/h1]
-Locked at 30 FPS, despite the Gamecube version running at 60.
-Dungeons slow the game down a little too much. The puzzles are decent, but can involve some painful trial and error.
-While I can appreciate a lack of handholding, the story is sometimes a little too unclear about where to go next.

[h1]SCORE: 83%[/h1]

112607166.review:
Grew up with this game and I've beaten it probably 30 times. This review is entirely based on how good the port is. It took around two hours of forum diving/googling/experimentation and setup, which might be a somewhat high barrier to entry for this port of the game.

It's mandatory to use TSfix, which means SpecialK injector is necessary, which means that dll errors and a lot of install jank is mandatory. When you figure it out though, it's great and you can even get 60fps with it in most areas (old game, speed is based on frame rate, GC version was heavily coded differently to compensate for 60fps, etc etc, everyone who has emulated old games knows this).

If it wasn't for TSfix, this would be inferior to the dolphin; but having a multiplayer-compatible camera and being able to just download the latest versions of TSfix's "dlc" (texture pack and model fixes, mostly) is really handy. Being able to run the game in the background and edit it directly on your computer is nice too.

As far as whether or not you should play Tales of Symphonia itself, obviously yes. If you haven't ever played this, it's a classic and the PC port isn't shaky anymore thanks to patches and fixes years ago. This game is on the same level as something like Chrono Trigger or Earthbound because it defined it's own niche in the RPG genre and many games are compared to it for a very good reason. Certainly it's not as popular as those games, but for 2003/2004, it was around as ambitious and successful with that ambition. The story and characters are charming and compelling, the combat is approachable and simple but very satisfying and easy to experiment with, the replayability is extremely high (thanks grade system), and there isn't any real BS. Just old-game jank that doesn't harm the game's overall experience much at all. Like, this game doesn't need me to introduce it; it's Tales of Symphonia. Play it.

112152463.review:
[h1]A Classic Gem[/h1]
I highly recommend this game if you want a classic action JRPG to play. This is a good game to start with if you haven't played a JRPG before or if you are interested in trying the Tales of series.

Pros:
[list]
[*] Strong narrative story that keeps you wanting more
[*] Large cast of fun party members
[*] Fantastic music
[*] Fantastic art style
[*] Includes extras from the Japanese exclusive PS2 enhanced port
[*] Dual audio English and Japanese
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*]Early English dub acting can be hit or miss sometimes
[*] Locked to 30 fps, has minor issues when forced into 60 fps from a mod
[*] Requires 5 playthroughs to 100% the game
[*] Skits in English are not voiced but are timed to the Japanese skits, requiring full attention sometimes or you'll miss half of a few sentences
[/list]

It was nice to revisit a game I grew up playing.

Personal rating: [b]8.5/10[/b]

Antes de dar la razón por la que no recomiendo este juego tengo que aclarar que no es tan malo, dicho esto comienzo.

MI RESEÑA CONTIENE SPOILERS, ESTAS ADVERTIDO/A

- El juego narra una historia que está bien contada pero tiene todo el tiempo un aire constante que hace que todo sea algo cliché, monótono y predecible. El sistema de combate es original a su manera pero se vuelve muy tosco a la hora de querer que tus compañeros no se metan encima de las habilidades del enemigo (si, ya se que se les puede ordenar ir atrás o estar a la defensiva pero aún así les quita participación en el combate, hace que el único personaje que valga la pena controlar es Lloyd por sus combos y no me gusta eso).

- La interfaz del juego es muy fea al igual que los items, reciclan varios iconos y les cambian el nombre y ya es un item distinto pero la verdad lo unico que me gustó realmente fue la intro anime con su soundtrack.

- La animación en el mapa mundi de Lloyd montando a Noishe es lo más robótico que vi y contrasta mucho en el juego, ya que para tantas animaciones y movimientos en combate no me podes poner a Lloyd mas duro que tornillo de submarino flotando en Noishe, no se como se les pasó por alto darle una animación al montar a la mascota que hace que termine pareciendo que Lloyd montara una motocicleta estando acostado sobre ella.

- El juego lo dejé luego de que Kratos traiciona al grupo, la verdad ya había tantos acontecimientos predecibles pero este se venía oliendo y dije "como Kratos me traicione y Sheera deje el team, desinstalo" y pasó osea xD

- ¡Ups! Iba caminando por un cruce y me choco con una persona que ni ella ni yo nos vimos venir y se rompe una poción (que es valiosa y por ende debería estar bien cuidada) que pertenece a unos tipos que tienen estética de maleante, que te hablan con ataques pasivo/agresivos, te amenazan y tras  yo haber matado y luchado por menos con muchos enemigos ¿que crees que haces para resolverlo? ¿Pelear? 109344495.review:
[h1]Comentario Robótico-Analítico: "Tales of Symphonia"[/h1]

Tales of Symphonia es un clásico JRPG destacable en casi todo lo que lo compone, y cuyo mayor defecto está en algunas carencias del port a PC que poco a poco fueron solucionando, pero que tras varias actualizaciones y un parche no oficial, siguen vigentes para algunos usuarios.

Y si uno de los pocos defectos de un título está en el port y no en el juego per se, es porque se trata de una obra excelente.

Tales of Symphonia no limita su argumento, sabe llevarlo más allá y consigue enganchar incluso en su extensa duración, en parte gracias a la belleza de su banda sonora, su estética y los momentos animados. En lo que a jugabilidad respecta maneja un modelo convencional de JRPG clásico cuanto menos hasta el combate, en donde se hará uso de comandos pre-establecidos para definir las tácticas de nuestros aliados.

Este juego fue una grata sorpresa. Cabe destacar que hay muchas diferencias entre esta versión y la de consolas, pero no las puedo corroborar.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Muy recomendable.

107475557.review:
This game is a classic and I think anyone that hasn't played it should give it a shot. It has a great story line and plenty of content to munch through. The character design is great and every character has a life of their own. The dungeons have puzzles that keep the game from getting too repetitive. There is a lot of depth to this game.

On the other hand, the combat system is not for everyone. You can play through the game on auto-mode, but that takes a lot of the fun out of it. If you want to 100 percent complete the game you will need to either play through it several times, or use a strategy guide. The camera system takes some getting used to, and items for crafting will take a lot of farming. Time, effort, and research is needed to get the most out of your experience.

Overall, I think it is an awesome game that has quite a few quirks to it. Even if you are experienced with RPGs, I would recommend taking some time to look at the strategy guide. Otherwise you will play through the first half of the game backwards, and miss out on some really cool titles and achievements.

106799108.review:
Having forced myself to finish this game, I've concluded that most of the good reviews here are people viewing this game through rose-tinted glasses.

[h3]Story[/h3]
This goes on for WAY too long. You go around collecting loads of summons for every element under the sun. The formula for each one is pretty much the same. Go to some tower/dungeon. Solve the puzzle there. Battle a dungeon boss. Rinse and repeat about 15 times. 

[h3]Graphics[/h3]
The graphics are cell-shaded 3D. It gives it a bit of a timeless look, but some of the textures are way too low for modern screen resolutions. I would have preferred more life-like proportioned characters. The game forces you to play at 720p. There is an unofficial patch to allow you to play fullscreen borderless window mode but it has bugs occassionally where the screen goes blank or the animation graphics don't play.

[h3]Sound[/h3]
The background music is OK. I didn't have to mute it but I wasn't looking forward to listening to any of the tunes either. I was disappointed to find out that there were no English dubs for "skits". That gives me the impression they "cheaped" out on it.

[h3]Battle System[/h3]
The best selling point of this game is the action-oriented battle system. It looks like you can have multiple players for the fights and I can imagine this game being quite fun between a couple of friend or siblings around 12 years old. It's a shame most people would probably not experience this playing alone on the PC.

One tip from me for XBOX gamepad users. Do yourself a favour and swap the default bindings for "Defend" and "Techs". This lets you rest your right-thumb joint over the 'B' button to block.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
Overall, I cannot recommend this game. There are better and more interesting games to spend your time playing out there.

106253455.review:
First J-RPG I bought and played for a home console back when the Game Cube was a thing. This thing blew my mind at just how lengthy, detailed and humongous of a game it was. It needed two discs back in the day. TWO! There is certainly some nostalgic value when I review this one positively.

Gotta admit, back as a kid my English wasn’t that great and there weren’t online guides, so I thought the game was far more challenging that I do now since my build was… sub-optimal, to put it mildly. Now under a new perspective the game still holds its own against its peers even after so many years; graphics are fair, voice acting – Japanese – did a pretty good job, the content is considerable and the choices you can make to change your gameplay are fairly significant which at the game were pretty impressive, I would say. You have your New Game+ mode and different difficulties if you really want to go over the journey all over again.

The story is your classic ‘boy from small village goes on a journey to save the world’ but it’s a bit more complex than that; we start small, plot thickens, it thickens more, and the payoff at the end is fine. J-RPGs have been using morally gray characters as interesting villains for a while now, even if they do like their incorruptible, good-two-shoes bright-eyed-child savior; but it works.

I'm told this game is a classic, and that it has an amazing story and characters. I'm quite certain that's true.
However, this game has a bit of a problem that gets in the way of that - it's a 3D console game made in the early 2000s, when developers were still trying to figure out how to make them. 

And it has [i]not[/i] aged well. Actually playing the game is like pulling teeth. The experience is slow and clunky, and it lacks many of the modern QoL features we take for granted today.

If the game is ever remade - which is possible, considering that everyone seems to love it - then I'll play that. I won't be touching the original again and I wouldn't recommend that you touch it either.

106137675.review: I went into this game not expecting too much, but despite the very dated graphics, Tales of Symphonia is an incredible RPG that stays fun and compelling throughout basically the entire game. The combat fun and unique, combining real time combat and strategy in an amazing blend. This isn't the first game in the series to do this, mind you, but there is a reason that people consider Symphonia one of the best RPGs of all time. It is so fun progressing through the game and seeing how much your characters get stronger. RPGs are supposed to do this, but this game does a better job than most I have played in the past. The gameplay progression in Symphonia is also one of the most balanced I have seen. You are always just strong enough to beat the bosses in or two tries, and just weak enough that it is still a challenge. While regular battles are fun too, boss battles are the highlight of this game. While dealing as much damage as possible and blocking attacks, you are conserving TP and items trying to heal you and your teammates. It is an interesting blend of real time skill and resource management and strategy that works the best during these boss battles. While outside of battles this game definitely feels more dated and the graphics have not aged very well, don't let that discourage you from playing. Tales of Symphonia is an excellent game for new and old fans of RPGs and I recommend anyone even slightly interested to give this game a shot.

105450162.review:
There are certain tropes associated with JRPGs, just as there are any other genre, like "zombies and violence," "platformers and princesses/imposing bosses," and "plumbers and turtles," but this particular JRPG seems to transcend those tropes and deliver something beyond "kawaii," "big eyes," and "stop staring at me, senior!" To start with, the stories in this game go well beyond the main story, which is mainly about Collette, the "Chosen" who must go on a journey to save the world, Lloyd, the adopted son of a dwarf who sees more in the world than his cynical counterparts, and Raine and Genis, who are two siblings who suffer discrimination on their journeys.
There are more than 8 playable characters throughout the game, and none of them feel like side-characters. They each have their own fully fledged stories and backstories, either explicit or implied, that are explored, either as a main-through, or told in cut up parts throughout the game. There are deeper themes involved than "go there and slice 'em up." The themes vary from self-sacrifice to save others, refusing to give in to hopelessness and cynicism just to become an indifferent self-serving individual like those around you, and the difficult choice of deciding to trust someone again, even if they crushed your hope into a million pieces. These themes arise from the game's focus on "emotional resonance," which gives the game an emotional depth and wide breadth of emotional experiences that, sadly, few games ever focus on, and instead choose to divert the entirety of their energy into profitability, not richness of experience.
Of course, the size of the world and the maps are not boring, the number of unique enemies, and types of strategies are enough to keep you interested in playing for a while, and the slashing and spellcasting are quite satisfying for a game of its time. The design is not groundbreaking, the replayability is alright, and the combat is amazing, but for its value in nostalgia, storytelling, and focus on characters, it is not a bad value for its price.

I have only played for 15 or so minutes, but main things to consider

103966062.review:
Tales of Symphonia is a 3D Action JRPG game that foretells a Tale of Segregation/Discrimination. Released originally on the Gamecube/PS2 and then having rereleased on PS3/Steam. 

Our main character Lloyd (Same VA as Robin from Teen Titans) acts as a body guard for Colette who goes on a journey of world salvation. Seeking out the seals and Colette slowly becoming an angel. As the adventure progresses, NPCs mention about how half-elves are evil and conduct world destruction. While many of the villains are half-elves, this also puts a problem for certain characters who are also half-elves and aren't evil. Lloyd and crew also seek a way to end segregation - while continuing their journey of salvation.  

Combat is real time action where using basic hits and skills to chain combos with CPU party members is needed to succeed in the game. I will say this though, Symphonia has a tough beginning game and gets easier as the game progresses. Equipment system is very basic and easy to keep on track. The only drawback the game has is questionable puzzle design choices in dungeons.

In conclusion, Tales of Symphonia is a great game and great as a starter entry to the series. Sure it does feel outdated; however this was really impressive when it first came out. This was the 3rd Tales game I've finished (Berseria > Vesperia > Symphonia).

103200238.review:
It isn't perfect but I love it anyway. At its heart it's a 2.5D hack-n-slash dungeon-crawler inside an anime RPG.

Good graphics (stylized but not photorealistic). Good music (one of my favorite OSTs). Combat system is simple to learn and excel at for basegame but surprisingly difficult to get good enough at for the optional side content (yes even on normal difficulty; this is Namco there is no easy mode lmao). VERY VERY LONG if you want to do and see everything, but even if you wanna just coast through it and do the bare minimum to roll the credits taking the time to relax and enjoy the story... it's still pretty long all things considered and it's a very engaging story [about fun things like grief & loss, racism & caste discrimination, religious oligarchy, literal fascists running concentration death camps, and... FRIENDSHIP! :D ...yes i am being 100% serious].

There are no less than 9 systems in place for strategy and mechanics (beyond "mash the x/A button until the bad guy dies"), and only one of them has anything to do with your characters' stats directly, so skill and strategy are wholly responsible for your advancement- there are no "character builds", it's more a mandatory job system. Fighters do physical damage, white mage heals, black mage does magic damage, jack of all trades do everything decently. You can adapt things to your playstyle, focus more attention on different characters if you like them more, revert most changes, or just stick it out and try again in new game plus with either buffs or nerfs to various things (with points you earn based on how well you do and how much you're willing to grind).

...I can't do this. Screw being analytical and using facts and logic, time to get emotional and anecdotal.

This is my favorite RPG. Fallout, Persona, Mass Effect, Dark Souls, System Shock, Final Fantasy, they are also fantastic RPG series I love, but I genuinely love this game more than all of them. In fact, scaling for cohesion length content etc, this is my favorite video game, of all time. Resident Evil 4, Dead Space, Metro Redux, Half-Life, Jak & Daxter, Metroid Prime, yeah yeah they're all great. I still love this game more. When I was 6 I got a brand new Gamecube for my birthday, my first exposure to video games that wasn't Atari or an arcade cabinet, I got Soul Calibur 2, Metroid Prime, Lord of the Rings: Return of the King, and my cousin let me play his copies of Ghost Recon, Falsebound Kingdom, and Tales of Symphonia. I played those games for hundreds if not thousands of hours growing up and they all left their mark on me, but none did as much as Symphonia did and it will always hold a special place in my heart. But I never stopped replaying it. For 20 years I've played and loved this game. I read the manga twice. I listen to the OST on my regular playlist. I've read transcripts of the drama CDs' audio. I'm rewatching the anime for the fourth time with my boyfriend. I have the Gamecube and the controller that came with it with a dozen saves on the memory card that came with it, all at the foot of my bed ready and waiting to be plugged into my CRTTV, and yet I bought this again on Steam, and if it wasn't hundreds of dollars and I could read Japanese I would buy it on PS2 as well. When I was in middle school I found and read a 136,000 word fanfiction that crossed it over with Invader Zim and Harry Potter in an afternoon. My love for this game is absolutely absurd and borderline obsession, and has been for 70-80% of my life. So why am I telling you all of this?

If you only like this game 10% as much as I do, you'll still have a damn good time.

102389394.review:
For better or worse, this game is a great example of an RPG from it's era.  The plot twists and turns it's way through 40-60 hours of content, which some side stuff available for those who explore around.  Sometimes the plot makes sense...sometimes it doesn't.

As with many RPGs from the era, the dungeons are varied but a bit painful.  Be prepared to backtrack around, have to re-fight the same enemies over and over while you figure things out, and become sick of pushing and pulling boxes around.  Fortunately, the ability to set the characters to auto-combat helps out tremendously in alleviating the fights.  The monsters are on the map and can sometimes be avoided, but often you'll be running down narrow paths and cannot avoid them.

I did have a tendency to get stuck on path edges sometimes.  Again, a relic of the era...but it was frustrating trying to dodge around an enemy and then start running in place because I had found the invisible edge of the path.  

I had to restart once because I managed to get myself cornered in a room by an NPC that paced around.  Since I was in the spot the NPC was trying to path to, he couldn't get out of my way and I couldn't get out of his.  Save often, just in case.

I would've loved a "quick-save" feature so that I could stop playing and shut down the game at any time without finding a save point, but dungeons aren't terribly long.  Not the end of the world...I'm guessing they wanted to keep as much of the original mechanics as possible.

The game is vibrant and the soundtrack suits the mood.  The characters can be a bit edgy at times, but that is typical from this era.  In my opinion, the game overstayed it's welcome just a bit and could've been about 10 hours shorter.  Ignore my listed playtime...I have a newborn in the house and had to walk away from the game from time-to-time.

Typically when deciding if a game is worth it, I measure how much time I enjoyed the game and compare it to the game's cost.  If it comes out to worthwhile entertainment for under a dollar an hour then I got a great deal.  I feel like even if I had paid full price, I would've gotten that from this game...so if anyone is interested in a good example of RPGs from this era, you should give it a shot.

102290319.review:
I haven't played this since the Gamecube, and it holds up. It's just a shame the Chronicles version was limited by the PS2 version. Sure it had more content, but also had worse performance. It's sadly felt a bit here, but it's still fun at least in my opinion.

There's a lot of content to go through, and in Tales fashion a lot to keep track of if you want to be able to actually do everything. I don't think this has quite as many hard to hit/follow triggers like Vesperia, but I guess an older game being simpler makes sense (at least before modern games became worse). 

The music is great, the characters are all enjoyable. I was surprised just how much was vividly burned into my brain given I hadn't played it in so long and had only played it once. The story is not that much to write home about, but it does the job. Playing right after Vesperia there's a lot of similar concepts and themes in the overall story. 

The combat isn't as slow to start, it's fun if a bit simple at times. It's also more simple depending on where you upgrade your EX Skills. Being able to link stuff makes it a lot more engaging than it otherwise would be. Thankfully unlike Vesperia you don't need to do anything for backsteps, recovering from knock up/backs, etc. IT's all there by default.

The AI I couldn't stop from randomly running toward enemies. Even having them not attack they'd still run up toward enemies for some reason. *shrug* Might just be me and not the game though I know it took me awhile to figure out Vesperia, but that was more complex with AI than this one.

The main issue I have with the game is that you can easily get stuck on stuff while moving around. The camera will stutter while it happens in some cases too which is annoying. It's just a bit wonky. I don't remember having this issue on Gamecube but that also had the weird hexagon thing around it's analog and you can still 'feel' that type of movement despite not using that controller. So maybe that's why?

It's a great JRPG. The only other criticism is the Japanese audio, a lot of things aren't translated for some reason. Like bosses dying dialog, or some of Presea's original victory dialog before a certain story shift in her character. I think literally just one enemy actually had her loss dialog show up translated. It's kind of a bummer. And in battle dialog for bosses is also not translated. So you'll miss out on some stuff if you don't speak Japanese and choose that as your language option.

100964993.review: I beat this game with my brother back when it first came out for the GameCube, and I got it to play again, all these years later. And it still holds up really, really well. This game really solidified all the gaming tropes you see in every JRPG since: A journey to save the world, element-based dungeons and bosses, young heroes that at a certain point start to feel like powerful demigods, a local economy that just so happens to match your current level, tech is evil while nature is good - and those are just a few of the spoiler-free tropes. And I love Every. Single. One of Them. This game is still engaging and fun, even if its a story you've heard a thousand times in other games by this point. The heroes are really likable, Lloyd Irving is young and naively idealistic without feeling whiny or incapable of character growth. Colette Brunel is soft-spoken and vulnerable, but isn't without the will or power to step up and fight or do things for herself. I found the side story of Genis and Raine the most compelling in the game: dealing with injustice, racism, fear of your friends' rejection, and the best way to deal with others' prejudice. This was one of the first games I played that really dealt with those themes. And there are a bunch of interesting side-stories woven in that make this game worth every penny.

100957699.review: Best Tales Game. Change My Mind, Ps super fun and amazing story

100909140.review:
A dated classic, but still a classic. There are some pros and cons to being based off the PS3 version(which in turn is based off the PS2 version) of the game as opposed to the Gamecube version, like bits of extra content while being stuck at 30 FPS, but the fact remains that this is a very charming game, that those who remember playing it way back when can tell you, it's from a time where games weren't necessarily the best at telling you about its gameplay systems and where to go/what to do, but it definitely encouraged you check menus, read everything, use your brain/instincts, and just have fun with what was at the time a very unique battle system that, while having better future iterations, is still very fun, and also multi-player! 

If you're coming from Tales of Arise or even Berseria/Zestiria, be warned: this is the kind of game that doesn't even explain how to switch characters mid-battle very easily, but if you're into that sort of player discovery, then you're getting a very fun history lesson to fill out some holes in your JRPG knowledge.

Now here's to hoping we get many more entries in the series like Graces and the Xillia games on Steam soon.

100660560.review:
Can't compare this to other games in the series as this is my first but while some of the mechanics and areas felt dated I had a great time. Battle system felt good overall if a bit sluggish in places, I liked the game's graphics style, and I loved the characters and overall story. 
Dungeons had a lot of clever mechanics and puzzles for the most part but some were very annoying with loads of waiting and backtracking in a couple select areas. The inclusion of local co-op is a genius idea and I can see myself hopping into friends' games over remote play sometime. The amount of side content and how the New Game+ system works makes the game great for replayability, though you will want a guide if you don't want to miss anything.
The PC port seems hit or miss though, game is locked at 30fps if you care about that and I did have a couple crashes at the midpoint of the game, but your mileage may vary as I've seen people with much less or more problems than me.

7.5/10, great game that holds up fairly well, though there's a chance you may have problems with the port

98705375.review:
The usual over convoluted story is expected in japanese RPGs, but Jesus Christ does this one drag out. When you think it finally feels like the story ends, it turns out you're only half way through and once you're done with the other half it turns out you're only 2/3 through the story. The ham-fisted messages about racism, tradition and friendship just isn't enough to justify the length either.

The anime cutscenes are beautiful, but sadly there are way too few of them. I would definitely watch a show or movie in that quality. The overall artstyle and design of the game are really great as well, but that is due to the limitations of the time it was made.

The combat itself is simple but really good... for like 10 hours and from there it's just too much of the same. There's also the terrible AI. You can set strategies for them, but they barely act on what you set before and you will find warriors doing nothing on the backside of the battlefield, while the mages cast spells right next to the enemies. The game is set for 4 players and it really shows with the AI.

To conclude: Mediocre convoluted JRPG story, pretty good real time combat, terrible Team-AI and overall too long for it's own good. It's too good to give it a negative review, but it's a long exhausting ride.

Time to finish: 57 hours that feel twice that long.

This was my very first Tales of game, and I've heard a lot of good things leading up to me finally playing it. So I had some pretty high expectations going into the game, and I gotta say I like it a lot and highly recommend it.

Even though when I first started it took me a little bit to actually get the hang of combat, and even after finishing the game I still only feel really comfortable playing as Lloyd. I wish I could figure out how to use the other characters more properly but oh well.

The story for this game is pretty good, though basically what you'll expect from a JRPG, although I thought the game would end like 3 times before it actually did, like the characters even say this will be the final battle like 3 times before it actually was, and each time it totally could have been the end of the game but something happened to keep the story going, but by the end I really enjoyed all that the characters went through. 

There is a pretty big cast of characters and I gotta say that by the end of it I really liked everyone in the party, they all just felt like friends going on an adventure by the end. The "Skits" in the game, which are basically just the party talking in games like Dragon Quest really expanded the character's personalities and made me like them even more than just the actual cut scenes. I also liked the antagonists of the game, though I wish some of them got more screen time. 

Also the game has a lot of good conversations about life questions such as discrimination and stuff like that, which are still prevalent today. And overall I highly recommend this game despite some of the minor problems that are in the game.

96437081.review:
Ahhh...Tales of Symphonia. This is a classic "Tales of" title, released in 2003 in JP and 2004 in EU and NA. One of the greatest games created by Bandai Namco in my opinion. It has character development, creative story and interesting battles throughout the game, as well as fun mini-games, collectibles and a huge world to explore. THIS was the game that has stuck with me the longest, right next to games such as Zelda: Ocarina of Time and Skyrim. 

This game is not only nostalgic, but holds up pretty well, especially with some fixes. But not all aged well with this game, and I recommend a few fixes to optimize your experience.

This game is in my top 5 favorite games of all time. PLEASE, read the issues with a grain of salt and DEFINITELY give it a try. If it's your first time, I HIGHLY recommend playing with Japanese voices, setting the control to "manual" and explore AS MUCH as the game allows when you can.

First, before I go into detail here, please keep in mind this game is LONG, and because of this, it has some unfortunate aspects that really show an uglier side of it's age.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
Note: This section is in no particular order.
[list]
[*] Animations for certain actions during impactful cut-scenes can be quite cheesy or borderline hilarious. Mind you, the game is trying to be serious, but these actions can be quite amusing to look at. I will say this though: I was able to look past this, still feel the emotion the game was conveying and enjoy the story. But this may be somewhat off-putting to some people so I thought I'd add it.

[*] English voice acting is quite bad. Unfortunately, nostalgia disallows me to play it in Japanese (at least on my first play-through) but I'll definitely be going back through in Japanese the next time around. More content is covered in Japanese, and the voice acting is [b]much[/b] better.

[*] I [b]cannot stress enough[/b] how bad the camera is in this game. It's okay in most situations, but while walking around the overworld, the camera will drive you crazy. The game explains that this is somewhat intentional, but honestly, it's infuriating not being able to see where you're going. There is a long-range mode that improves this (you'll find out) but you have to walk around blind to find the monument to allow you to be able to use long-range mode. In addition to the above issue, if playing with a friend, you will not be able to see one or the other if the players choose both a long range and a close range character. Basically meaning, you both must choose close or long range, otherwise someone will not be able to see what is happening.

[*] Ship control. The ship turns extremely slowly and is quite bothersome to travel with. It takes about 5 seconds to turn from straight to left or right. Yes, it is this bad.

[/list]
[h1]The Good[/h1]
Now it seems like everything I listed is bad, but there is [b]so much[/b] good in this game (literally everything else) that while these things do weigh it down, it's still an amazing game to play through. I will list some main points, but I obviously love the game so I'll keep it short.

[list]
[*] The story is amazing. It makes several twists throughout the journey, and leaves you guessing at what will happen next. It's got everything you'd want from a story and more. Not to mention the character development, morals the game discusses, sacrifices the characters make and how their choices impact the world.

[*] Battles are fun. They are challenging (especially on hard), without forcing you to grind the entire way. There's tons of enemies you'll encounter, and really cool boss battles and optional ones too. "Tales of" games have always had great battle systems, and this game is no exception.

[*] Skits, Collectibles, Mini-Games, titles etc. will be found throughout the game as you travel, complete the story and do random things such as complete 256 battles on hard mode. There's so much to do, so many extra little things that you'd never expect (like making Colette talk to all the dogs in the game) that really make this game shine. You're probably used to fetch quests in RPG games, well instead of fetch quests you get tons of extra character development, mini-games and collectibles to find!


[h1]Workarounds[/h1]
[*] Download cheat engine. No you're not using it to cheat. Attach it to ToS.exe while it's running, set "Enable Speedhack" to on, type in manually 1.1x speed, then click apply. What this will do is help fix the movement issues and make battle feel a bit smoother by increasing the game speed. At 1.2 or higher, it will be your choice to battle with it on or off, I do not recommend it for difficult battles.

[*] Install this program from this community page and install your desired gamepad buttons, HD texture packs, fixes, etc. This is something I stumbled across whilst trying to find a way to run the game at 60 FPS. Not the fix I was looking for (there wasn't one) but a fix I was thankful to find. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=618359790

Buen juego, aunque quizás un poco sobrevalorado. No es uno de los mejores JRPG de la historia como he visto en muchos sitios.
El sistema de combate es simplemente genial. Entretenido, con posibilidades. Los enemigos de relleno se disfrutan, y los jefes son desafiantes. La IA de los compañeros es muy buena. Pueden perfectamente resolver un combate ellos solos. De hecho, los enemigos de relleno, ellos hacen tanto trabajo como tú.
La historia, el otro gran pilar de los JRPG, es simplemente correcta. Demasiados giros de guión que se ven a kilómetros, demasiadas situaciones absurdas (te traiciona todo dios, y aún se siguen fiando del primero que pasa?), y un poco confusa.
El diseño de mazmorras es malo, algunas son horrorosas. Esperar a que lleguen plataformas lentas, escoltar aliados con una pesima IA, dar vueltas y backtracking, etc.
En fin, un buen JRPG, con un genial sistema de combate, buenos personajes, historia normalita, y muy largo.

It tries to address complex themes like systemic racism, religion and differences in ideals leading to conflict and war, very poorly. [h1] Un juego excelente y memorable [/h1]

Lo más interesante es su historia. Es un juego que va creciendo y cuando crees que ya entiendes de qué va el juego, te encuentras con algo nuevo. Tiene múltiples dinámicas, en un principio parece que se tratará de un viaje en el que irás visitando sellos y luchando contra guardianes, en otro momento crees que trata sobre la guerra contra los desianos y finalmente te das cuenta de que todo lo anterior son apenas piezas de una trama mayor. 

Te encontrarás escenas cómicas, trágicas y románticas que te harán sentir leyendo un muy buen libro de fantasía. 

En cuanto a jugabilidad es bastante versátil, tienes varios personajes con estilos de juego muy singulares que aparecerán a lo largo de la trama de modo que si crees que ya eres un dios con Lloyd, ve y lucha siendo Regal, Sheena o Presea a ver qué tal te va. 

Simplemente un juego fantástico. Si disfrutaste juegos como Final Fantasy XI, aquí encontrarás un sucesor espiritual bastante bueno.

I would eagerly recommend it to anyone who did not play the original. For those who did play it, if you want to feel the nostalgia, or make someone discover it, definitely too.

Simultaneously a completionist's dream and nightmare.

I never got to play this game as a kid, but I did have [i] Tales of Symphonia: Dawn of the new world [/i] which I poured 200+ hours into. That used to be my go-to game whenever I'd have other kids over for sleepovers, so I jumped at the opportunity to try the original.

[i] Dawn of the New World [/i] really didn't do justice to ToS's world (or Lloyd's himbo energy). I'm honestly just blown away at the sheer size of this game and the number of things to do. Am I annoyed that I can miss a side quest by not talking to some random NPC from three towns ago (which forces me to play the game with four guides open because that's who I am as a person)? Sure, but for some reason, ToS does it in a way that it actually motivates me to do additional playthroughs so I can unlock everything that there is in this vast world.

95516893.review:
This was my first time playing, so I don't have nostalgia clouding my review.

Overall, despite being an old game, it's still a good game. It's not my favorite of the Tales series, but if you're a fan then perhaps it's worth your time. The storyline is great, the characters are good, and the combat is alright.
There are only two problems: 
1) If your controller has vibration on, your game lags/stutters every time it vibrates. I didn't figure this out until the end of the game basically, which was super annoying (but also amazing to see what the combat is really supposed to be like at full speed instead of 1/4 - 1/2 speed). 
2) There is no free run. Sometimes, you fight multiple enemies that come at you from several directions, but you're just a 2D fighter with your target. Avoiding enemy attacks can be extremely difficult, especially in the beginning of the game. There's a bit of a learning curve...

Anyway, if you want to get into the Tales series, don't start here. As an old game it does show it's age in many ways so I can only recommend it to people that have played other Tales games, enjoy the series, and want to investigate some of its roots :)

95095367.review:
[h1]Is The Nostalgia Strong With You? [/h1]
Well it’ll have to be since the only way to catch all these achievements, whoever plays this game will have to beat this game approximately 5 times to do so.  Not only having to play the game that many times, but also have do tons of preparations, placing many restrictions very early on the game to get titles for certain characters which leads to achievements, tons of grinding with not only with levels, but with cooking levels, money, grade (I’ll explain that later), getting almost all items, collectables, monster list, figurine in one playthrough, etc.  In other words, the very first play-through of this game is going to be the busiest, grind heavy, restrictive (the first half of the game), and demanding playthrough.  However, the great new is that after that hump and second and other playthroughs are less demanding and more opened.  As long as the players choose Kratos as their final party member on their first playthrough and gotten all of the titles for that playthrough, he’ll get his last one on the second and then the player will receive the achievement to getting all the titles for him just by starting new game plus.  So, if anyone wants to gain all achievements for this game, they have to play this game like it’s a mission and to finish this section of this insanity is with the five people you must speak with in a certain snowy town to guarantee the completion of titles and collection book and they are: Kratos (pretty easy), Zelos (hardest character), Colette (easiest character), Genis (easy character) and Regal (surprisingly easy if player find all of the outside skits for him (find those prism rings and GameFaQ will help)).
Now I can finally talk about this freaking game and for those who love the Tales series will love this one since it’s the first one to do 3D.  The game suffers for what I call the “Final Fantasy VII Syndrome” which is it’s “everyone’s first (final fantasy/Tales) and these people get extremely emotionally attached to these two games.  Spoiler alert: those are my first introductions to those series – Final Fantasy 1 was my first RPG and Tales of Destiny was my first tales game whereas this game was my fourth one.  Both VII and Symphonia got a lot of similarities, strengths and weakness that sett hem apart, but overall good games; however, not my top 3.  What makes Symphonia stand out so much to many Tales Fans are the characters, the story, the interactions between the good and bad guys, but most importantly, the game is easily accessible, anyone can literally pick it up and play it without any hassle - with the character class restrictions, the players can strategizes which character can be effective in battle vs slapping on the right materia to characters which will take a while if people aren’t familiar with the mechanics.  Unlike Final Fantasy VII’s main antagonist Sephiroth, I prefer Yggdrasill because I find him more terrifying due everything he has done in this game and the vast majority of stuff he did was all his idea unlike Sephiroth who had a ready-made plan already handed to him and all he needed to do is sit on his ass, occasionally trolls the main character and has his “mother” do all the fighting for him and most notably, he waited 7 years to finally use his “mother’s” body like a gundam (for more context, then play Final Fantasy VII and the explanation for that will take about 30+ hours to get to that point), but hey at least he looks walking through fire I guess.  I would say the game’s greatest strength is that it doesn’t drag on and on like VII does sometimes whereas in Symphonia, I don’t feel that at all, but unlike FFVII, Symphonia does have some dick moves where if the players do fight a certain optional boss, talk to a certain person at a limited time bracket, then they’ll never have access to some of the best equipment in the game.
Remember where I briefly mentioned Grade early on, this is where Symphonia has over FFVIII in terms of replay-ability.  Grade serves two purposes: its use to buy material use for customizations aa well as EX Gems that will gain each character unique skills, but importantly, its use to buy bonuses for new game+ which is required to get everything in this game as well as making the game easier for players on harder difficulty.  They’re obtained through battles along with money, EXP and drop items – think of Grade like a score for combat performance where in order to get the highest, the fights need to finish quickly, no damage, doing tons of combos, using technical skills and the like.  Those how played old school Tales games knows this, but at least in this game we can actually use these points as currency.  If anyone wants the best of the best stuff that new game+ plus got to offer, then prepare to grind for hours; however, there is a bonus that can be bought with grade to double the amount of it on can obtain, but it also doubles the loss if the battle performance is subpar, so high risk, high award scenario.  Unlike FFVII and other games Tales games, by beating the game, the sound test is unlocked which is awesome since the music in the game is very good, but there are older Tales games like Tales of Destiny that have that feature already available the moment the title screen appears.  Nevertheless, anyone can make the game easier or harder through the Grade store, but only if the game is beaten.
Before I recommend this game, the negative comments on this game in the steam community are legit since I have encountered some of these issues they addressed, but luckily not all of them.  For example, when I got over 135 hit combo in the game, for some reason it felt like I gave the game a heart attack because it looked as if it was going to crash when it froze for a little bit and all of the sudden it got better.  The worst crime in this game is the movements of the NPC where they can walk right up on me and get me stuck into a corner of a building that wasn’t properly smoothed out in coding and I’m imprison in that corner for all eternity until I reset he game or load up the file and hope that I saved before the incident.  That happen to me at least 3 times and nope, the NPC can’t be shoved away.  Another annoying thing to bring up is when you uninstall and reinstall this game; it automatically set it to full screen regardless of the setting where I have to switch it back and forth to get back to windows mode and the FPS I believe is locked to 30 which is a no no for PC gamers because they hate it when FPS is locked.  That being said, the game is the PS2/PS3 version which contains more content, more techniques for each characters, titles and more optional boss fights.  The gameplay is going to be a little rough for those who play the more current Tales game, but that hump with dissipate very quickly by playing the game more.  Get this game on sale, can be played with friends and family and the opportunity to play the very game that paves the way for more 3D Tales game for years to come.  As for this game’s sequels, one of the happens to be the very first Tales game which is Tales of Phantasia, a great game, and the other one is a direct sequel called Tales of Symphonia: Dawn of the New World which is a game that should never existed and be completely skipped for Phantasia – trust me, I’m doing everyone here a favor by stating that fact since I really don’t understand the point of that game other than milking money out of people because I saw the words “Bandai Namco” which gave me the prove that it’s was just for the money.  It’s on sale now, so get cheap before time runs out.

94797037.review:
This is the first Tales game I've beat - having only played half of Berseria around a year and a half ago, I thought it's now a good time to bust out Symphonia.

If you want a nice comfy story to experience, complete with pretty visuals (even though they've not aged that well, but i don't need to tell you that graphics are not important), nice and sweet music and very lovable characters, you can't go wrong with this game.

This is probably a good Tales game to start with too, considering that it's not too outdated and has everything in it to make it a "Tales of" game through and through. There's plenty more where that came from as well.

There are many different ways to play it to make your playthrough your own. Paths split and can be done in what order you want, tons of secrets to discover and extra non-essential things to see and do. The story is nothing groundbreaking, but for a comfy adventure that makes sense and doesn't try too much - it's great and gripping enough while being easy to follow. It has romance, it has sad moments, it has funny moments and it has some really brutal ones. But what makes this story stand out are the characters. All of them are unique, all of them have their motivations and interactions between them are fantastic, if the presentation might be a bit lacking sometimes. The characters SELL this game.

Combat is really simple too, and although you can customize it and play around a lot to find what you're comfortable with, you can also change around to whatever character you want to control whenever you get bored of one. Lloyd is still my favorite to play, and Zelos is probably the most interesting and funny character to watch.

The voice acting is not perfect, the voice quality included, but it does its' job. The music is pretty good though, and sets the mood of any scene well. It has a tendency to get abruptly cut because of changes of the emotion of a cutscene, but considering this game is quite old, that shouldn't be an issue.

Anyway, without getting into too much - it's recommended, pick it up during a sale, and if you want a nice comfy story to play around on summer evenings - can't go wrong with Tales of Symphonia.

94704618.review: I just beat this game and let me tell you, it's pretty good. This is my third Tales of game (Berseria was first, Zestiria was second) and I was not disappointed in this one. For a 2004 game, it actually holds up. This game has a pretty enjoyable cast of characters. Lloyd, Colette, Genis, Kratos, Raine, Sheena, Presea, Zelos, and Regal are all enjoyable characters. The dungeons in this game are incredible. As a fan of The Legend of Zelda, I think these dungeons are some of the best I've played in a video game, and definitely better than those in Berseria and Zestiria. Those two games have good dungeons, but compared to Symphonia, they just aren't as good. If I were to rank the 3 Tales of games I've played so far, it would probably be like this: 3rd place is Symphonia, 2nd place is Zestiria, and 1st place is Berseria. If you've never played a Tales of game, this one is a good one to start on. I think this game is really good, and you should too.

94569968.review:
[b]I completed this game on Gamecube, and later purchased it on steam just to show my appreciation to the devs, since I bought my GC copy second hand, this is why I have 0.1 hours played on steam[/b]

This is my first tales game, and I intend to play other games in the series now because I really liked what I played here overall.  It's not perfect though, it's really starting to show its age, and some aspects I just don't think were designed well to begin with.  Let me start with the positives first since there's far more good than bad here.

The writing, and the characters.  Oh my GOD this is an incredible cast. With the sole exception of Zelos, the cast is filled with lovable, memorable characters that will stick with you LONG after you finish the game. The main character Lloyd, Genis, Regal, and Kratos are my personal favorites. This game will MAKE you remember them, because not only do they each have their own character arcs, and play roles in the main story, but Symphonia does something that I don't think I've ever seen in a game before, skits.  From what I understand, this is a system that most Tales games have.  But basically, if you aren't aware, at random points in the game, whether you're on the overworld, in a dungeon, a town, or wherever else, you'll get a prompt for an optional skit.  Skits are essentially optional pieces of dialogue centered around the main cast, and there's hundreds of them. They'll comment on recent story beats/discoveries.  They'll comment on the town they're in, or recent characters they've met.  Or they could just be casual conversations between some of the characters, or them just having some fun.  This is an incredible way to develop these characters, and add extra context or information to the story in a way that doesn't seem overwhelming or annoying, because they're entirely OPTIONAL!  You can completely ignore them if you want to, and that's really cool.

Gameplay is really great.  It's an action RPG taking place in a 3D space, but you're fighting on a 2D plain, like a fighting game.  You can move left, right, and jump.  You also have basic attacks on the ground and the air, as well as skills that can be combo'd.  Most things happen in real time, though you can pause the action at any time to use an item or issue a command to your teammates.  Over time, as you fight, you'll learn more skills, not by leveling up and spending skill points, but by using the skills you already have, and changing your affinity, you'll gain new abilities mid-battle that are either brand new, combinations of previous skills, or previous skills that morphed in some way. For example, one of the earliest skills you get is Demon Fang.  It's a long range wave of energy essencially.  If you're T-Type, it'll morph into Double Demon Fang, shooting two waves instead of one.  If you're S-Type, it'll turn into Fierce Demon Fang, which removes the range, but makes it a multi-hit close range hit.  The way your abilities morph and can be combo'd with each other keeps things constantly fresh throughout the whole game.  You have a new ability to try out all the time, and its really fun to see how it performs, and how it fits into your combos.  
Oh yeah, and there's up to 8 characters in your party, and you can play as all of them and they all have this.  Extremely robust battle system here. 
Music is incredible.  Very memorable soundtrack.  Not sure what else I can say on that, it's just really good.

Voice acting is pretty good for the most part, though it's a bit disappointing that only important cutscenes are voiced.  I hear future games have full voice acting, even for skits.  It's a shame that such an incredible cast didn't get more time in the spotlight.

Story is pretty good, lots of twists and turns, and very impactful events.  The game gets pretty dark at times.  Unfortunately, this is where a few of my gripes with the game start.

As I said, the story is good, and there's some seriously messed up things that happen in this story.  But it feels like the characters aren't allowed to take things seriously for too long.  I won't spoil anything, so I'll use a vague example to illustrate my point.  Imagine a very important character dies.  The cast is devastated. As you leave the place where it happened, the music is gone, the characters are silent, everyone is mourning the loss of their friend. 5 minutes later you get a prompt for a skit.  Now, this could be the one where they comment on their fallen comrade and talk about what they meant to them, or it could be a silly skit with the characters making jokes and laughing.
See the problem here?  That happens a lot if you always do the skits.

The overworld is awful.  It's huge and you move at a snails pace. You don't get a means of fast travel until around 30 hours in. The story will have you make constant trips back and forth across the region and through places you've already been just to get to the next story segment.  The game is very non-linear at times, which for the most part is alright, but there's a few times in the story where it doesn't tell you where to go next.  Usually, you have the synopsis menu to tell you exactly what happened up until this point and usually tells you where to go next, but at random points it's like *BOOM* check literally every town/area you've been to!  One of them has a new scene, but we won't tell you what one!  Have fun!
I wasted a good few hours early on trying to figure out where to go in this game.  The problem is almost completely resolved after you get the flying vehicles since you can travel the regions in seconds, but early on especially, I'd recommend keeping a guide near you so you always know where to go next.  

The dungeon design isn't great.  I see people say that they are good but I don't know what they're smoking.  The ones that have you solve a genuine puzzle are pretty good, the one where you had to figure out the order to get the windmils spinning was one of the best.  Had me actually write notes, was a really cool time to play through that blind.  The rest of them? It's all block puzzles, pushing switches, or breaking stuff.  And oh my GOD there are so many multi-room puzzles that require you to go on one side of the dungeon for one step, go on the other side for another step, and back and forth multiple times.  Tedium is the perfect way to describe these dungeons. The one where you're in a forest and you have to do things in a VERY SPECIFIC ORDER across the entire multi-screen area to get a piece a fruit??  That mini dungeon is the absolute worst.  If you mess up even once across the dozen or more steps, it's back to square one and you have to do it all over again.  I hate crap like that, and symphonia's dungeons are FILLED with things that make you start over. Around 30 hours into the game I just said screw it and kept an eye on a guide.  Any time I found myself in a new dungeon, I just followed it.  They are so exhausting to play through and there's so many of them, that I just wanted it to end.  You will NOT get engaging dungeon design from this game.  Have a guide up and play with it to save yourself the time and the headaches.

Overall, would I recommend this game?  Yeah I say I would.  As I said, this was my first tales game, and even though it was rough around the edges, it got me interested enough to give the later games a go though.  I may have wrote an entire novel of my thoughts of the negative aspects of the game, but don't get me wrong, I liked this game more than I disliked it.  I think for the most part it still holds up today.  I don't even really like JRPGs that much so the fact I could play this all the way through without dropping speaks to its quality, I feel.  Give it a shot if you're in the mood for a good action rpg.  Just.. don't go into it expecting a "perfect" game, because it certainly is not.

94364260.review:
After playing through this thing, the story of it, for once, and having some backgroundinfo, I have to say, I really like it. It might not be the kind of masterpiece I thought it would be after what I heard from my friend who told me to play it, but it's fun to play and really entertaining. And the story is really good, even if it goes the path of the typical JRPG. There might be some things that are annoying at times, like slowly moving platforms or a menu that isn't exactly beginnerfriendly, but that are things you can close an eye on.

But the question is, if I would recommend this game and that is a no. Well, it is a yes, but not for this version. If you have the chance, play another version of the game instead of this.
This is not the worst port of a game that exists and it's not unplayable either, but it's poorly made at some points. There are annoying bugs and one of them almost made me quit in the middle of the game. You can get stuck between NPCs and if you aren't lucky to get out somehow, you'll have to reload from your last savepoint, no matter how long you have played since then. There is also a point where you might softlock yourself if you can't equip a certain quality of life ability anymore. Also, for those who want to enjoy the story, at some times text just gets to places where it shouldn't be and takes away the text that should be there (and you might never know what text should've been there).
The worst thing though is about an item you'll need for many things that suddenly has so much delay that it becomes almost unuseable and so makes a lot of stuff way harder than it is intended to be. So you have the choice of learn to control the delay or only use it if it's absolutely required.

So, to conclude: Really nice game, so I'm sad for the negative review, but this port sadly didn't really leave me a choice there. If you can live with the bugs though... buy it during sale at least ;)

94245326.review:
The port could be better optimized.  That aside, let's talk Tales.
    There are A LOT of games in this series.  Out of all of the games, this one is MY favorite.  In the Tales series, I think it's all about which game resonates with you more.  This one happens to be the one for me.
    The story is typical anime and fantasy fare, but it's done well with plenty of plot twists and character development (for a 50-70 hour game).  It's told with a combination of text, voice, anime cgi, and engine- rendered cut scenes.  It looks great for it's time.
    The battle system is hack and slash with RPG elements infused.  You'll run into monsters and start combat.  At that point, you push the A to attack and then the directional buttons plus B to carry out special movies linked to specific buttons which you assign.   Special moves can chain if you have the right skills. A lv1 skill links to lv 2 which can link to lv 3.  You also have a limit-type gauge which when filled will allow you to carry out party combos.  If you use the right skills in the right order, you can execute powerful party attacks.  It's fun to figure them all out.
    Compared to the newer Tales, the combat is fairly primitive and slow, but it's still fun to play with.  There are titles to learn which increase your leveling stats and EX gems (three slots per character) which can allow a little bit more customization.  The party controls themselves and you can set tactics for them; however, the options are limited compared to newer games in the series.
    The dungeon design in this game is great.  They are just the right length and I love the puzzle elements.  I think the dungeon design is better than Vesperia, Xellia, Zesteria, Abyss, and Beseria.  Graces compares to it very well, but IMO, it's the only other one with such well designed dungeons.
    Though old, it's a good entry in the series.  If you like JRPGs, this one is worthy of your time.  It packs 50-70 hours of gameplay, and it has solid story, systems and pacing.

93857813.review:
Surely anyone who have heard of the "Tales of" series would know they're in for a fantastic ride. So to shakes things up, lets start with the bad. 

GRAPHICS, STORY and BLOCKS. To go into detail, there are moments when the facial shading just doesn't match the surrounding lighting. Story is pretty solid, but it falls for the same trap in most JRPGs and anime. It wasn't so bad at the start, but near the end, the whole world would be falling apart but EVERYONE in the game will have time to say their piece of mind. Lastly, block puzzles. They're interesting when they decide to work. But when they don't, MY GOD I WANT TO .... 

But if you can ignore these problems, the game works fine. Combat was pure bliss. You can be hands on or just auto-pilot like I did. Music worked well with the story, and just generally good. It's no square enix level epic but the BGM does have it's moments. That takes us to the next point; by far the strongest reason that kept me hooked. Very strong character development occurs throughout the game. With a cast of lovable (and hate-able) characters, there's sure one for everyone to latch onto. Sadly not all villains get their own backstory or revelations, but somehow, i didn't mind. This leads me to the second strongest point for Symphonia and any RPG tbh, character influence. How each character and the story develop along with each other and the rest of the world. A good example is the city of Luin. Without spoiling too much, your characters will remark on how they (implying you as the player) helped the town through the good and bad times. 

On a last note, probably a more neutral point, are the mini games. They vary in terms of fun, with some just weird random. It's not that they seem lazy, but I think they're going for the Yakuza games style of kooky. 

In summary, I personally enjoyed almost every minute of playing this game. But wholeheartedly would recommend.

93785036.review:
After putting in about 20 hours, this game has not aged well. If you do not have nostalgia for it, I don't think there's any reason to go back to this one.

Story:
People talk about the story and characters in this game, but after about 20 hours I just could not make myself care about either. The story feels incredibly generic. The world is bland and uninteresting. The villains are boring and not particularly threatening. You're escorting "the chosen one" on her quest to unlock various magical seals and regenerate the world. She accepts her role as sacrificial savior of humanity with a smile.  There are some bad people (or elves?) who enslave humans for.... reasons. The story feels like FFX if you excised everything from FFX that gave it any character or sense of place. Maybe this is one of those games that "only gets good after 40 hours" but who has the time for that? If a game can't get you to feel the slightest invested in the first 20 hours, it is not worth your time.

Characters:
It's hard not to compare this game to FFX. Even though FFX' characters were also mostly tropey archetypes and kinda annoying, Symphonia's characters all somehow manage to feel like even worse knockoffs. The main character, Lloyd's, defining trait is that he's dumb. Colette is the Yuna analogue. Her character is "good." That does not mean she is a good character. Rather her entire personality can be summed up in one word. "Good." (and maybe "innocent/naive"?). There's an Auron analogue who's the story's stoic warrior type but... more boring. Other characters... exist. Again, maybe I need to put in another 15-20 hours before any of these characters start to even hint at any sort of an arc, but there are other games to be played.

Mechanics:
I don't particularly care for the combat system in this game. Battles are very repetitive, and even the early boss battles feel pretty dull. You control one character and have some limited ability to set the three other characters' strategy. The control of your character is a bit wonky and the battles just don't feel satisfying or fun. You just spam the same basic attacks, while your allies may or may not help you, until the enemy dies.

The game does an absolutely TERRIBLE job of making you feel any sense of progression. It's never clear what your character gains from a level up. You do not find interesting equipment or upgrades in the world. There's no joy in exploring the world. There's an entirely pointless equipment upgrade "system" that serves no apparent purpose other than forcing you to interact with two NPCs in each town instead of one. As far as I can tell, the ONLY control you have over your characters' growth is what title you choose to give them, with different titles being unlocked by completing certain tasks.
Fighting generic enemies after 20 hours feels the same as the first generic encounters. Fighting bosses feels the same as fighting generic enemies except the battle lasts longer.

Style:
This game has not aged well. The art style is bad and really contributes in a negative way to everything said above. It's hard to take the characters seriously when they look so ...childish. This is especially true of villains who all just look like goofy bobble-head dolls. 
It's hard to take the story seriously when every dramatic moment is totally undercut by the lack of art direction. The game renders cutscenes in engine, but the game engine is totally inadequate for recreating any scene meant to have either action or emotion. 
Although the game sort of flirts with a cartoon style, it fails to hit the timeless look that games like Windwaker acheived. Instead, Symphonia's visuals are just the worst of early 2000s 3d. Dull blocky environments. Dull blocky characters.

93054833.review:
When it comes to JRPGs, my favourite franchises are [i]Final Fantasy[/i] and [i]Persona[/i], no question about it (with [i]Chrono Trigger[/i] being the very best standalone title in my opinion). With that said, I felt like it was time to broaden my horizons a little bit, and get a taste of a series I’ve never had the chance and/or time to play before. That’s how I eventually picked [i]Tales of Symphonia[/i], my very first [i]Tales[/i] game.

I’m happy to say that I wasn’t disappointed, not at all. The story translates very well to modern times, although it’s quite complex, so paying attention to every little detail is a must if you want to understand everything. I’m not afraid to admit that I still have some questions regarding a few plot twists… Well, all the more reason to play it through again, I guess!

As for the other aspects of the game, the graphics are nice (considering how old this title is, of course), the characters are really fun, the dungeons are cleverly designed (although there are a few frustrating puzzles), and the battle system is quite unique, yet not too difficult to master. The replay value is also extremely high thanks to all the various side-quests, collectibles, difficulty settings and endings.

Highly recommended to all JRPG fans – as for me, this was definitely not the last [i]Tales[/i] game I’ve played, so to be continued!
