92855576.review:
Okay, there's a lot to say about this one but I'll try my best to make my thoughts coherent about this game.
There was a lot that I liked, but also a lot that ground my gears.
After one full playthrough, here's a quick summation of my thoughts:

Pros:
-Great music by Motoi Sakuraba and the rest of the team
-Beautiful art design, colourful scenery that has a certain purity to it that modern games lack
-The story's deeper than it initially looked to be (though it has some flaws)
-Most characters, even minor ones, each have their moment to shine and some compelling motivations
-Combat can be very pleasing and arcade-y when you really get into mastering it and taking advantage of all your accumulated skills
-You get to humiliate angels at the top of the world

Cons:
-The world map has the WORST auto-tilting camera I've ever seen, sometimes making it so you can't even see your character and sometimes ONLY being able to see your character.
You can look forward, sure, but never do you have any control over the vertical angle.
-The initial ten/fifteen hours are a complete slog to get into and it took way too long to start getting good
-The game as released has a 30 FPS lock and a very low-resolution, blurry look to it with low-resolution textures everywhere. TSFix improves things but if low frame rates bother you then this may be very unappealing.
Perhaps that's a limitation of being an old GameCube game.
-Drawn out gimmick dungeons help diversify your treks, but get tiresome after a while
-Romance options have no tangible effect on the ending
-In terms of storytelling it's great to have an anti-discrimination theme, but the writers seemed to lack a deeper understanding of how discrimination works and how it affects people in a society. This makes it lack the amount of depth that could've really helped bring more weight to the overall plot being told.
-Character designs are cool, but everyone in-game suffers a bit from Bobblehead syndrome
-Synopsis pointers to the next goal aren't always quite intuitive
-In the initial stretch on a first playthrough, it's entirely possible to spend hours not knowing where you're supposed to go
-Some of the character writing can be a bit naff, especially with characters like Regal.
-In combat sometimes your movement input can seem a bit too heavy and delayed, such as pressing the block button but it not reacting soon enough. Combining that with getting stunlocked can lead to awkward situations.

Overall I'd say the initial hours were the longest for me, to the point it took me years to actually start getting somewhere.
And I think that's a shame, because it can be a real turnoff that causes most people to quit and move on to other games, as even I did.
In the end, though, as I progressed further into the story and got to know the characters, it really opened up more.

This game could have been much, much stronger than its hyped reputation would suggest.
It's not...BAD, but a lot could've been done to improve the pace of the initial sections of the game and make everything flow together more nicely as a whole experience.

This just makes me wonder why games like Tales of Eternia or Tales of Phantasia never made their way to Steam as remasters instead, because this is just not up to that level of engagement.

92500613.review:
I didn't think much of this game in my first session. Sometimes first impressions are wrong. This is not one of those times. While the story seems like it could be okay in that generic, but tried-and-true sort of way, that in no way makes up for the game just not being any fun to play.

Initial plot setup is lifted straight out of the Mana series. Which could be sort of okay, plot points get recycled all the time. Just this was so much of a copy-paste job I actually had to double check I'd opened the right game.

Combat sucks, and sucks hard. Your character moves and attacks on a 2D plane. The enemies move and attack on a 3D plane. This is dumb as hell and makes it really easy to get hit-stun combo'd for large portions of your HP.  Doesn't help that your attacks are slow and clunky, really compounds the previous issue to make the combat just completely unenjoyable. I've discovered you can turn combat to full auto, which is kinda nice in that you avoid interacting with the clunky combat. But fights are on the long side for an RPG, so enabling this just means you aren't even playing half the game. Which is kind of silly and boring if you ask me.

That clunkiness just kind of extends to everything else in the game. Characters seem like clunky one-note caricatures, though admittedly I didn't see much of them in 3 hours. Combat, as mentioned, is horribly clunky. Walking around feels clunky. Exploring dungeons and solving puzzles is nearly as clunky as the combat. Everything just feels bad to play.

Graphically the game isn't much to look at. I understand this is an old game, but it can't have been very impressive when it came out either. The modelling quality is what you'd find on an early PS2 game, but animated like a PS1 game. I generally don't put much emphasis on visuals, but this comes from that dark time when 3D sucked but nobody made 2D games because they were "outdated" even though they looked better.

91398049.review:
[h1] Definitely recommend! [/h1]

I'll start off by saying, I have owned multiple copies of this game on Game Cube, once on the PS3, and now on Steam. It's been one of my all time favorites since I first played it on Game Cube. I was very used to playing with a controller, but switching over to the PC wasn't bad at all! Some of the controls are a bit wonky, but that's just because of muscle memory and having to adjust to using a mouse and keyboard. 

If you enjoy heavily story based games, you will definitely want to try this one out. The story is very well done, and all of the characters have their own unique personalities and quirks. The graphics are pretty great for the year this originally came out, and the sound is all great too. 

The game also allows you to customize your menu settings. You can change the color and the opacity of menu boxes, speech boxes, and enemy speech boxes. This I feel comes in handy if you want to color code things, or have a nice clean and sleek look to your game. You can adjust the speed at which the written text on their speech boxes appear as well.

It's a long game (originally two discs), but is easily replayable over and over again. There is an alternative ending, which is based on a specific choice you get to make later in the game. If you're looking to speed-run the game and avoid most side-missions, you're looking at around 15-22 hours. If you want to take your time with it, you can easily sink 72+ hours into the game. 

All in all, I have replayed this game from start to finish dozens, if not hundreds of times, and have yet to be bored of it!

TL;DR

If you enjoy long, story-based games with a fantasy aspect, you'll definite enjoy this one!

90865106.review:
I love this game. I used to play it a TON on the GameCube. That said, I don't want to make it seem that I think this game is perfect. It isn't. While the plot starts off right away, it is slow going in the beginning as you learn the mechanics and what-have-you. Although it doesn't feel like it is dragging, the plot is very cliche and was at the time of it's release. 

In my opinion, some of the characters aren't all that great either and and as you go through the plot, some things just don't make sense in the large scheme of things. There's a LOT of pushing to justify some the plot and characters. I don't want to make it seem like I hate the characters. The ones in your group are great and they have great story lines. It's just a lot of the "extended" relationships that have a lot of pushing and I find I don't care too much for the characters that are there for a single plot point. They're very forgettable. Plus some of the things done to make some of the characters seem mysterious just make them look incompetent.

I do want to mention that I have a great time playing the fights in this game. There is a lot of button mashing, but it is still fun. Also I like the dungeons in this game too. There are several puzzles to solve, which is something that is really lacking in the newer Tales games. 

There's also a bunch of fun stuff to do on the side. So the game does not have a linear feel to it. There is a lot of exploring to do and items/places to unlock. You can get some good optional gear this way as you take part in some of the side quests. 

Replay value for this game is extremely high. While you do get the same ending every time, your relationship value with your party members can slightly change the path to that ending. It can affect who remains on your party and which part of their story you will uncover. This gives the opportunity for new titles and total completion. You will not have 100% completion your first play though.

All said, I think it is a great game to pass the time with.

My only problems with it is, since its an older game it doesn't like to run on most modern hardware. And the controls can feel kinda clunky by modern standards. Which is why we need a Remasterd/Remake of this game FAST.

Anyway my final score would be a solid 9/10      perfect game for newcomers to RPG's or veterans.

90497661.review: I have played this game ever since I was a dumb kid on the gamecube, and I have never been happier than when playing this game. The world(s) are expansive, rich, full of lore and things to do, and have challenging puzzles that are sure to stump you your first time through the game. The way the character's interactions feel very genuine and well thought out, and each of them feels unique and not stereotypical (despite initial impressions). The gameplay is simple to learn but fun to experiment with, seeing just how high your combos can get. The variety in ways the game is designed to allow you to enjoy it and the small rewards it gives you for doing daunting tasks feel incredible. I am currently going down the Hard Path for the first time and am finding myself falling in love with the game all over again. Whether it be the wonderful environments to explore, varied designs, wonderful mix between sci-fi and high fantasy, interesting characters, beautiful soundtrack, or just overall replay ability of this game with the New Game+ system this game is great. That's not to say that the game is without it's flaws. I personally believe that an auto-save feature after defeating each boss would be a welcome addition to include in the newer versions of Symphonia, I understand that the original game was designed to be fair with save point distribution, however I feel that Modern RPGs have spoiled me somewhat and it is what I have come to expect. It's like Mama always said "save often and often you will be saved". My favorite character is a certain blue haired gentleman whom I just want to hug.

90061131.review:
This feels like an overrated Tales of game or it probably did not age well.  In my opinion, if you like your RPGs to be well voice-acted and/or well written then this is not the game for you. If you like good gameplay, interesting lore with some dark social philosophy involved and likeable characters MORE than good writing and good voice-acting then feel free to ignore this review.

Pros: 
- nice easy-to-get-into combat system that gives you enough depth pretty early (unlike Vesperia where combat feels satisfying after quite a while)
- cute graphics

Cons:
- mostly mediocre voice-acting
- horrid writing in dialogues (this kind of childish writing does not age well compared to other RPGs during that generation - like KOTOR/FF X/Neverwinter Nights/Morrowind), even though the story has interesting concepts (the same issue can be found in FF VII), it's like the writers just learned how to write a dialogue scene, they force concepts in very short phrases so that you get the most information with as little reading as possible and it looks soooo bad ("it must be the exsphere from the Angelus Project that we've been searching for")  BUT it might be because of the limitations of that specific hardware (Gamecube). Either way, it's bad and it keeps me completely detached from the story.
- unvoiced skits
- unskippable cutscenes (which is quite bad since watching that horrible dialogue play again after failing a boss is atrocious)
- locked 30 FPS
- clunky controls on large map

After finishing Vesperia (4 times and my personal favourite), Zestiria and Berseria and after playing more than half of Graces f and Xillia, I think that this one is praised because of nostalgia. The story concept is very similar to FF X in the first part of the game. The game might evolve as I understand it's quite long and despite some shortcomings (which I can tolerate easily) I could have liked the game (it is enjoyable to play) if not for that terrible, terrible dialogue writing.

It's not unplayable, it's not a terrible game, it's just badly written.

89654026.review:
The PC port of this game is pretty buggy and really requires a fan patch, but the fan patch does fix up everything that it's no big deal really. This version of the game includes all the new content that was put in when it was released to other consoles, too.

IT'S OLD AS DIRT, but is still a pretty fun time. The pacing to the story is surprisingly very fast and steady and so much happens in this video game that you never really feel stuck in one spot for too long. There's enough to like that you can forgive it's archaic aspects.

The only issues I had were:
1) You would need a guide to figure out where and when the side content happens. Most of it is incredibly easy to miss and the game has almost constant points of no return.
2) You are locked running only back and forth in the combat and can't roam around the arena in all directions like the later games. It leads to an occasional annoying battles where a party member is blocking you from the enemy or you get cornered.

Don't play the direct sequel to this game it's just bad.

89273659.review:
The great:
- Consequences: Many actions brought consequences, you might have been on your own, roaming around, which brings consequences, even the "right thing to do" brought consequences. 
- No pussy way out: All the main cast tainted their hands with blood one way or another, they killed because there was no other choice. They all atone for their sins and they have a big burden upon them
-Skits and characters interactions: Very fresh, it never felt too centred on the MC, some fun interactions, some sad, some cheerful.
- The music: Pretty good, Motoi Sakuraba is very talented

The good:
- Plot twists, there's too many of them, I didn't put it on the great because there were too many, at least it never felt too tedious as every single aspect of the plot was balanced well and never overstayed it's welcome
- Characters: Likable bunch, there are some questionable moments at endgame that prevents them from being great, but they're good nonetheless. Lloyd is a good main character who learns a lot through actions and consequences, never feels too oblivious and idealistic.
- In-game cutscenes: They serve it purpose, some are fun, some are epic, some are pretty sad too. 
- Combat: While not perfect, it's pretty fun to play and there are some cool flashy skills, summons and Compound Skills, playing "Exphere" tetris was nice to balance out characters, although it's not as elaborate as other games

The bad:

- Dungeons: While the layout was pretty nice and overall the dungeons never felt too long or tedious, their puzzles were a bit of a pain because of the controls, they're so clunky is easy to fuck up a puzzle, where you have to start all over again, and some mechanics are way too slow

The ugly:

Janky controls (while roaming, not combat).

Overall a pretty good game that is pretty balanced.

87802400.review:
[i]Tales of Symphonia[/i] is one of my favourite JRPGs of all time. Over the years I have beaten the original GameCube title at least 10 times. It's an endearing, and enduring classic.

Even when playing the game when it was new, I did roll my eyes a lot at the dialogue and story, with all its cliches and melodrama. Whilst a certain overly-dramatic script is a feature of many JRPGs, so that perhaps to others [i]Symphonia[/i] doesn't seem particularly noteworthy in that regard, I was still a relative novice to the genre in 2005, and coming off the more down-to-earth style of [i]Skies of Arcadia Legends[/i], I couldn't help but be frustrated by a lot of the dialogue and characters. On the other hand, not liking certain characters doesn't mean they're badly written, and in fact they're all well-rounded, it's just that the somewhat angsty and juvenile tone can be a bit irritating. Its heart is in the right place, however.

That aside, none of this really stops the game from being consistently fun. I think the biggest factor in my constantly coming back to it is the real-time battle system, which makes fighting even basic enemies an engaging experience rather than the chore it tends to be in turn-based games. The care shown by the development team for this system is perhaps best shown by the fact that every enemy in the game has a host of unique animations, including for when they're stunned: zombies clutch at their heads, for example, while sewer rats perform cute pirouettes. There are hundreds of moves, or techs, to learn, and every party member is able to be player controlled, though the protagonist Lloyd is by far the easiest to handle. I always look forward especially to the boss fights, particularly those against the more humanoid foes, like the Desian Grand Cardinals.

The Steam version of this game is based off the Playstation 3 version, which adds a lot from the original GameCube that I grew up with. I appreciated the extra costumes, the faster pace of skits, and of course the chance of playing the game in widescreen, which allowed me to notice details I had never picked up on before. I did miss the original artwork for items and weapons and such, and they have added a largely unnecessary bit of padding to the plot, but on the whole I think the changes and updates were positive. 

This is a huge game and it's impossible to cover even a small part of all its depth and complexity. Suffice to say it's one of the best JRPGs of the last twenty years and certainly value for money for what you get. To see everything in the game would technically take 8 playthroughs (getting all achievements requires 5)! I love the music and playing it again always brings back fond memories. Highly recommended.

Although a lot of the mechanics and character lines have not aged well, this title in the Tales of Series brings an outstanding level of world building that isn't seen in most games nowadays. Much like old Final Fantasys, this game established a goal and brings you to a conclusion before literally flipping the world upside down and experiencing a completely new world... and this this AFTER you probably have already invested hours into this game. 

The lore and story are what make this game GREAT. Please do not judge the simplicity of a boy going on an adventure. Like most rpgs, there is more than meets the eye.

86584751.review:
[No Spoilers] 
This was one of the first JRPGs I ever played (the first being SMRPG) and I'm so glad I got it when I was younger. This is to this day, in my opinion, the BEST of the "Tales of" games and I can tell you why I think that is.
Story: So Tales of has always had some influence from Norse mythology but this game has THE Norse mythology story. This is like an anime video game love letter to it. The creator of Symphonia brought together all he had researched and put it into this game with his own twist. So of course the story is GREAT. His own ideas elevate the game to the next level. The story is unforgettable. The game goes on way longer than you'd initially think and this is one of the longer games in the series. The first time took me 44 hours and there is more content past that I did later playthroughs.
Gameplay: A lot of the other Tales of games have the same sort of formula for gameplay but this one is a step above them I think. The first time I played through this game I skimmed through a lot of the mechanics without knowing that they went deeper. I died A LOT on my first playthrough but I could still manage to barely get through bosses using all my life bottles and gels and it was a lot of fun. Then I played through it again when I was older and realized just how deep the mechanics went, this time I destroyed bosses and optimized my ex-skills and it was fun in a whole new way. This way of letting people figure the game out at their own pace and learn to play it better the next time is something the other Tales of games don't do as much, their mechanics are easy to grasp and built into how you progress way more so than in this one. The fights in this game are also a lot of fun with the ability to use every character who joins your party and chain together creative combos like you would in a fighting game or hack n slash.

Replaying this game is a joy and playing with another person is even more fun. (Should really get the GC version for the best experience. If this was 60 FPS it would be better but 30 FPS is still good.)

I love this game. I'd give it a 10/10.

85624843.review:
Keep in mind that this is a game originally from 2003. Given that, we can find some flaws but for me they're forgivable. In this port, though, some tweaks could have been made. 

[h1]PROS[/h1] 
- Nice story
- Awesome characters, you get connected with them and their backstories + relationships all the time
- Many characters to play (the game lets you control any of them, in the field and during battles)
- Bonus costumes!
- Various side quests
- Beautiful visuals and scenarios for 2003 standards
- Cool soundtrack

[h1]CONS[/h1] 
- The lack of maps during dungeons and cities
- The lack of map rotation option
- Clunky controls during battles (it's like the battles are limited only to the 2D perspective and doesn't feel fluid, animations are also slow)
- The world map navigation (it could include location names and quest markers)
- The game length is exaggeratedly long. I say this because I found myself various times feeling like the story was being dragged, and there is so much backtracking
- If you find yourself during a hard time progressing in the game, you'll have to do a lot of grinding

I think this is a game that aged well except for the flaws that I mentioned.

85103945.review:
I deeply like this game i haven't played it for 10 years but there is a lot missing from this. Is there a patch ? still a good buy though
-Posted: Jan 21, 2021 @ 2:22pm


Amazing story that is timeless and relevant to current culture war happening our real world. On Discrimination of people just for being born different whether it be race, sexuality, gender, religion or national origin. This game's focal point is to accept those who are different irregardless of what they might believe or be like. Even if it's something you don't like. So tolerance.

 4.7/5: Narrative 

I find some of the characters to be 1D, and a little flat sometime. I think Lloyd for example is kinda boring, not a bad character but he feels weird sometimes. He's likely my least favourite out of the playable characters and my favourite being Collete or Presea 

 3.4/5 Protagonists

Game play it feels dated but i do kinda like the system even if feels kinda janky sometimes. Some of the characters are really hard to play as if not done right. but if you can master combos it's pretty fun 

3/5 game play 

The villians can be rather interesting the main villian is just more tragic than anything else. and the more supporting antagonists are just your standard supervillains. Powerful but stupid, smart but cold, cunning and spiteful, ruthless and lacking in empathy, and total psychopathic. 
3.5/5


Graphics are very dated if they were the graphics from the cut scenes it would be even better. but i kinda like the anime/cartoony style 
graphics 2.5/5




Edited Jul. 22. 2023

84881958.review: Tales of Symphonia is one RPG that is a must for everybody, even though it has its shortcomings. The anime designs have aged well, though the graphics are a different story. The frame rate is half of that compared to the Gamecube and that game ran at a blistering 60fps. The graphics are a bit too cartoony, even for anime standards. The gameplay is really unique for an RPG. Like most RPGs such as Dragon Quest and Final Fantasy, there is an overworld where you can go around and there are battles you can encounter. Unlike Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest, the battles are action-oriented instead of turn-based. Keep in mind that this is the first game in the Tales series that is fully three-dimensional, even though the battles are played in a two-dimensional environment. The story can be riveting, but it's rather formulaic. Like Phantasy Star, it blends fantasy with science fiction elements. All in all, Tales of Symphonia is truly a must for every RPG fan.

84824704.review: Been missing the feel of an old JRPG and this game absolutely scratches that itch. Similar to Legend of the Dragoon in a number of ways, but good ways.

84640818.review: Tales of Symphonia is the first 'Tales of' game that I have attempted to play. Upon beginning my playthrough I found that many of the important information about the game is never or only sparingly provided, so I strongly urge using a guide to ensure you are doing everything you need to. I made the mistake of entering Balacruf Mausoleum too early and am now forced to grind up 8 levels to be on par with the area's boss. If you are interested in playing this game, I would recommend trying the remastered PS3 version or trying another game in the series. Unfortunately, the Gamecube port is very dated and the controls (even with GamePad) are unnecessarily complex. I will be moving on from this game 12 hours in to pursue more modern titles in the series. Rating : 4.2 / 10

Redownloaded the game, made sure all parts were downloaded correctly, checked virus protection and nothing was being blocked and restarted computer multiple time. After trying to get assistance, which Steam does not personally give since its a third party game I am seeing people all the way back to 2016 having these same issues and many never got a resolution. Only good note was Steam replied to my refund request very fast.

82891928.review:
I first played this game in 2005; originally I grabbed it because of the anime-like artwork on the front and I'm so glad my weeaboo heart drew me to this game. The story, the characters - it's all so deep and intricate. The game goes on for hours and hours and never gets boring - even if you've beaten in five times, so far, like I have. 

I love that I discover something new every single time I play - one of the side quests, an item. There's so much to do in this game and I love that you can't do certain things until you unlock a part of the story. It all goes so well together. I don't think I'll ever stop loving this game. It was a huge part of my childhood but I still enjoy it well into adulthood. I love the characters even more now that I can truly understand where they're coming from and what's going on in their heads. Each character is so unique and written so beautifully and the story is also absolutely fantastic. 

There's a lot of lessons to be learned in this game and I think it shaped me as a child - I became a lot like Lloyd - a gentle idealist.

82865136.review: I had wanted to play this ever since it came out on the GameCube back when I was a kid, and now, *many* years later, I was finally able to play it! The music and art style were both excellent. The gameplay was alright; I wasn't a huge fan of the battle system. Otherwise, it's a fairly standard JRPG: there's some evil people that are wreaking havoc on the world, and the protagonist and his friends have to stop them. The story was decent, though not the best. All in all, I think it's a game that every JRPG fan needs to try, but it honestly wasn't one of my favorites

82853402.review: I had never played any game of the Tales series, let alone Tales of Symphonia. However, I have played multiple RPGs with very deep stories, and I have to say, my goodness, what a roller coaster ride this has been. The best stories are the ones that are thought provoking, and this title has been such a gem. Sacrificial lamb for the greater good, slavery, discrimination, the multitude of sides in war are just a few of the many themes that are explored in this game. The characters are fun, and their development has been fulfilling to experience, and the setting is massive considering its time. The combat system isn't perfect; it's designed to be more optimal towards co-op gameplay, but it doesn't change the fact that this game is a must play if you're an RPG fan!

82811130.review:
Uno de los mejores RPG que he jugado y al que le tengo más cariño. Jugué a la versión de GameCube por centenares de horas. Reconozco que tengo la versión de Steam por nostalgia y que posiblemente nunca lo termine en PC, pero a todas aquellas personas que no lo hayan jugado nunca, os espera todo un viaje.

Pros:
-duración estimada en primera partida: mín. 40h.
-alta calidad de la historia en general.
-personajes memorables.
-buen papel por parte de los actores/actrices de las voces en japonés. En GC jugué con voces en inglés y aunque no llegan a la misma calidad que en japonés, no están nada mal.
-cierta flexibilidad a la hora de completar la historia, con caminos alternativos (no muchos, pero se agradecen en posteriores partidas).
-gran cantidad de objetivos opcionales y coleccionables.
-diálogos entre personajes importan y tienen impacto en la historia.
-buen sistema de habilidades. Me gustaría saber si sigue existiendo el bug que permite acceder a habilidades S y T al mismo tiempo en esta versión.
-banda sonora excepcional para la época. No esperéis un nivel tipo NieR: Automata, pero hace su trabajo y es memorable. Única pega, han mantenido el opening japonés. Uno de los pocos casos en que el opening Europeo de GC era mucho mejor que el del país de origen.

Cons:
-al sistema de combate se le notan los años. Además, creo que fue el primer título de la serie "Tales of" en introducir un campo de combate en 3D, pero el movimiento del pj del jugador no dispone de movimiento libre por todo el campo, teniendo que cambiar de objetivo para moverse en otro plano. Por suerte pulieron el sistema en "Tales of" posteriores.
-los gráficos podrían ser mejores al hacer el port. No espero que los actualicen a niveles modernos, pero creo que incluso la versión de GC se veía mejor. Quizás es cosa mía.

82764151.review:
Never played ToS, despite hearing how good it was as a kid.

- Battles were fun; I've always liked the style - it's definitely the game's strongest point
- I thought the character development was pretty good, even if the dialogue was designed for a younger audience
- Good variety of characters to play
- No software issues, ran smoothly
- Themes are presented a bit too bluntly at times - yes, this is all 'good vs. evil' but it could be more subtle
- English voice acting is okay, not the greatest quality - some voices I liked
- I think it holds up today, but the writing will likely leave adult gamers unsatisfied

Overall, pretty good. Might go for a second run on higher difficulty.

82311669.review:
Tales of Symphonia is a classic JRPG. It is a great game by any means; if you, however, expect a great storyline, full of unexpected happenings and so on, I would not recommend it. 
 If you play it awaiting for a mature plot, it is certain that disapointment will strike upon you - instead, approach it light heartedly, appreciating the great art and little details of the game which make it so enjoyable. Sincerely, this game has been a great journey which I have gone through during this pandemy, and it certainly helped to relieve a little bit of the inherent tension attached to the period in which we are living.

82223031.review: Un buen JRPG me encantan los Tales of..., buena historia, personajes que se les coge cariño y bien desarrollados, los combates entretenidos aunque son muy puñeteros cuando quieren, la banda sonora bien no para tirar cohetes pero bien, graficos es un juego del 2003 asi que son lo que son cumplen. Es un juego muy recomendable si te gustan los JRPG.

82192081.review: This game is great fun and a classic example of action based RPG. Beautiful story, with exciting characters and many objectives make this game worth playing.

82190416.review: Game speaks for itself, enough said. Enjoy!

81941981.review: Bastante bueno en historia y se puede jugar de coop players si tu compañero es paciente.

81837836.review:
Para todos los jugadores de la vieja escuela de RPG sin lugar a dudas es un titulo que te puede llegar a encantar, la historia y narrativa del juego es perfecta y la evolucion e transfondo de cada personaje lo hace aun mejor, al comienzo puede llegar a ser aburrido como cualquier RPG pero a medida que avanzas es muy divertido; si quieres divertirte mas en los combates recomiendo aumentar la dificultad.
Si eres un jugador que le gusta sacar logros vas a tener que hacerlo con ayuda de la wiki debido que los logros de este juego son muy secundarios y dificiles de encontrar a simple viste, tambien eh de decir que para jugar la maxima dificultad ahi que jugar el juego por segunda vez; puede sonar molesto jugar el juego dos veces para desbloquear la dificultad pero debido a los logros y a que el juego tiene una sorpresa (No quiero dar spoliers) esto facilita las ganas de jugarlo dos veces.
Como dije antes, lo mejor de este titulo es la evolucion de cada personaje y las interacciones que tienen los mismos mostrandonos un plano mas intimo de ellos y de momentos sentir que estas haciendo lectura de un libro por lo bien hecho que esta para el jugardor/espectador. Si buscas un juego con buena historia y risas/retos este es un titulo para eso

81793657.review: Great storyline, Dont wait and just buy and play!

Well, indeed, is not the best of the ports
   ...and you have to fix it because does not work in windows 10 with the special K installer.

But it does run on a netbook (Ideapad10) with a fanless celeron n2840 dual core processor, provided one lowers the resolution to the minimum, as well as tweaking the special k installer ini file. In this tiny screen and a proper controller, it just feels nice to play the game.

79773525.review:
So Tales of Symphonia was one of those games I heard a lot about. Most of it good, but when I actually went to play the game it didn't live up to expectations. It has a good battle system and an interesting story (though the length of the story is a bit loo long) but other than that it has too many problems for me to recommend.

Firstly I should say the game is LONG. As in a single playthrough took me 70+ hours!!! Now it's fine if games take that long to complete, but the main story should not take that long. For the record I actually do like story, but after awhile it just drags and you start to wonder when is it gonna end. I didn't even go after that many optional things. (at least I don't think I did as I played it blind) But yeah the game takes a long time to finish. RPG's are known for having long play times but that's usually  when you take into account optional stuff and side quests. The main story should not take that long to finish. As a working adult, who has limited time to game, I want to play a game, finish it, and move onto other ones. If I like it maybe i'll come back and replay it (especially if it has either multiple endings or different classes to play as) I don't want to spend 70 hours on one game just to finish. If I spend 70+ hours on a game it should be because I had FUN playing it and want to keep playing it. 

Secondly the Tech and Upgrade system is a bit flawed. The game tells you there's a difference between T and S Skills and that different gems have different skills you can learn, but you'll probably need a guide to figure out how to get some of the better skills. I kept leveling up and using the techniques and I swear I wasn't able to get some of the better ones. I really wanted to Zelos to learn some new skills, but I must have been doing something wrong because he never seemed to learn any better magic skills. I eventually tried looking up a guide to help me but even that didn't really answer all my questions. So yeah I don't like the tech system for learning new techs, felt like there could have been some work there. 

Finally there's the upgrade (or sythesis) system. It uses a similar one to FFIX where you need to use old weapons and armor and fuse them to make new one. I'm not very fond of that system as sometimes you need to buy more than one weapon or armor to make it work, but also there is an instance in the game where a certain town is destroyed and you needed armor from that town in order to fuse a better armor later......Oopps guess I should have known that town was going to be destroyed and i wasn't going to be able to go back and get the armor  I need for a better fusion later, boy am I an idiot.... So yeah needless to say I don't much like the upgrade system in this game either

All in all I think you would be better served playing a different RPG. I'd recommend FFX, Mass Effect, or Chorno Trigger (all of which are available on STEAM) before I recommend this.

79513984.review: Tales of Symphonia is easily my favorite game of all time. I'm not going to go over pros and cons and explain why I think it's a good game, I'm obviously biased in that regard, but I do want to talk about the quality of this port. I have played every version of this game multiple times on all of the consoles it was released on minus the PS2 version because I don't have a Japanese PS2 nor do I read Japanese. That being said, the PC port is by far the version of the game that I prefer the most since it is the most accessible if you game primarily on Steam, as well as having all of the added content that wasn't in the original GameCube release. While it obviously isn't perfect by any means, I wanted to put my opinion out in the open since I consistently see people complaining about this port in their reviews. Since it was released, I have never once had any sort of issue with this port even after all of the time that I've put into it. The only odd thing that I've noticed with it is that during an important cutscene for two of the party members, some of the audio files and lines of text don't match up with how they're supposed to but that is the only time it happens in the entire game. While it's a bit confusing at first, it's certainly not game breaking in the slightest. The 30 FPS cap also doesn't have much of an impact on gameplay either since battles still feel really smooth even with the cap in place. All in all, if you've been thinking about picking up this port for one reason or another but have been turned off due to the complaints that people have, don't be. This is still an excellent version of the game and will absolutely give you hours of entertainment if you find it enjoyable.

79444607.review: Probably the greatest RPG on the Gamecube and now it is finally brought to Steam.  I know there are comments about how the graphics don't look right, but as someone who played the Gamecube original when it was released and never played the PS2/PS3 version this is based on, I didn't even notice there was a change until reading up on the game after completing it.  I had a lot of fun going through the game for a second time and really enjoyed reliving the story and playing the great action RPG battle system.  Tales has battles that you transition into but you can see all enemies so they can be avoided, but once in a battle you are playing a full on action game with special moves, where you are in a 3D space but on a 2D lane with the enemy you're targeting.  This makes it easy to do precise combos and work special cancels and other high level techniques into your repertoire.  This great combat system combined with a great story that has pretty good pacing and some novel touches for a JRPG make for an RPG that is hard to put down.  Overall, this is one of my favorite RPGs and I'm glad to see it has stood up to the test of time.

79307791.review:
Oh man. So conflicted feelings on this game. Part of me liked this one the best of all the Tales games I have finished so far. But I feel something's missing here. Let's open this up a bit.

First of all, this game is old so I'm not gonna go to details about the graphics. You can tweak the resolution up but the game is way too blurry and mushy to look at in the end. A full on remaster would do the trick and just sharpen up the textures and models. Oh well, can't have it all. The game itself if bright and colorful and has nice animation. Nothing bad to say about that.

The sound. Hm. Best music of all the Tales games in my opinion. Very nice melodies overall. But the damn sound effects ruin this department. I had to put the volume from 100% to around 10%. But some of the sound effects were still at 100% volume so in some areas wind/sound of water/some misc sounds here and there just damaged my eardrums and you couldn't do anything about that. Kinda annoying. Did they test this  game before they launched it? ..I doubt it.

Controls are good and responsive. And the tech system is fun to use and is solid overall. Nothing bad to say about it. 

*SPOILERY THINGS AHEAD ABOUT THE STORY*

The story.. well. Here I gotta say that this game lacks a bit in this department. Some of the characters were fleshed out more than the others. The game had some heart wrenching moments with Colette losing parts of herself but POOF, she got better way too fast. Raine and Genis didn't really have a good character arc after the being a half-elf and it making some other half-elves miserable. They didn't really have a reason to be so cross about it because they didn't really grow up in that environment after a while. Sheenas arc was good one. But I really wanted some more tension between her and the SO GODDAMN AWFUL protagonist who was so dense about everything. I think they made the best pairing from the bunch. It just lacked something. Preseas arc was another sad and emotional one. I really liked that but it could have been tied more to the Colettes arc better. I thought they were too similar in the end. Zelos was kinda ...boring. actually. He didn't really have and arc if you didn't pay attention to the Kratos/Zelos affection choice. Yeah there was a awful affection point system going during the game that chooses your "soulmate" or something. I chose Sheena on my playthrough and I really wanted to see how their relationship could go. But HOLY BALLS the ending was awful on that department. It closely related to Mass Effect 3 ending where the choice didn't really matter besides one character was shown in the very end with the protagonist. 
About the protagonist. I think he was one the most boring characters ever made. I think he is the worst main character in the Tales series. He's dense and doesn't really bring anything to the table. He's the everyman, a swordwielder, magic sword blah blah. He's so dense to boot so there was no chemistry at all with any of the other characters. Well. I suppose he's made to represent a blank slate to the player. I liked Tales of Vesperia protagonist more with some more witty dialogue and such. 

Overall, the length of the game was around 70 our on my first (and only I suppose) playthrough. The game drags itself quite a bit at times but it doesn't get monotonic enough to be annoying. The puzzles were fun at times and dungeons didn't drag themselves too much. I think the game is just a lengthy sort of game. Lots of dialogue and skits to watch, things to do and side quests to explore. 

For a Tales game, there are better ones, for a RPG itself it's fun enough to play, as a story it's confusing at times and the characters lack a bit of Flash and Pizazz but they serve their purpose at times. Recommended overall to pick this up on sale. Just cringe through the loud sound effects at times.

78854814.review:
This is a really great RPG for it's time. This game came out in 2003 and I was shocked with how long the game lasted me. It took about 80 hours for me to beat the game.

Basically it is a typical RPG that has a cute aesthetic and a very interesting story. The gameplay is very satisfying and addicting. It consists of a 3D battlefield with the player having almost full control of it, being able to move all around it. Each of the 9 playable characters each with their own move set which adds to the replayability. If you have beaten the game after playing mostly as Lloyd, trying playing Colette or Genis instead.

While this game is older, it does have some quirks such as no fast travel (not until much later) and limited options for certain mechanics such as cooking. However, even with these letdowns, it was still really fun. If this game was great, I am sure later additions to this series will be even better.

78503990.review:
Having never played any of the Tales series, this was a blind purchase when I bought the four games on steam. I am not at all disappointed, while many aspects of the game remind me of early Final Fantasy games in the items and way the story is done, the combat system is a refreshing and unique system that I've never seen in any RPG that I've played. The game doesn't do very well at informing you of some of the things, or I missed it when they mentioned it, because I was like level 20 or so before I realized that I could switch my character's titles for bonus stat growth at level up.

While the entertaining and challanging battle system makes the game really fun to play, the level of customization, though limited to a degree, allows you to set your character up the way you want them. I haven't made it very far in the game, but playing on Hard battle rank lives up to the term. I have found myself having to do heavy leveling just to manage some of the enemy groups in the game. The difficulty is intense in the beginning due to the level of learning required to get familiar with the battle system, but makes for a fun and epic battle compared to the turn based battle systems I was used to in the older Final Fantasy series.

After having beat the game three times now, I have to say that this game is really a welcomed find. The quality of the port seems lazy and partially broken, but more than fine to still enjoy the game. I have to say the sound levels are one of the biggest issues; moreover, anytime you are near something constant like a waterfall, the sound level is so loud. You can adjust the sound level of special effects, but in doing so, make other things so quiet that there is really no fix to these high volume levels. One other complaint is for achivement hunters, one of the all title-based achivements is broken. Fortunatly there is a mod here on steam that you can use to allow it to unlock. I didn't continue to use the mod afterwards, but at least there is that option to get the achivement you earned. My last complaint is that for all achievements, you are required to play through the game four or five times. While I love the option for new game +, this causes the game to become very tiresome.

All in all the game is a very enjoyable experience, this port is not the difinitive version of the game based on what I've read; however, while it feels to be a lazy port, the game is still very playable and fun. I wish developers would stop tying achivements to multiple playthroughs and instead just include a new game + feature for those that want to make multiple runs through the game. I have to say the new game + grade shop options compensate to some degree for the additional runs by taking some of the extra work out of the next run. If you have never played this game and enjoy JRPG's, then this is one you will want to check out.

77849317.review:
This is a story of a world with a long history of discrimination and oppression, which is the most basic reason to cause plenty of hurtful tragedies and also the crisis of the world's destruction. All those dire historical events are all led to the extreme desires of humans to make themselves more power to control and rule the races that are different from them and seen as the "evil". The past brave saved the world but hasn't saved the negative desires from human hearts until now. And now, the world is facing another huge crisis. How do Lloyd and his companions face to understand both huge problems and find their way to solve them? This is the main highlight of the story. Following the fantastic story, you'll deeply dig out the sad past of each character, understand their values, and have your own reflection about the theme that the game is aimed to express. I believe that you will enjoy the story of the game if you are a fan of JRPG.
The music directed by Mr. Motoi Sakuraba is really satisfying perfect work. The beautiful tones show the broad and relaxing scenes of both Sylvarant and Tethe'ella, the tense rhythms for battle mention the difficulty of the battles not only for monsters but also for the Bosses. The BGMs in the four temples of Spirits and Derris Kharlan are very holy and serious, in order to show the greatness of the ancient power and the contributions of ancient heroes. Play the game will not only make you enjoy the story but also let you fall in love with the music produced by Mr. Sakuraba.
At last, as a Chinese player, I strongly recommend my compatriot fans of JRPG to buy this game. And I also hope that Bandai Namco Entertainment provides Chinese subtitles for us to fully understand the game (both traditional or simple are all OK). Thank you.

77714178.review: Incredible mechanics for its time. Super cute!

77707347.review:
[h1] Quite good, isn't it? Actually, it sucks and is outdated. I lied, it's actually Great [/h1] 

Absolute stone-cold classic boomer JRPG comfort food. So near and dear to my heart that reviewing it is like asking me to review my own Dad... 
Still, here goes:

The first third is unassailably great, on par with the first disk of Final Fantasy VII. Unfortunately, the game never quite lives up to the high stakes it sets up, and the middle sags quite a bit. The plot twists and sprains its way to form an epic (though at times unfocussed and underexplained) tale of friendship, sacrifice, loyalty and betrayal, starring a cast of lovable, memorable and well-realized anime people (and Regal and Presea...), all with some of the best designs you'll ever see.

The gameplay is also still a lot of fun. It's less smooth and action-heavy than later games in the series, and the main protagonist is basically the only one who's actually genuinely fun to play without learning how, but the combat is still enjoyable and addictive. If you've never played a JRPG before and you're turned off by turn-based combat, this may win you over... Or I'm just old and this game actually handles like arse to anyone under 25...
The game is often quite non-linear with a ton of interesting (and easily-missable) side content, which was great back in the day, but is actually a huge pain nowadays. If you're any sort of completionist, or if you only want to play it once, you may suffer. It's full of all sorts of random extra stuff to find.

yeah, it's kinda old and the voice acting has a strong "budget DVD by ADV films" energy to it, but it's still great. They just don't make 'em like this anymore... *sssip*

77241891.review:
Wow wow wow what a game. I don't even remember why did I get it but it was in my library for years. Tried to play it a few times but the combat system instantly turned me off. Just didn't really click for me. But this week I finally started the game with a mindset that I finish it no matter what... and it was a good decision! It's a really really good game. I admit I still didn't really like the battle system but this time I did something differently. I've played the whole game through with auto-battles! And yes it works, and it was fun. There is a bit difficulty jump around the first real story boss but after that the game is much easier (as long as you still fighting random mobs so you level up +  you keep up with getting gear upgrades). In the end before the final boss I was level 65-67 with all my party members https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/1656720389304029449/4A5D371510196D0156010897477CCCA6EC203FF3/ (not sure that's high or low but didn't have a problem)

I really liked the story, the characters, and the world. Had really strong Final Fantasy vibes when playing the game. Can't really say anything without the spoilers but the story is actually engaging and good, maybe a bit too long for its own good but that's not a big problem. It just takes time before it picks up and starting making sense more or less. Maybe that would be my biggest criticism that sometimes the story is all over the place. Not story complicated per se just complicated because it takes itself complicated. Hard to describe that but with a different pacing the story telling could have been good. But that's still a little thing compared to the whole of the game. So yeah it was a blast and now I'll play the other 3 Tales games too that are available here on Steam.

I can highly recommend the game if you want to play a good JRPG. I'm pretty sure the battle system makes or breaks the game for a lot people but as I said above try the auto-battle mode, it's still not easy you just play on a different mode (imagine kinda like how Final Fantasy XIII worked, which I really liked). One problem I encountered: if controller vibration is enabled (and you play with a controller) there are heavy FPS drops, into the single digit territory, in some scenes. Just disable vibration and everything is fixed.

If you need a good spoiler free 100% guide then arguably this is the best choice https://gamefaqs.gamespot.com/gamecube/561316-tales-of-symphonia/faqs/42708

And this is the Ex skills guide I've looked up sometimes https://gamefaqs.gamespot.com/ps3/765388-tales-of-symphonia/faqs/61238

76828547.review:
If you're comparatively young, I'm sure you'll LOVE this game! If you're not, this game is virtually unplayable. 

First of all, this game is targeted to a ridiculously narrow age bracket -- allusions to which are constant in the dialogue and character design itself. This was particularly disappointing because Tales of Destiny II remains one of my favorite games of all time. 

This game follows the Nintendo & Bandai Namco marketing strategy, which have never produced a decent RPG. Apart from the narrow audience, the character design doesn't work for anyone older than about 12. The character dialogue is so corny, that sticking with it is impossible. And I'm not just being critical, It simply wasn't made to be played by anyone but children. 

The map design is also barrier. Huge icons represent baddies. And the dungeons are so generic that I I knew I was done afterward.  

I honestly regret paying $5 for this game. For kids though, It's probably the best there is.

Hope this help!
*tips hat

FULLY RECOMMENDED for children
NOT RECOMMENDED at all for everyone else

Hace miles de años, nació un gran árbol en el mundo, distribuyendo maná por todos los lugares del mismo. Sin embargo, las guerras y las disputas acabaron por agotar el maná del mundo, hasta el punto en que casi lo destruyen. El gran héroe de guerra Mithos se sacrificó para dar al mundo una oportunidad más, y esa leyenda ha pasado de generación en generación hasta hoy. Tales of Symphonia es un JRPG  en el que te embarcarás en la aventura de Lloyd, un chico un tanto terco pero siendo un trozo de pan, donde acompañará a su amiga de la infancia Colette en la misión de restaurar el maná del mundo. En su viaje se encontrarán con más personajes que les ayudarán y, a su vez, te dejará entrever que no todo es tan bonito como los gráficos lo indican en un principio. 

Este juego te muestra facetas muy crudas de la vida, cómo el racismo puede afectar hasta niveles insospechados a los personajes; te mostrará escenas bastante crueles y algunas incluso te darán repelús por lo que conllevan. Esto no hace más que añadir a la aventura el toque de querer seguir jugando y de ver cómo se desarrollan los acontecimientos. Yo destacaría este punto como una de las características más fuertes del juego, ya que ayudan a que creas en la historia y en lo que está sucediendo en el mundo.

Mezcla de fantasía, aventura, comedia, tragedia y momentos de suspense, este juego apuesta por una historia bastante larga pero bien contada. A través de las conversaciones que saldrán entre los componentes del grupo, Tales of Symphonia te aporta una aventura rica en detalles.

En cuanto a los gráficos, nos encontramos ante un juego que se estrenó en la GameCube, y muchos sprites siempre repetirán una acción establecida y eso será lo que veas, pero los gráficos no es algo que yo tenga mucho en cuenta a la hora de hacer una reseña porque lo que importa es cómo te lo cuentan todo. Este juego no se restringe por eso, y los combates están llenos de movimiento, magia, detalles y al principio me encontraba un poco perdido en mitad de tanto caos. Sin embargo, uno se acostumbra a verlo todo en pantalla.

En cuanto al apartado musical, yo diría que está bien. Tiene algunos temas musicales bastante destacables y otros menos. 

Tenemos un juego bastante entretenido: tienes mil cosas que hacer, con algunas rutas que cambiarán dependiendo de qué decidas o de cómo hagas las cosas, los personajes tienen su sistema de afinidad (el cual debo decir que apenas entendí porque supuestamente los traté de la peor manera posible cuando yo veía que se llevaban bien con el protagonista) pero tengo entendido que se nota poco esto último. Tienes muchas submisiones ocultas, y esto puede llevar a confusiones porque, si llegas a determinado punto de la historia, tal vez esa submisión se pierda si no la has hecho antes. Ergo, o conoces lo que hay en cada zona y cuándo ir, o posiblemente te saltes alguna cosa (como me pasó a mí). Aparte de eso, tendrás enemigos poderosos, un sistema de mejora de armas y armaduras, la posibilidad de cocinar para el grupo tras cada combate...hay mucho por hacer en este juego.

En resumen, estando lo barato que está (a mí me costó 3 euros), me pasé mi primera partida en 51 horas, sin realmente pararme en mucha cosa, y explorando lo que me apetecía. Es un juego bastante largo; muy rejugable, ya que al acabar una partida puedes canjear una cosa llamada rango (lo vas obteniendo tras cada combate) para transferirte x cualidades, equipo, etc, a tu "New Game+" y para poder hacer cosas que quizás te saltaste en tu anterior partida o tirar por otra ruta. Recomiendo este juego para aquellos que quieran estar entretenidos muucho tiempo en un JRPG con una historia interesante, buena y que a veces, te deje pensando en los eventos del mundo de Sylvarant.

Deep breath... Deeeeeeeeeeeep breaaaaaath. 

Wow man, this game has divided me so much that I really don't know what to say. Actually I know what to say but it may take long and I want to cut short as much as possible. Also small note: This is my first "Tales of" game. I deliberately started from this game because it is the oldest "Tales Of" in Steam. And the other reason is that when you go from old to new games you can see lots of improvements and kinda enjoy it. If you do it reverse, you cannot stand old games and your brain kinda rejects them. It is a tactic I always try to apply.

First thing first: I gave thumbs up because I couldn't give thumbs down to this game, my heart couldn't allow that. But believe me that [b] if Steam had allowed "Neutral Thumb" when reviewing (which I reaaaaly like them to add this goddamn feature), I'd most definitely used that one.[/b] Definitely no other way, no sirreee!

This game is good at some mechanics. But really bad at some other mechanics. 

Good things are; most of the voice actings (played English VA), really good main story, fighting mechanics (to a degree).

Bad things are; Outdated quest log, REAAAALY BAD story presentation, unnecessarily long game lenght bad quest mechanics etc. etc.

I know that this game has come out for Gamecube but believe me I've seen so much better presentation from PS1 games. I can call myself that I do not discriminate games for their release dates but this game is so bad at presentation aspect that occasionally you find yourself saying "What? What the hell??!"

And that is a really game breaker (at least for me). You cannot immerse yourself into the game because of this. Also you do not have any quest marker as well. I know that at "synopsis" you can see the general information but most of the time those informations are not enough as well for you to figure out what to do. Was it really hard to add at least general marker for where to go next? Apparently it was.

Lastly the game is unnecessarly long. I've played lots of long J-RPGS (100+ hours games) but when playing this game you really feel wrongness at some point. You feel the stall tactics clearly and I believe most of them are reaaaaly unnecessary.

At least the main story is good but because of the presentation you cannot feel enough emotions. Maybe it's me but I  couldn't immerse myself into this game. Even so, I like the companions and they all have different characters. Their voice actings are really good most of the time.

I can write lots of other things but I don't want to do that. I just want to say this: 

[b]This game is really outdated and you need a strong patience to finish it. I cannot bring myself to say that "This is a bad game" but I can say this: [u]The game is average at best.  [/u]

Consider this if you want to start this game. [/b]

75472373.review:
Es un clásico atemporal.

Tiene algunas cosas arcaicas porque fue el primer tales of en 3d, sin embargo es un juego que esta bastante adelantado a su época, tato a nivel de calidad de vida (interfaz, menú de objetos, funcionamiento de las tiendas, moverse por el mundo) como en mecánicas, pese a tener ya casi 20 años sigue siendo bastante ameno y es de hecho menos tedioso que incluso algunos jrpg/rpg que salen hoy en dia, la peor parte respecto a esto es la incapacidad de saltar escenas, pero no es un problema muy grave porque hay muy pocas cinemáticas y los textos se pueden pasar realmente rapido, ademas las pocas cinemáticas que hay siempre esta bien verlas, aunque como alguien que se ha pasado el juego como 15 veces, los créditos son una putada XD.

En cuanto al sistema de combate, no es el mejor de la saga, hay ejemplos muy honrosos como el graces F o xillia 2 (los mejores) o el hearts (las 2 versiones) que tampoco están nada mal. Sin embargo es mejor que muchos juegos de la saga, incluyendo algunos posteriores como el abyss, el vesperia o el zestiria y posiblemente a la par que el berseria.

Esto lo consigue gracias a su diseño equilibrado, sin mecánicas absurdas que conviertan la lucha en unilateral y con control sobre la cantidad de golpes que puede recibir el enemigo, mediante una mecánica que tumba el enemigo y lo vuelve inmune al retroceso durante un tiempo. Esta mecánica se perdió en los siguientes juegos de la saga y no fue hasta el xillia 1 que no se recuperó (aunque el graces tiene un sucedáneo de esto mediante un stat concreto, si no estas absurdamente leveado es muy difícil hacer combo infinito a nada). El resultado es que el juego se siente bastante justo sin dejar de ser desafiante, con algunos combates realmente difíciles por su duración no porque te maten a cada golpe (esto es un problema muy notable en la dificultad del vesperia, cuando tienes un sistema de combate que permite hacer combos infinitos, la única forma de subir la dificultad es la muerte instantánea, y en el vesperia hay mucho de eso).

74875344.review:
I spent a lot of time ruining my life by trying to get all the achievements for the game but after 4 runs I realized I forgot some titles and now I need to do at least 4 more so I'm going to have a conniption fit at some point.

Regardless, it's a nostalgic classic that picks me up when life's got me down. The characters (maybe not Colette), the story, and the gameplay are incredibly charming and just a joy to experience, even now as an adult. With loads of sidequests, secrets, and end game content, you can easily rack up 40-80 hours on your first playthrough depending on your playstyle. 

It's your standard JRPG with standard JRPG tropes in terms of plot, but the character development is so well done and there are twists and turns in the plot being thrown at you constantly. They might not be surprising twists, but there's enough of them that you'll want to keep playing to see where the road takes you next.

The battle system is riveting and, at certain difficulties, have you on the edge of your seat. Straying from turn-based battle (which I also love) and using the real time action system really makes this a unique experience to the franchise. Doing the a 10% exp. run after some vanilla ones really made the game engaging again even after a couple playthroughs, as you have to rely less on how you battle with your character as you did before, and rather rely more on organizing what the whole team is doing at all times. Speaking of characters and your team, the ability to battle as any of the 9 main party characters, even switching between them in the midst of battle, adds so much variety to how you can go about any playthrough.

I do have some bias because this is an old favorite I played for the first time about 14 years ago, but I believe regardless that there is much to fall in love with in this game. I would hands down consider this a 10/10 JRPG experience and probably the best game I have ever played so far in my life.

Anyway, I'm giving it a break for now, but I'm going to get those last few achievements eventually or so help me god....

74271258.review:
I played this game originally on gamecube and the story in this game is so good, it can literally be in the top 3 best story in JRPG in history. 

The game has a lot of great pros and some cons to it obviously.

Pros :
- Great story, well written.
- Great game lenght. It was requiring 2 CD on the gamecube back then! (which was extremely rare!)
- Fun puzzle solving with the sorcerer's ring.
- Gameplay easy to understand which make the game accessible even for those not familiar with JRPG
- Even though the game is old, the art-style still manage to look good even to this day
- Great side-quests
- Extremely good character design with lots of back story. All party member gets soul and love put into them.
- Good Replay value with bonuses for fun and completionist!

Cons :
- The game being kinda old, the combat system limitation didn't aged well.
- Even though the combat system is easy to understand, it can be a bit cluncky at times.
- The AI can be a bit terrible at times.

I really can't give more cons to this game even though I've been searching for 15 minutes.

Would I recommend this game to someone : YES!
Is it worth the full price of 21.99 CAD$? : YES! Even to this day, this price for the lenght of this game is a steal!
"But I'm a hardcore gamer, is it fun even though I'm used to JRPG?" : Yes, there is the Mania difficulty, on new game plus, you can lower your EXP gain to bring even more difficulty and even more challenges! Plus, the side quests can be extremely challenging!

Not convinced yet? ...... How the heck are you still not convinced? I told you, the price is neat, the story is A-MA-ZING and the game still is fun to this day. The only reason you wouldn't get that is because you hate J-RPG, So...... go ahead and buy it!!! :D

72856834.review:
Tales of Symphonia….a timeless classic I’d say and don’t worry the story gets better later on trust me, so just bear with the 1st half of the game. Now here are the breakdown of the game:

[h1] The Pros [/h1]
(+) [b] A Really Interesting Story [/b]
The game had a really slow start before the story gets good and by that, I mean a [b] REALLY [/b] slow start. The theme of the story revolves around racism and sacrifice which is the bread and butter of most JRPGs with interesting twist here and there to keep you entertained with the story. 

(+) [b] Tons Side-Quests [/b]
As per usual, tales of game have tons and I mean tons of side quest to do. Some of them are tedious to do and some actually have a pretty good story with great character development on the side. 

The down side of this for me is that there are no quests indicator so either you to talk to every NPCs to find it or you read a guide for it.

(+) [b] Combat Are Easy to Jump Into [/b]
Combat are really simple and easy to understand, you either block or attack or perhaps heal from time to time. However, the part that irks me is the fact that Mystic Artes are really complicated to execute and the camera need time to get used to.

(+) [b] Lovable cast of characters [/b]
(+) [b] Very Nice Anime Cutscenes [/b]
(+) [b] Great Soundtrack [/b]

[h1] The Cons [/h1]
(-) [b] No Skip Button [/b]
This is kinda sad, the closest thing you get is a text speed configuration. 

(-) [b] Translation Issue [/b]
Some line of the dialog just doesn’t make sense or doesn’t fit with the situation. But not to the point it ruins the game experience.

(-) [b] No Retry Option [/b]
Yeap you heard it right, its game over if you lose a fight. Make sure you come prepared before every boss fight.

(-) [b] Random Crashes [/b]
Yea this part is the most annoying part of the whole experience, since you don’t know when the game will crash and ruin your progress. I don’t know if there’s a fix for this, but make sure you save everytime you get the chance.

[h1] Verdict [/h1]
All in all, for me this game was a really enjoyable jrpg with a great twist on the story. Now I do hear some troubling aspect of the game that some other people experienced, but thankfully I don’t experience those or perhaps it was so minor that I didn’t notice (I meant other from the crash issues). If you enjoy classic jrpg then this one is right up your alley. Do give it a try.

72226900.review:
I think I had a different experience than most reviewers, so bear with my atypical impressions.
The bad:
1) The start. It's...slow and a bit tedious. And by the start, I mean the first 20-30 hours or so.
2) Walking on the map sucks.
3) I ended up using a keyboard and no mouse because for some reason my controller didn't work. Awkward.
4) About 2 or 3 times I was left wondering where I had to go next with no clear hint in my quest journal. Thank god for the very helpful Steam forums or I would have given up.
4) The final 4 or 5 dungeon puzzles are HARD. Maybe I'm just stupid or impatient or old (or all of the above), but if I hadn't been able to watch YouTube playthroughs for the last 20 hours of the game, I fear it would have become 40.
5) Too many ending fake-outs. I was ready for the game to end several times, but there was always a twist to keep the story going (usually involving poor Colette being kidnapped).
6) The combat system was convoluted (though you can set things to auto and button mash through).
7) An affinity system that's never explained, pointless trophies and hidden systems you'd need a guidebook to take advantage of fully.

The Good:
1) A charming, goofy old school aesthetic.
2) Characters you grow to love.
3) A long (it took me 70 hours) story with unexpectedly dark twists and serious meditations on sacrifice and racism.
4) Even though I didn't really know what I was doing, the combat grew on me.
5) At the end, I was entirely satisfied with the conclusion of all the character arcs, and felt a little bit sad that it was all over as the credits rolled.

Verdict: This was my first Tales game (yes, I'm very late to the party), and now I'm eager to try more. Recommended, but unless you're a methodical puzzle-solver (or masochist), be prepared to reach out for help,

71947488.review:
The thoughts™️
+Combat rewards you for learning it. Deceptively simple, but gets more fun the more effort you put into learning the nuiances.
+LOTS and LOTS of endgame content.
+New game+ mode
+Sound test when you beat the game
+Story around the end gets really interesting, and lots of character development
+Absolutely incredible soundtrack
+It gets better later

-"It gets better later."
-"It gets better later."
-"It gets better later."
-"It gets better later."
-"Later" is "The 35 hour mark"
-Some sidequests have to be constantly maintained throughout the whole story.
-The first 35 hours of the game are a total fucking slog where you see every plot twist coming, there's no emotion in any interactions or story events, and this is the part that took me three years to trudge through. At the 35 hour mark, though, it suddenly pulls a COMPLETE 180 and becomes an actual really good game with a gripping story that left a good taste in my mouth. ...Why'd that TAKE so long?
-Almost every single dungeon in The trudge is ridiculously annoying or incorporates a frustrating puzzle or gameplay mechanic. I remember one forced me to grind random drops off enemies and then take them to some random NPC in a town just to get past a progression wall.
-Skits. I mean, it's nice that they have little optional events to view character development, but please give me one good reason these are timed and autoprogress at their own rate when none of them are voiced? Half the time it's just watching a character portrait's mouth move for WAY too long per message box and you can't skip any of it once you've read it.
-90% of the sidequests in the game pay off only right before the final dungeon, including all of the alternate cosutmes.
-Many many MANY sidequest and event rewards require up to FIVE playthroughs to get everything.

Overall: 5/10. "It gets better later." Exemplified, but it's no lie. If you have the patience, this game is great in the long run.

Though it may not be nearly as unique as I first thought as a kid, there's a lot to like about this game. Solid story, endearing characters, and simple but fun battles. Especially if you have the ability to do co-op with at least one person, it's a good game to laugh with, and end up a little more touched than you might have expected. Great voice cast too, particularly for the time. And did you hear that battle music in the trailer? Come on. 

If you enjoy any of the other Tales Of games, this is one worth the time to go back to. If you haven't played any of them, this is a great place to start (especially if you're not interested in the older 2-D ones). You can even easily find someone's save to start new game+ with increased experience or starting items, so you can easily get by skipping a decent chunk of encounters if you want to play through it quickly. 

Full disclosure: I easily played through this game's 40 - 60 hours 10+ times when I was younger. I'm somewhat biased, but it's just a very good time.
