71107420.review:
[h1]THE STORY[/h1]

Our tale begins with the Empire of the One God.

Ah, dammit, wrong game.

Once upon a time, there was a giant tree, blah blah blah, war, life of a hero, goddess, angels, chosen one, blah blah blah.

Our tale begins in a world known as Sylvarant, where it is said that, as long as there is enough "mana" available, the fields will be plentiful and the world will be peaceful. Naturally, there is nowhere near enough mana, so the world suffers from constant food shortages (of which we never actually see the effects, funnily enough) and the evil Desians (read: magitek half-elf Nazis) run rampant.

In the village of Iselia, there lives a young girl named Colette, who is said to be the "Chosen" who will restore peace and plenty to the world. But this isn't about Colette, this is about Colette's classmate Lloyd. When Lloyd and his snarky half-pint best friend Genis (yeah...) witness Colette receiving a magical "Cruxis Crystal" from the angel Remiel, they become deeply fascinated by the "Journey of World Regeneration", a sacred pilgrimage undertaken by the Chosen to awaken the "Summon Spirits" and the goddess Martel, which will hopefully replenish the world's mana and defeat the Desians.
Unfortunately, a series of shenanigans involving an elderly prisoner of the local "human ranch" (read: concentration camp) leads to Lloyd and Genis being banished from the village, leaving them with no choice but to join Colette on her journey, against the wishes of the village elders.
After more shenanigans, they meet up with Colette and her group and journeny through the desert to the Seal of Fire, resting place of the spirit Efreet. After defeating the monstrous Ktugach, guardian of the Seal, Remiel appears before the party and grants Colette angelic powers of her own. And with that, our heroes, along with Genis's older sister Raine and the mysterious mercenary Kratos (no relation), continue on their journey to save the world.

But Colette is hiding something, and it seems that virtually everyone our heroes meet knows more than they're letting on. And a mysterious young woman seems determined to stop Colette at all costs. Could there be more to this journey than "stop the bad guys, save the world"?

Oh, you have no idea.


[h1]But how does it actually play?[/h1]

I'd describe it as a cross between Chrono Trigger and Super Smash Bros., strange as that may sound. Ok, Maybe that's not the best description, but it's late and frankly I'm not very good at describing things like gameplay. So we'll skip straight ot the pros and cons, shall we?


[h1]Don't mince words, Mr. C., tell us what you really think![/h1]

It was a mistake for you to accept promotion.

Gratuitous Star Trek reference complete. Time to do the actual review.

Pros:
[list]
 [*]Incredible art style with some of the best use of cel shading I have ever seen.
 [*]A unique and charming cast of characters ranging from a young self-taught swordsman to a very busty ninja to a martial artist who seems to like his handcuffs a little too much (it makes sense in context).
 [*]Thrilling real-time combat
 [*]Many waifus
 [*]Many husbandos
 [*]Some frankly spectacular magic spells
 [*]A damn fine soundtrack (which as we all know can make or break a game)
 [*]Wicked sicknasty interdimensional jet-scooter-plane-things with an awwesome theme song
 [*]Enough sidequests and bonus content to, by my estimate, nearly double the length of the game.
 [*]Truly incredible voice acting, with spectacular performances by Scott Menville, Cam Clarke, Tara Strong, Robin Atkin Downes, and many other famous names.
 [*]Provides a deep and surprisingly nuanced examination of human nature.
 [*]An impressive amount of replay value if you have the patience to sit through the first part of the game multiple times.
 [*]Both heroes and villains are hella fucking badass!
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
 [*]Chocolat
 [*]The tech system can be quite awkward; learning spells/special attacks requires each character to have performed lower-level spells/attacks a certain number of times, usually 50. This isn't so bad for most characters, but for some, such as Kratos and Zelos, you'll have to carefully manage their skill usage if you want them to learn any really cool moves.
 [*]Chocolat
 [*]A lot of stock anime humour, mostly involving Zelos. This wasn't [i]as[/i] tired and overdone when this game was made, but still!
 [*]Chocolat
 [*]You WILL need a guide to fully enjoy this game. Seriously. Especially if you like sidequests. Many of them require counterintuitive steps just to [i]initiate[/i], to say nothing about actually completing them. Case in point: [spoiler]to unlock many late-game sidequests, you have to enter [i]the last room before the final boss[/i], view the cutscene, and then [i][b]turn around and walk away![/b][/i][/spoiler] It's ridiculous!
 [*]Did I mention Chocolat?
 [*]While some of the game's puzzles are fun, they can get [i]very[/i] grating, especially in those areas where you're constantly being hounded by enemies in a confined space.
 [*]The game's replay value can actually work against it; you need to beat the game [i]at least[/i] three times to complete the Collector's book and the Monster List, as [spoiler]three minor accessories are associated with specific endings, and a particularly spoilerific boss is exclusive to the bad ending.[/spoiler] Combine that with the fact that the system that determines [spoiler]which of the game's eight (count 'em, eight!) endings you can get[/spoiler] is very opaque in and of itself, and I honestly cannot, in good faith recommend trying to 100% this game unless you have a frankly obscene amount of spare time and are willing to devote at least a month of your life to completing this absolute beast of a JRPG, but if you do somehow manage to pull it off, then I salute your devotion to completionism.
 [*]Minor nitpick, but due to a quirk in the art style, characters can sometimes look as though they have tiny bandito moustaches, even though they actually don't. [spoiler]Yuan[/spoiler] is probably the worst offender, but Colette gets it quite badly as well.
 [*]The writing is usually excellent, but some scenes leave a lot to be desired (case in point: Chocolat).
 [*]I will never understand what the deal was with that scene where Lloyd and Genis run into Raine as they're leaving the Martel temple... And that music... What were they thinking?!
 [*]You now cannot unsee the moustaches!
[/list]

Overall?

I fucking love this game! Don't get me wrong, it has its flaws. A lot of flaws. But it more than makes up for them with its lovable characters, thrilling real-time combat, and deep, compelling plot that twists and turns like a twisty-turny-thing while still managing to remain coherent. As long as you can look past the apparently-cliche-at-first plot and occasional moments of cringe (*ahem*Chocolat*ahem*), you [b]will[/b] enjoy this game.

                                                                                                               Yours Sincerely,
                                                                                                                  -Mr. C.

[h1]So do we get a TLDR, or...?[/h1]

Yes, yes you do.

tl;dr: it has its ups and downs, but I still recommend it to any serious JRPG fan.









But what I want to know is, was the coffee really hot or cold?

69049656.review:
Quick:

3/5  Tales Of Symphonia is a good game.  It is a solid JRPG, if what you're looking for is something to sink a lot of time into.  The story is decent, but like many things about this game... it's just good enough.

More:

     This game started off slow.  The middle portion was exciting, and endearing.  Towards the end it dragged out and slowed down again.  My favorite portion of this game was the middle portion; when the world initially opens up to you.  There are dozens of cities to explore and multiple interesting characters to meet during this part of the game.  When the game nears the ending, it begins to grind to a halt, and the padding shows up.

     There is so much needless padding in this game.  It is ridiculous how many times I thought that this game would end, only to send me off to complete another objective.  I stopped caring about the story after approximately the third time that this occurred.  The story arc for this game looks like the reading on an oscilloscope monitor.  It just keeps going up and down... up and down.  Characters are introduced so often, and the story tries to pull so many twists that I eventually had no idea what was going on.  All of the different groups and their motivations began to blend together, and the goal of the player's group became muddied behind it all. 

   Then there are the puzzles.  The puzzles are horrible.  Dungeons more often than not have some type of puzzle that you're supposed to complete.  Some are not clearly described, or they are simply trial and error exercises.  Some are just ridiculous.  It made finishing this game a chore.

     One point that I constantly hear when people discuss this game is the battle system.  That is just OK as well.  It is often noted that there are no random battles in this game.  Encounters with enemies are initiated when the player's character model contacts an enemy in the world while moving around.  This is a good idea... yet it is implemented in a horrible way.  Battles in this game often times are unavoidable because you spend a lot of time walking down narrow corridors, and you can't simply run past the enemies.  When you move to another 'screen', and then go back, the enemies respawn.  You end up in battles more often in this game than in any other game I've seen with random encounters.  It happens so often that you will quickly become tired of battling enemies all-together, and just constantly use the escape option (well... I did at least).  I would rather have random encounters than to run into enemies every 10 seconds.  The worst part of the battle system is the constant player chatter.  Players and sometimes enemies talk 'CONSTANTLY' during the battles.  Every few moments someone will call out their current move.  Sometimes there's a cacophony of voices screaming out different magic and special attacks, and talking over top of each other.  I muted the game more times than I can remember because of this.  My ears literally began hurting during one battle because of the repetitive and mind-numbing chatter.

     This game is OK.  It's fine.  If you like RPG's and especially JRPG's, then I can recommend it.  Just make sure that you have a lot of free time on your hands to complete this one.

68344784.review:
Story:
Tales of Symphonia is a pretty standard JRPG: you're placed in control of a random kid who gets wrapped up in a quest to save the world. Along the way, he finds out things aren't quite what he expected, so he runs off on an idealistic journey not just to save the world as he knows it, but to make it into something better for everyone.
The good:
The characters are generally likable and enjoyable. Despite the nature of the story, the game tries not to take itself too seriously, which is good, considering that you're basically playing a cartoon.
The bad:
The story is a bit formulaic, a bit cliched, and sometimes a little cheesy. There were moments that the dialogue was so corny, especially toward the end of the game, that I prayed like crazy no one was watching me out of fear that I would die of embarrassment. There are a few too many "well that was convenient" moments in the game for my taste.
The ugly:
There comes a moment when you have to admit to yourself that this game is kind of cheesy, but you keep on going so that you can beat the tar out of more evil plants or watch one of the main characters make a buffoon out of himself.

Gameplay:
It's a real-time battle system that feels sort of like a traditional fighting game with lots of combos and special moves. You're limited to a 2d plane of movement, but the camera and that plane will rotate as your enemies move around the map.
The good:
Generally speaking, the gameplay is fun. The battle system takes a little bit of practice and a little bit of strategy, so it's not a complete hack 'n' slash.
The bad:
Your teammates' AI is, well, dumb. Technically speaking, you can choose to control any of the characters in your party, but you're pretty much forced to play Lloyd or another tank; if you try to play any of the support characters, you quickly find that the AI is too dumb to protect you long enough to cast any spells.
The ugly:
Some of the gameplay mechanics have not aged well at all. The battle controls are a little finicky and lack the polish and fluidity that you would find in a game like this today. Particularly obnoxious is the sort of arbitrariness surrounding the battle camera and the restricted plane of movement that shifts as you attack different enemies. Some of the puzzles are more tedious than I remember, and wasting ten minutes to push a couple blocks across the room is... unpleasant.

Port Quality:
The good:
It's a 100% faithful port of the PS3 port of the original GameCube version. All the features are there, including the originals animated cut scenes. They updated the UI and fonts so that they don't look blurry on modern screens, too.
The bad:
This is not a terribly well-optimized port, which makes me think it's just playing inside a custom-built emulator. Certain options, like antialiasing, had to be disabled because they completely trashed my framerate and made the game nearly unplayable. I played it on a mid-range laptop that can handle games like the Witcher 3 just fine, so any lag at all in a port from a GameCube game in 2004 is unacceptable.
The ugly:
This isn't an ugly game, and the art style still holds up at 1920x1080, but high resolution screens exaggerate all the flaws in the original game, like low resolution textures or Colette's hair clipping through her clothes.

Overall, this isn't a bad game. It's not going to go down on any "best of" lists or anything, but I enjoyed it a lot more than some "classics" like FF X. You can get a good forty hours out of a single playthrough, especially if it's your first time. It hasn't aged as well as some of the truly great console RPGs, but it's worth your money if you've got a few weekends to kill.

67737074.review:
*Got this version for preordering Zesteria. Finished this game twice on the Gamecube, and that version visually better. The only reason I would suggest buying this version would be if you're interested in some extra content not available on the GCN release. Without the TSfix mod, the game looks and runs terribly in comparison.*

Aside from that, this game is fantastic. The voice acting is incredible featuring the voices of Scott Menville, Tara Strong, Jennifer Hale (Mass Effect), and Cam Clarke, etc. The characters are unique and are developed beautifully. 

The story is captivating with enough plot twists to make M Night's head spin. And the game is long, with an average completion time of 40-60 hours.

The artstyle of this game has to be my favorite of all the tales games. While animation is a little dated at times, the chibi character models and cel shading make the graphics age a little nicer. Newer tales games in the series (Zesteria and Berseria specifically) look too textbook anime/over the top to me. And Anime mixed with motion capture never sits well with me.

The battle system is addicting, with 8 different playable character styles, each with two different skill trees to work with. It's fast, technical, and fun. It feels like a beat em up with each random encounter, with special moves tied to the B button similar to Smash Bros.

The gameplay outside of battle is a little hit or miss. There are a ton of missable sidequests and unlockables for your characters. And in this version, it will require a minimum of 5 playthroughs to unlock every costume. The dungeons start out simple and kind of enjoyable, but later on they get really cryptic and tedious, with one in particular is tied to terrible AI.

For the main game, the difficulty level stays pretty flat in my opinion. You won't have to do much grinding. Some boss battles will knock you on your ass if you're not prepared with proper move sets.  I like to play on Hard on my first playthrough which kicks my ass for the first 30% of the game and then it seems to level out as I learn better skills.

The post game will have some things you will have to beef up for however. There is the ability to start a New Game+ in which you can purchase perks with battle "Grade". These perks will allow subsequent playthroughs to be way easier (or harder if you choose).

Overall, the game itself I highly recommend. If you can play the Gamecube version, go with that one. If not $20 on steam isn't a bad deal at all.

Good basic concept, but makes a lot of mistakes.

[table][tr][th]
Overall      ★★★★★★☆☆☆☆ - 5/10
Music        ★★★★★★★☆☆☆ - 7/10
Graphics   ★★★★★★☆☆☆☆ - 6/10
Gameplay ★★★☆☆☆☆☆☆☆ - 3/10
Story         ★★★★★☆☆☆☆☆ - 5/10
[/th][/tr][/table]

Difficulty   ★★★★★☆☆☆☆☆ (except some special challenges)

Big flaws:

* game starts quite boring
* story has a lot of logic flaws in it (especially when you look into details)
* most character designs are not quite interesting
* game uses a lot of filler events in the first half of the game
* some characters are quite annoying (eg Colette, Zelos, Genies)
* weird and slow camera bevaviour on maps (angle)
* you can't reload in mid-battle
* you can't skip cut scenes (only dialogues)
* NSC can make you stuck in corners (you can't push them)
* battle system has too much elements in it (lack of a clean concept)
* some special fights are way too difficulty compared to the rest
* Niflheim dungeon has no savepoint before boss battles
* you get forced to play the game 3 times to get all Steam achievements and in-game collectibles
* limits in usage of summons of Sheena renders summons quite useless
* mystique arte of Lloyd only usable with a certain (not the best) sword

Good things:

* story gets better on second half
* up to 4 players (local coop)
* a lot of sidequests / events
* like the anime style video cutscenes
* new game+

Tales of Phantasia was way better on SNES. Tales of Symphonia can't live up with this.

66703753.review:
Classic tales of game given a bit of a facelift to clean the graphics up, but is otherwise untouched from what I can tell. The gameplay is the usual tales of combo system where you link basic attacks into different levels of special attacks, from 1 to 3. So 1-2-3 basic attacks, then a level 1 special, level 2, then level 3. Its a lot of fun to create combos from all the different moves you have available, with the 8-9 characters you can play with through the game. Its the kind of combat system you can get lost in, or just happily button mash your way through. 

The only real problems are that the AI is dumb as bricks and requires some management in boss battles to stop spell casters running into melee range. The very early sections of the game (first five hours) are weirdly difficult due to the lack of healing available. This is also back in the days where tales of games had a crazy amount of secret content, which means players should be prepared to consult a guide at any time or miss out.

Other than that things are good. Encounters are visible on the field, save points usually appear just before a boss, soundtrack is memorable, and the story is well paced for the most part. Its a good game and its really not as dated as I thought it would be. 

A final note on the game length. The game took me about 56 hours to finish (don't know why steam says 59), but I did most of the side content. I would guess that you could probably get through in about 40 if you only did the main story. New game plus and doing 100% will push you close to 90 hours I expect, although I wont be doing those.

65645454.review:
Disclaimer: This is my first Tales game.

I'm a fan of (older and modern) JRPG's, and after playing the Trails series and looking for similar games, I found that Tales of Symphonia almost has this legendary status. Did it deliver?

■■■ Gameplay ■■■
Gameplay consists mainly of a "2.5D" fighting system, exploring the overworld map and towns, dungeons, and reading dialogue. I got most of my enjoyment from exploring towns. Unfortunately for me, I just couldn't get into the combat system. It felt slow, and I didn't like the enemy targeting system. There are quite some items and equips in this game, but I never really needed it, and played the rest of the game on Auto after a certain point. That is, except for some bosses with INSANE difficulty spikes in the beginning of the game. I had to level for hours to even get a chance beating them. I like that the dungeons have some puzzle elements to it, but most of them were extremely easy, and just very tedious to do. All in all, it felt like a really low-quality game to me, even for its age. Keep in mind this game also is LONG, which I guess can be both bad or good. (50-70h)

■■■ Visual style & Graphics ■■■
I really liked the colorful and toony visual style. Most town designs are pretty cute. Although a lot of textures are super blurry, everything looks good enough to play on your big TV in 1080p. Except for the overworld, which looks empty and very low-effort. The anime portrait art while viewing conversations was good. Character animations are pretty basic, but do the job I guess.

■■■ Music, SFX and Voice ■■■
Not impressed by the OST. Again, I know it's an old game, I don't mind the crappy midi-instruments ( in fact, I love those!), but the compositions of most songs just didn't cut it. No really memorable tracks here for me. Most SFX are decent, but some have VERY obvious loop-points. Come on, devs. However, voice acting is great, and there is quite some of it!

■■■ Story ■■■
And here, maybe the most important section. I often hear story is extremely important for Tales games.
I really liked that there was a lot of character interaction; a lot of silly conversations which still give some depth to each character. At fist I didn't really care for them, but they grew on me.

The main plot itself was a big letdown, though...
After the first few story events, the pace drops to pretty low and this will continue for about half of the game. The second half of the game got a bit more interesting... but man. The cutscenes are some of the worst I've ever seen.
Pacing is all over the place, and animations are sh*t. They just all have zero impact the way they are made. I never cared about what was happening in the game at all, and most of the time it felt more like a chore to follow everything.

Some sections and interactions made me think of the Trails in the Sky trilogy, but then I realized how infinitely much better executed the story in Trails was, even though those games also are pretty dated.
If you're looking for an extremely well-written story with very good character building, go get those games instead. (Music is also excellent!)

■■■ Technical & Bugs ■■■
Kinda bummed this didn't run on 60fps, but I never really encountered problems.

Well, what can I say... Sorry to all Symphonia fans out there. I think nostalgia might have been playing a big role in this game getting the status it has. But considering other JRPG's that are available now, new and old, I think this game isn't worth it if you have no connection to the Tales series already.

I might still try one of the newer games, but I don't think this series is for me.

65619091.review:
This is a port of the Gamecube version of the game that came out in 2003 and the fifth main title in the Tales series of action RPGs, and unfortunately the gameplay hasn't aged well at all especially compared to the more recent Tales games. I do not recommend this game but if you insist on playing it at your wallet's risk, be sure to install Kaldaien's Tales of Symphonia Fix mod (visit the Steam guides page for more information) to solve all known technical issues and ensure a smooth gameplay experience. You can then go to Settings ingame and select 1920 x 1080 resolution. While you're at it, visit NexusMods and install the Braless Sheena mod. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) This game is completely devoid of fanservice so even the smallest hint of cleavage ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) is certainly welcome. A controller is also highly recommended.

I have played and platinum'ed all the latest Tales games on the PS3 and PS4 (Graces f, Xillia, Xillia 2, Zestiria, Berseria) so it is quite disappointing to experience how primitive the Tales series used to be during its early days. The story follows the standard Tales formula and tropes: a group of characters go on a journey for some inane reason (in this case, Lloyd accompanies his childhood friend, Colette, on a pilgrimage to release all the seals that will allow her to transform into an angel and regenerate the world), discover an alternate world (two worlds is a trope that exists in pretty much every Tales game) and their quest is escalated to world-saving stakes. The cast of characters are quite bland, to be honest. The female characters are extremely covered up to the point that it gives off the impression that the character design was intended to cater to mentally challenged SJWs (though this most likely isn't the case given that the original game came out in 2003, way before any of this woke garbage infiltrated gaming). If you installed the Braless Sheena mod ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°), you do get to see Sheena's nice set of plump breasts that hang pretty realistically against her chest to show appealing cleavage though it doesn't come anywhere close to count as lewd or arousing.

The battle system is atrocious and extremely cumbersome compared to recent Tales games. Movement is restricted to a 2D plane (only forward/backward movement) as there is no free roam, and you can't sidestep to avoid enemy attacks which forces you to either backstep or defend and this makes combat extremely sluggish. Unlike recent Tales games, there is absolutely no way of gaining 100% stagger immunity so your attack animations can still be interrupted by enemies no matter how far you are into the game. Getting staggered and interrupted is the most annoying part of Tales combat and the fact that this is unavoidable in this game is extremely frustrating and makes battles an absolute chore. You'll spend more time in battles getting interrupted than actually doing damage, and most of the time battles are won by your AI party members casting long range AoE spells while you get chain staggered by enemies. Party AI isn't as great or customizable as recent Tales games, but they get the job done moderately well at default settings i.e. they heal when needed and don't waste TP by spamming skills unnecessarily. The element and species weakness system found in recent Tales games is noticeably absent in this game, so you'll be doing pathetic amounts of damage regardless so there's no incentive to tailor your skill setup for different enemies.

The difficulty at the beginning of the game is ridiculously overtuned and among the worst balanced I have ever experienced in gaming. It does eventually become more manageable once you get enough characters to fill your party but I highly recommend using a trainer for the first 2 hours of gameplay at least if you want to have any chance of progressing.

Unlike the latest Tales games, this game still uses a world map for exploration like old-school RPGs. However, traversing the world map is extremely tedious and slow. Monsters show up on the world map and battles only occur if you run into them but it's pretty much pointless to evade them as they can move faster than you so you end up fighting a ton of unnecessary, repetitive battles just to go to your next objective. Signposting is terrible in this game and areas that can be entered aren't well-defined, so you're left to wander aimlessly on the world map until you eventually find a location you can enter. The synopsis occasionally hints at the direction of your next objective, but overall the game is pretty vague as to where you need to go. You'll be forced to backtrack plenty of times during the course of the game, and since there is no fast travel whatsoever （╯ ͡ ͠° ͟ل͜ ͡°）╯︵ ┻━┻ it's gonna be extremely frustrating if you don't know where to go and have to revisit old areas one at a time. The camera angle while your on the world map is very restricted and it's really difficult to see where you're going, much less avoid enemies.

Dungeons start off pretty easy and relatively manageable compared to recent Tales games, but by midgame they quickly become annoyingly long and filled with tedious, frustrating mechanics that we've come to expect from Tales games. However, recent Tales games have the benefit of nice graphics and a fun battle system, of which this game has neither. The combination of the terribly primitive battle system, unclear directions and frustrating gimmicks make dungeons in this game an absolutely horrendous experience.

Post-victory battle quotes in this game are extremely lacking in variety and comedic value compared to of those in Tales of Graces f, Xillia and Xillia 2; I saw the same 4-5 unfunny post-victory battle quotes recycled throughout the entire game regardless of my active party. Skits in this game are not voiced if you play with English voices, and they are terribly boring. The sad attempts at humor are pretty cringe; they are nowhere near the level of comedy gold of skits in Tales of Graces f, Xillia and Xillia 2. Even Tales of Zestiria has funnier skits, and that's really saying something.

Tales of Symphonia could have passed for a decent RPG 17 years ago, but the quality unfortunately doesn't hold up to modern RPG standards. I do not recommend this game at all due to the terrible graphics, extremely and lacklustre dated battle system, bad gameplay mechanics and absence of fanservice. If you're looking for a GOOD Tales game, I highly recommend Tales of Graces f (my personal favorite Tales game) which has the best combat and party AI in the entire franchise, and tons of entertaining and memorable skits and post-battle victory quotes. Tales of Xillia and Xillia 2 are also must-plays for the skits with tons of sexual innuendo ("bazongas" ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) ) and awesome, sexy female character design. Tales of Zestiria and Berseria are controversial games in the Tales community, but they have extremely enjoyable battle systems once you learn them and grind for the correct builds. Literally all of the above are better than this game. Tales of Symphonia is the worst Tales game I have ever played.

This was one of the first games I have ever played on the gamecube, and holds a special place in my heart. I had lost the second disk of the game so I haven't had a chance to play it until recently when I got some money to buy it here on steam. For anyone looking for a good story, as well as a fantastic cast, this is a really good RPG to get a start on, because the Tales series is really good, but this one by far takes the cake.

It definitely has some issues as a port, but nothing super hurtful to the joy it can bring. My biggest issue is controller mapping being limited to battles, since on the world map it feels weird to press specific buttons to do things, when on the gamecube it was formatted a bit different. 63902195.review:
Truly the best game ever made. 

The story seems kinda standard "chosen one has to save the world" at first, but evolves after ~10 hours into something much bigger with some great twists.

 The cast of this game is phenomenal with very likeable characters. We have the impulsive but very kindhearted, the dorky chosen one, the genius, the mysterious mercenary and many more. The chemistry between those characters is truly great, which gets enhanced due to skits between the characters. They really make this game and is the main selling point.

Speaking of the characters, the voice acting in this game is top notch with some known voice actors. Also the soundtrack is really great with some pumping battle tracks.

Graphically, its a Gamecube game from 2003, so its not state of the art, but the cell-shading-look is passable still to this day. The overworld and the non animinated cutscenes look dated unfortunately. Speaking of, this version is sadly only 30 fps locked, unlike the Gamecube Version, which plays fluently 60 fps.

The 2.5 D battle system is really fun. Chaining combos as Lloyd feels really good. If you played newer titles of the series, like Tales of Vesperia, the gameplay feels a bit rough with the lack of free running, but this is by no means gamebreaking. If you have some friends you can even play with four players simultaneously.

The port had some issues at launch, but they are fixed mostly, minus the 30 fps.

Tl;dr: Play it, it is a masterpiece.

63386873.review:
This was not the best JRPG I have played but I am sure it is not the worst JRPG.  I would recommend it though only to people who would enjoy a JRPG mostly for the sake of it just being a JRPG.

Some of the factors that lowered my enjoyment of the game include:

At least one unbearable character that joins your party which of course you can not dismiss.  I have rarely felt this way about characters in any RPG that join your party.  In some cases you might have someone annoying or just not cool that you can effectively bench resulting in no longer having to heard their dialog during cut scenes and such.  This is not the case with this game, you are stuck with who joins and any time 'story' happens you will have to hear them.

The world is deceptively open.  There are events in the game that open up more 'enhanced' modes of travel just like in most JRPGs, like boat and air travel.  However I was greatly let down when I spent a lot of time exploring only to be shut down by the game saying stuff like 'this place is not open yet' thus forcing you into a rather liner mode of playing.  

The combat system was a bit new for me as I have mostly stuck to Turn Based systems.  The real time action combat or whatever the term is called was refreshing at first, planning out what attacks to use to link together and such.  This eventually became extremely boring.  The one saving grace that stretched out interest in this system was the ability to directly control any of the party members and they all felt rather different for the most part.  

The story was not all that captivating.  In fact at a certain point I just wanted to get the game over with, this resulted in one of the rare occasions I did not feel a desire to go pursue all of end game side quest content 'like gathering Ultimate Weapon activities and fighting Bosses that are harder than the End Game Story Bosses'  in a RPG.  

I do not have a ton of positive things to say about the game.  The overall impression for me was that the game had average content and a lot of it.  Which is not necessarily a bad thing, especially if you are someone who is looking for a huge game to sink some time into.  Also I did not have any technical issues during my entire play through (no crashing or anything).

62112743.review:
Rápido: Gran juego para empezar con la saga de Tales. Buena evolución de historia y personajes. Gameplay divertido, sencillo y más profundo de lo que aparenta. 

1. Gameplay: 1.1- Combate: Ataques básicos y habilidades que pueden resultar en largos combos. Se pueden bindear hasta cinco habilidades en total al control o teclado. Dos de estas pueden ser para ordenar a nuestros compañeros que hagan ellos sus habilidades como sanar, buffear, dispels o cualquiera que queramos. Las otras tres serian para el personajes principal que estemos usando, el cual podemos cambiar en cualquier momento. ¿Desea poder usar a Genis que es un caster? Pues puede ser su main. O si ud quiere ser el soporte, pues también puede serlo. En total (y por lo que veo en todos los juegos de tales, porque este es el primero que juego) en nuestro equipo podemos tener cuatro personajes en un solo combate para nuestra ayuda. 
 Recalco que podemos tener cinco habilidades si queremos para nosotros, o solo tres pero poder ordenar de forma más sencilla a nuestro compañeros presionando algún botón. Por supuesto esto no quiere decir que solo estemos limitados a dos ordenes para nuestros compañeros. Desde el menú de combate podemos usar items, ordenar a nuestros compañeros que usen ellos los objetos o habilidades. También desde ahí podemos escapar del combate. Y también cambiar la estrategia del combate, si queremos que nuestros compañeros sean más agresivos, ataquen de largo, no usen tanta maná etc etc etc.
Luego tenemos una habilidad especial que nos permitirá hacer un ataque en conjunto.
En ocasiones nuestro personaje principal se queda atorado entre los enemigos y no podemos moverlo, esto no pasa mucho, pero es molesto.

Las animaciones, por cierto, son geniales. Algo que no me esperaba. Las habilidades empiezan siendo un poco las típicas como bolas de fuego. Ataque rápido con espadas etc etc. Pero a medida que avancemos iremos consiguiendo más, y más peculiares, en especial la de los casters.

1.2- Items, armaduras, Ex gemas: Pociones, armas y armaduras son las normales. Lo más curioso de estas serían como unos tipo de abalorios que pueden llegar a ser de lo más útiles en el juego, porque nos dan celeridad en hechizos, resistencias, fuerza etc etc etc.

Las Ex Gemas son unos items que nos ayudarán a mejorar nuestras estadísticas, y depende de que escojamos nuestras habiliades pueden fusionarse para elaborar. Claro, las gemas no solo afectan esto, pero ya me estoy cansando de escribir.

1.3 - Exploración: Seré cortico. El mapa es más de lo que parece. Como es normal podemos encontrar cofres con items. O hallar ciertos circulos que nos regalan unos pequeños diálogos donde elegiremos nosotros la respuesta. También la forma en la que exploramos el mapa va evolucionando a medida de que avanzamos en la historia. Yo tengo 56 horas de juego, y eso lo obtuve mayormente haciendo la historia principal del juego. Por todo el mapa, si buscamos bien, nos encontraremos con monstruos, jefes nuevos, NPC´s que nos dan misiones etc etc etc. 
A veces la cámara se mete en lugares extraños y es un poco tosca de mover.


1.4 - Puzzles: No esperaba encontrarme con estos. Algunos sencillos, otros no tanto. Lo normal. Mis problemas son con uno de los últimos. Este tiene cierta "mecánica" que ni siquiera es eso. Lo llamó así para no decir lo que es. Nunca se había presentado en ninguno de los anteriores. Pero cuando llegamos a este tampoco se nos da una pista, porque además esta es la única vez que esta "mecánica" esta dentro del todo el juego y básicamente se encuentra teniendo suerte.
También los primeros puzzles tienen su justificación, pero a medida de que se avanza pierden su "porqué" y solo están ahí para retrasarnos. Al menos yo al final ya estaba un poquito harto, pero solo un poquitico :)


2. Historia: Empieza siendo extremadamente típica. (No olviden que es un juego del 2004, aunque igual no es excusa) Pero esto creo yo es al propio. Nos mantienen al tanto del hilo principal con tanto diálogo con ellos, como si quisieran que no olvidemos de que trata el juego. Y a medida de que avanzamos, sabemos que estamos por terminar lo que se nos propuso al inicio, pero lo estamos por hacer muy rápido. Así que es esperable que haya un plot twist. La historia evoluciona y cambia mucho. Nuestro objetivo final incluso puede llegar a no estar claro. Pero eso es lo genial. La historia evoluciona  y cambia tanto a medida de que nos vamos enterando de todo, que lo hace genial, con uno que otro y otro giro de guión. 

2.1 - Personajes: Grandes personajes con personalidades un poco ya vistas, pero bien marcadas y usadas. Todos aquí tienen un porqué. Todos tienen sus conflictos que los hacen interesantes.. La mayoría consigue un buen desarrollo y desenlaces. No diré nada más.

3. Datos extra: La dificultad está bien casi siempre. Algunas peleas son un tanto difíciles pero nada imposible.
De vez en cuando nos salen un diálogos extra con algo de animación para profundizar en la historia o personajes o para hacernos reír.. Nosotros podemos elegir si queremos escucharlas, pero también hay algunas se nos aparecerán y tendremos que verlas obligados. Estas no son tan comunes como en el Tales of Berseria (ahí llevo casi 30 horas, y esas me tienen harto) El problema viene en que si uds son como yo y no se quieren perder nada, las van a querer ver todas, pero a veces son un poco molestas (como en el Berseria, no me dejan ni jugar) Pero aquí no pasa tanto.

3.1 - Por cierto. Gran banda sonora, en especial al final. Muy buena. Aunque repite un poquito. 
3.2 - De vez en cuando se nos van a mostrar animaciones completas cuando pasen cosas importantes. 
Estoy seguro que no he mencionado todo, pero es que ya no quiero seguir. En fin. Buen juego para empezar con la saga. De todas formas hasta la fecha que escribo esto solo hay cuatro disponibles en steam. Los voy a jugar y reseñar todos. 

PD: Recomiendo jugarlo con texto en inglés y audio en japonés. No sean como Waffer (espero que no lea esto. Waffer lindo :D)
Gracias a Morttis por regalarme el juego :)

61664706.review:
I remember as a kid having Tales of Destiny 2 for my Playstation. It was pretty good. I then remember having Tales of Symphonia on my Gamecube. It's a game I never really forgot. It's a game I never beat. After waiting for poor performance and things to be resolved, I finally picked up Tales of Symphonia on Steam. This game hits right in the nostalgia and really, I have no complaints. I never had any glitches, any hiccups, it all just worked. 

I can't speak to mouse and keyboard controls, but I plugged in my Xbox controller and all the controls worked great right out of the box. I highly, highly, recommend this game to anyone who likes, or thinks they might like real time JRPGs.

61639066.review:
This my first Tales series game. It's a great game, but not without problems. I couldn't use all of the supposed control keys on the keyboard. No, it's not my keyboard. Just that, it just doesn't work. I could use the controls properly using a controller though. Thankfully, that made the game playable. It took me a while to figure out how to play other characters in combat. Guess they didn't explain it that well. I didn't experience any crashes whatsoever.

The graphics are pretty good for an old game. The combat is not the classic turn based system. It's hack, slash, block. Combos are quite difficult to do, especially combos reaching up to 50-100 . There's other combat features like the Overlimits, Unison Attack and the EX Skills system. I don't think I'd ever figure those out without a guide. The story, the world building, the lore are expansive and well written. I really like the voiceover which is available in Japanese and English. Personally, I prefer the Japanese dub as it's the original version. The dungeons are quite challenging. There's a lot of them in this game, so be prepared. If all else fails, look at the guide!! (So that you don't miss anything). 

Anyway, I enjoyed this game very much. I'll give an 8/10. Try this out if you like story-driven RPG games.

61554449.review: I've beaten this game a couple of times on the GameCube, and after all these years, I haven't found a game that's struck me as much as this one has. I know more about ToS than any other game (any other fictional world, for that matter!), yet I'm still excited downloading it for the first time on my new computer :) Strong characters and lore with admittedly convoluted mechanics, BUT I didn't pay any attention to tech and strategy details when I first played it as a kid and still fell in love with it. I think it can easily be enjoyed on the whole spectrum from casually enjoying the rich story to maximizing battle strength/efficiency, so there's a little something for everyone, if you know where to look :)

61012792.review:
If you can somehow play the ps3/gamecube version or handle playing it on emulator, I'd suggest going that route. There's nothing >wrong< with this port...but it does lack a lot of things that made my time playing this game much more smooth when I was kid - in particularly, movement is really restricted on this port and is a complete pain in sections of the game where small movements are important such as the dungeons on small/narrow paths or trying to reach more difficult angles. Handling the boat/rheairds is a lot more tedious, too. 

The game itself is one of my all time favorites but it's kinda predictable if you're a writer familiar with story-telling tropes or older than say 18 and have a book once or twice in your life. The battling is fun for me, even if the AI can drive you insane. If you can play with friends acting for the other characters, you might have a lot more fun with bosses. 

Otherwise, great game - I love this story and its characters so much. Despite some gameplay flaws with the port, I will never consider this a bad game. There is tons of replayability.

=====Do NOT buy==========

I brought this on steam in good faith considering how other games ported to PC (Berseria and Vesperia) worked like a charm, further more i am not one to complain on the reviews without good reason.

58615321.review:
Tales Of Symphonia es un juego  que a mi me ha marcado mucho desde siempre, y lo he jugado en todas las plataformas que he podido. Os recomiendo probarlo ya que aunque el juego ya le pesan sus años se mantiene bastante bien y puede ser un buen comienzo en la saga Tales Of.

Empecemos destacando el apartado jugable, un apartado en el que siempre ha destacado esta franquicia y pese a que sus hermanos pequeños pueden dejarlo en pañales, Tales Of Symphonia tiene un sencillo y eficaz sistema de juego que engancha. Para quien no lo conozca y sigue leyendo pese a mi aviso de spoilers, decir que el sistema se basa en los combates de acción activa donde podremos encadenar golpes básicos y técnicas especiales para hacer grandes cantidades de daño a los enemigos mientras nos desplazamos por el escenario 3D aunque tan solo en 2 dimensiones.

Algo que remarcar en su contra es que para desplazarte en alguna dirección que no sea derecha o izquierda debes depender de un segundo enemigo que este en una posición distinta a tu objetivo actual, ya que te mueves para adelante o atrás usando al objetivo que tienes marcado como punto de referencia para el movimiento en un supuesto eje X de una gráfica tridimensional, eso fue modificado a posteriori en otros juegos de la saga pero en este no llego a existir ningún botón de movimiento libre en ninguna de sus versiones.

El juego te permite controlar en combate o fuera de el a cualquier personaje que este dentro de tu grupo de combate lo que te permite una gran variedad a la hora de luchar casi con la imposibilidad de aburrirse ya que cada personaje tiene sus pros y sus contras con los que deberás lidiar mientras los manejas.

En combate deberemos aprender como enlazar los golpes básicos con las artes que aquí fueron mal traducidas o simplemente adaptadas, como gustéis, como ataques especiales, existen artes de nivel 1, 2 y 3 que en principio se pueden enlazar en ese mismo orden haciendo un combo medianamente largo, un sistema sencillo que se puede enrevesar mas si tiramos de otra funcionalidad del juego, las gemas EX lo que nos permite alterar las características de como combaten los personajes entre otras cosas.

La banda sonora que ostenta este juego es simplemente maravillosa, cada uno de los temas de los personajes esta grabado a fuego en mi cerebro. La solemnidad y respeto que me despierta el tema de Kratos, los bonitos sentimientos que vivo cuando escucho el tema de Sheena, la alegria al escuchar el tema de Colette. Esa experiencia callejera que me despierta el tema de Regal, la dulzura del tema de Presea, la tranquilidad del tema de Raine, hacen que ya solo por los temas de los personajes me enamore de esta OST.

Pero es que eso no es todo, la ost que ambienta el resto del juego es de la misma envergadura, haciendo que disfrutes desde el opening hasta un paseo por Palmacosta o Welgaia sitios con unas músicas muy distintas.

A nivel visual tenemos un juego que pese a no ser un portento gráfico ni ahora, ni en su día el cellshading, el uso de los colores vivos y también ese diseño a medio camino al cartoon le permiten envejecer a una velocidad endiabladamente lenta haciendo que a día de hoy se siga viendo bastante bien en cualquiera de sus versiones. Ademas contamos con unas cuantas escenas de animación que amenizaran grandes escenas. Dependiendo de que versión juguemos veremos mas escenas que en otras, siendo la de gamecube la que menos tiene ya que la de PS3 y PC se basan en la de PS2 que incluía mejoras respecto al original.

Todas sus versiones se mueven bien siendo quizás la mas solida , de forma natural, la de PS3. Si ya tiramos por mods la de PC te permitirá hacer verdaderas virguerias como llegar a los 4K y 60FPS como una roca.

Otro de los puntos positivos del juego es que en varios puntos de la historia nos permite la elección de varias respuesta, alterando sensiblemente la escena pero poco mas en la mayoría de los casos, podría quedarse ahí pero no, estas decisiones pueden ser lo mas insignificante del juego o lo mas importante segun como puedas llegar a verlo. En una primera ronda puede que no te des cuentas, yo al menos no lo hice, pero este juego cuenta con un a la vez semioculto a la vez semidescubierto sistema de afinidad de los personajes principales con Lloyd que permite alterar ciertas escenas durante todo el juego. Este sistema de afinidad dota a Lloyd de un pequeño efecto avatar que ya incluso al principio del juego y si nos damos cuenta insinúa que merece la pena la nueva partida + dándole rejugabilidad a la historia. La afinidad también aumentará con otras acciones como que Lloyd cocine tras la batalla con el ingrediente favorito del personaje o las skit repartidas por el mapa del mundo.

Por ultimo y no por ello menos importante me gustaría hablar de las Skit un recurso muy valioso que no solo nos permiten disfrutar de escenas relativamente irrelevantes, algunas son de gran importancia y otras nos permiten conocer mejor a los personajes de forma cotidiana y son un recurso valioso que llevan usando mucho tiempo en la franquicia.

58350784.review:
This is, hands down, my favorite game. I've loved it since it was a two-disc special on the gamecube, and I would play it tirelessly to try to get the completion bonuses and entice friends into playing the multiplayer so that I could talk story with them. Lets talk about the good and the bad.

The good:
- ToS has an amazing storyline. I mean it can get predictable at times, but it's really immersive and you get to know the characters really well and it gives you an opportunity to form your own opinions on them. I mean you're not like.. sitting there definitely loving everyone. A few of them can be hard sells.
- Good characters. Ties in with the first one really, but the characters are (for the most part) really interesting and have a good bit of versatility on what they each do so that you don't HAVE to play the main character for fighting and whatnot.
- Story-driven outcomes. I love a game with different outcomes! A lot of things can change in your second playthrough depending on how you go about the game. It keeps it a little fresher, so that when you replay, you have some things to discover.
- Replay value. There's things you'll miss, there's things that the second time through you'll be like "ah this thing I figured out later makes SENSE NOW" which is neat and fun, there's bonuses for beating the game and starting over so that you  aren't starting fresh.

The Bad:
- Tbh while the visual update is good I guess I was hoping for a little more. 
- Still some bugs, though they're nothing huge and nothing that breaks the game (as far as I've seen).
- Keyboard feels like the worst possible idea ever for this game so make sure you have a controller handy.
- Collette's voice still makes me want to punch a wall.

I'll never not love this game tbh. I think everyone should give it a shot, if you like a good story, if you like a good rpg, and if you just generally like Fun.

57604498.review:
----OVERALL: 8/10----

-Story - 9/10
The story starts with what seems to be a weaker beginning (until you realize everything’s eventual importance) — do note that ALL OF IT is solely to build up to a powerfully-written middle/endgame.
Plenty of satisfying twists, & effective juxtaposition between emotional moments and triumphant moments, both of which are (usually) accompanied by voice acting and just about always accompanied by a nice fitting score.

-Characters 8/10
Symphonia has a relatively large cast of characters compared to most of the Tales games, but each character carries a relevant part of the story & lore with them, even if some later characters seem a little off-to-the-side.
Some are much more enjoyable than others, but none are particularly dislikable; even the characters that are generally more boring still have unique quirks that make their dialogue always worth looking forward to (Like Raine and her obsession with ruins)

-Setting 9/10
The game sets up strong world-building where every region and race has its own lore that intertwines with all the others and has very clearly lead up to the present situation, affecting the way the story plays out.
An easy-to-navigate and easy-to-remember world map, populated by distinct cities with individualized personality & charm, all typically worth returning to for their own reasons.
Varied dungeons each with very distinct, memorable mechanics; the sorcerer’s ring changes the way you go about solving puzzles. Elemental seals comparable to Ocarina of Time temples (but smaller)

-Gameplay - 7/10
Given the time, as an ARPG the combat feels a bit dated, testing the waters for the series with mechanics that have been since-refined, but Symphonia still effectively implements the features it includes.
There exists a feature called “EX Skills” which are a fun way to use passive skills to differentiate characters, in addition to two branched skill paths for each character, effectively altering the abilities they learn throughout the game from start to finish.
Unison Artes (think dual-techs from Chrono Trigger, but only occasional) are satisfying to unleash against bosses, and it’s fun to watch the characters use these abilities together and discover new ones. 

-Graphics - 7/10
Symphonia uses a very unique and cute cell-shaded art style which provides an interesting complement to the sometimes-darker undertones of the story.
Every character has a uniquely identifiable design that helps make them memorable from the first moment you meet each of them.
All the colors help to make every part of the world stand out, as well.

-Soundtrack - 7/10
With Symphonia being a 2003 game, expect lots of midis, but this isn’t really a bad thing. Given the composer is Motoi Sakuraba in the early 2000s, if you’re into Golden Sun’s soundtrack, you’ll LOVE this one.
All the frequently-played songs such as battle themes, the world-map, and some dungeon themes are memorable and don’t really get annoying like they sometimes can in a handful of RPGs. 
The music selections ALWAYS augment the dramatic scenes.
The different boss themes complement the accompanying boss very well, ESPECIALLY for the major fights that are given unique dedicated themes.
Songs made for less-important segments of the game (like the ones that cut in for like a minute during hectic moments or something) aren’t as memorable, but those are of little consequence.

-The Remaster Itself- 7/10
Firstly, the widescreen support, enhanced resolution, much sharper UI & ditching of the original game’s tendency to blur make it MUCH prettier to look at.
30fps lock is confusing, given that the Gamecube didn’t even lock it like that.
This version includes additions like new regular artes, mystic artes, and even enhanced elemental variations of artes. Also new costumes, dialogue & some extra enemies too.
Also removed various bugs while also removing obnoxious (albeit kinda fun) exploits from the 2003 version of the game.
Apparently this used to be a terrible port at launch, but it has since been significantly fixed up. No worries now :)

----OVERALL: 8/10----

57314392.review:
After playing this game for 2 hours, I feel the need to write a review for it. These are just my first impressions, and I will update the review after finishing the game. Now, without further ado, let's dive into why I love this game so far.

The story is nicely paced, and told in an interesting manner. You take control of Lloyd Irving, and you set out to look for the Chosen, Colette, after being exiled for the Desians attack in the nearby village of Iselia, because you and your friend Genis decided it would be a good idea to visit the off-limits area of one of the Desian's human ranches. So far, good stuff.

The gameplay is what I like the most so far. It's really fucking good. It's so simple, yet so effective at doing what it needs to that feels really smooth once you get the hang of it. Using different techs and learning when to block can be tedious at first, but when you get the hang of it, it feels really good. Overall a really solid combat system so far, and I know it will just keep expanding as I keep playing, and I can't wait to see what gets added later on in the game.

The graphics are really good, considering this is a port of a 13 year old game. Yes, this gorgeous game came out in 2003, I can't believe it either. But if you only care about graphics, and don't really care about a solid story or solid gameplay, skip this title, you won't get anything out of it, since it really isn't the main focus. Textures look kinda low-res when compared to more recent games, but for 2003, it looks mind-blowing.

The voice acting and dialogue are charming and intriguing so far. I like it, good stuff.

The only real problem I have with the game so far is the 30 FPS lock, which doesn't really matter to me all that much since it looks smooth, and you don't need pixel perfect inputs to control it, but it would be really cool to see this in 60 FPS, like on the original Gamecube version. While this may be a problem for some, it doesn't bother me too much.

Overall, I'm really enjoying this game so far, and I'm excited to see where the story goes next. It's entertaining to play, with a really nice combat system, and the writing is pretty good. Overall, if you like JRPGs with a more action oriented focus like Chrono Trigger, Secret Of Mana, and other games like them, I'm sure you would like this one. If you're more of a graphics kinda guy, and don't care about story and gameplay, don't play this game.

Rating so far: 9/10

57109378.review:
I played this as a kid back in 2004. This version is perfectly fine for me to be honest. 
It works well enough and I had no crash or issues. If you can get past the first few hours of the game, you will probably end up loving it.

* HUGE GAME, over 180 hours of content for sure.
* You will think it has ended and then BAM nah. This game came with TWO discs back in the day.
* CHOICES MATTER!! 
* Costumes!! Side quests can get your characters costumes! But only a few of them can wear the costume for good after the event, so pick your favourites!
* Near the later end of the game, you will get a flying machine, and it's so fun to fly around your world map!
* I totally recommend button mashing any moves you get as many times as possible with each character, their moves can branch off with how much they learn, theres so many moves I never learned because I didn't press them enough. For example, the character Raine has 'First Aid' at first which does some basic healing, but if you continue using it, she will eventually learn REALLY powerful healing moves, as well as all the other characters, they all branch from this sort of thing. 

*And yes you can fight in multiplayer mode! The camera is wonky, but you get used to it.

* Your ending will be the same in every game, story wise, but you can end it with any of the characters in your party and it will be different, and it's great. I ended my game with a high relationship with the professor, Raine, so at the end of the game, we met up and had a special conversation with extra stuff.

* As you go through the game, if you talk to people, you will find out REALLY interesting stuff, from ex-boyfriends turning into creatures, murder, meeting parents, aaand you can miss it if you don't chat with them! Do some side quests!!

As a child, that was my first game that actually changed based on what I did, on purpose and on accident.
This game taught me empathy, feelings I could relate to, and just funny things.
This game is my soul. Please play it...all!

55392285.review:
First of all, everyone needs to know this game supports local co-op. Four people can play in combat at once, enjoy.

A lot of people have technical gripes about this game, which is hilarious since it was developed for the gamecube almost twenty years ago, so grow up pussies. It doesn't look pretty but at least they managed to beat Microsoft at making things run at a better frame rate in HD resolutions.
While Japan proves that they continue to not know how to implement controller support for any video game actually solid on PC, I don't recall ever the game being available on Xbox. The game thinks there's one there now (Steam Controller master race) and buttons aren't missing, so that's aces in my book. Great controller support in this game, surprisingly.

There's a lot of things I like about this game, such as the relationships between characters, hours of fucking content everywhere, anime trope shit galore, and an interesting story that continued to be dynamic enough to keep my attention.

This is pretty impressive for a three hour review, I'll get to that later, drink your milk.

There's a lot of things you won't like about the game, for example an FPS lock, which at least works, so can we grow up? It's not giving you the illusion of unlimited FPS, so at least the game looks and perform well, I welcome the lock after playing Halo: Reach on Steam. The real issues in this game lie in some of the less revealed aspects that they kind of expected you to somehow figure out or buy a guide for. Controls aren't really explained well in the tutorial, there's some things that you want to skip or speed up that you can't, and while I love having Robin from Teen Titans as the main character I hate a lot of character's voices in this game.
It's an older RPG, so it's at this awkward stage of being less forgiving and reliant on a saving system I wish we let die in the 90's while not being too difficult, just frustrating more than anything coupled with annoying. There's a perk for keeping Lloyd with the wooden swords basically until Disc 2...so good luck figuring out when that is on PC, but it's worth the grind and tears. There will be tears.

If you can get over this, it's a great RPG for the price of $20. This is the Tales game that effectively reinvigorated the franchise, and if you're not going to go back and play the best Tales game (Tales of Destiny) then this is a good starting point. If Xillia is ever on PC I recommend that next, and I'm looking forward to playing Berseria eventually.

Now, about the three hours. Ah yes, I remember my first ex-wife.
So the whole reason I bought this game was to have my girlfriend play it while I played second hand banana as whoever I wanted with a second controller. Turns out my girlfriend would rather play shitty games like Apex and Overwatch instead, so fuck her, going to start boosting those rookie numbers by myself soon. If you have a girlfriend who plays RPG's and sucks at not dying in them this series is made for you.

4/5 Decent JRPG that you can play with guests/play once with people who say they love you.

55069609.review:
Tales of Symphonia was released for the Nintendo GameCube on August 29, 2003. This is the exact same game. I missed it when I was younger and the Gamecube collapsed. TOS tells of a hero named Lloyd who has a magic object called an Exsphere on his hand. Exspheres are made by growing them them on humans at human ranches. The objective of the game is to prevent a parallel world from eating your world by helping a holy maiden, Collete, create World Regeneration.

Storytelling is pretty cliche with names like Lord Yggdrasil, Ymir, Heimdall, Mines of Moria and Remiel the Angel. The characters are just mirrored in Sylvarant and Tethe'alla. Kratos = Zelos, Presea Combatir = Colette, Dirk the dwarf = Altessa the dwarf. The story is really long and spans the 2 worlds covering Exspheres, Summon Spirits, Human Ranches, Cruxis and Yggdrasil. There aren't any details but a rough touch-and-go.
Yes, I missed Izold, the fishing village. I took the long route up to Asgard and had to walk all the way back. I think their ad for 80 hours of story is true. It's not very good story but it is a long one.

No map. It was so hard to navigate on the World map and in the dungeons. Weldgaia was a super pain in the ass since they intentionally made roadblocks without telling you where they were.

Switching between characters. Technically, it is possible. However, the obtuse way of setting keys and changing from Manual/Semi/Auto is so tedious that I stuck with Lloyd Irving instead. The system is meant for up to 4 players to fight.

Unison Attack. Very good except for 1 single flaw. You can't set healing abilities like Nurse. So, you can't combo a heal and attack at the same time.

The amount of content is very good. There are many levels and stages to play. The main issue lies in the quality of the content. While there are plenty of stages to cover and many interesting puzzles to play, it feels "not wow". Like a huge sackload of potatoes but little quality steak. 

New Game Plus is sucky as it forces you to start from the beginning. Yes, a 50 hour linear game repeats with some GRADE modifiers. This is not the Witcher where your choice determines different outcomes.

Conclusion, you can play Tales of Symphonia. However, it's very old and all the nitty gritty tiny things that you take for granted in newer games are not there, like free camera rotation. It's not a smooth experience. Play TOS for nostalgia. 

Note: TOS' total worldwide sales across its original platforms have reached 1.6 million as of 2008, making it the best-selling Tales title to date. The game designer is Kosuke Fujishima.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Interesting Mechanics
Like the dragon rider and dragon. Flying dragon was eh. Trap Faker was nice. 

2. Makes you Appreciate 20 years of Gaming Tech Improvement
Such crappy controls and graphics. See how we have improved over the decades.

3. Puzzles
I love the level design. Not for the irritating bits but for the trickiness. It makes you think one way and then ta da, it's another. E.g. Sewers, the Energy Lines, the Temple of Darkness.

4. Funny Designs
I like the weird designs like the Iris Boxer (Irish Boxer). It's so punny. The Gravekeeper is nice too. I like how the hand just grabs you and pulls you into the casket.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Roaming Creatures Give Random Monsters
If you see a bird, you get a phoenix and scorpions. If you see a grub, you get scorpions. If you see a blob, you can get a thief. The roaming creature model does not match what you fight. You get a flower, you get 2 ogres. WTF

2. Can't Move Around the Battlefield
Yes, you are stuck on a linear path with 1 enemy. You can't maneuver around to its back.

3. Reaction Times Are Slowed
Model turn speed is set really low.

4. The City Size Does Not Match Its Model
Big zone but tiny city model.

5. Can't Control Camera Rotate
Can't control the camera. It just rotates on its own.

6. Surprisingly Confusing Skill Tech Build
You can't just plug and play Tech. It feels like a Street Fighter Game rather than a RPG.

7. Repeating Models
2 giant caterpillars, 1 green 1 yellow. 2 ladybugs, 1 red 1 orange. I know it's hard to do multiple models but just having 1 repeat simply due to a colour change is off-putting.

8. Mini Games Are Weirdly Placed
On the bridge in Teathella, you have a lone Kat playing Red Light Green Light. Why?

9. Wasted Quartz
90% of the bosses don't have a weakness to an element. What's the point of using Quartz?

10. Cooking is Lacklustre
Battle over? Press J, Cook, heal and level up cooking. No difference from drinking potion. 

11. No Quick Jump
Yes, who would have thought that this is so important?

12. No Main Quest Markers
Yes, having to guess certain parts of the story is really tedious.

[h1][b]NEUTRAL[/b][/h1]
1. 4 Rheairds
No need for 4. 1 is good enough.

54743595.review:
This review is 98 percent spoiler free.

First played this game on the Gamecube release when it was fairly new. I still haven't played another Tales game. But this is a game that I will certainly return to over and over again. It's far from perfect, so let me list the downsides first. The overworld mechanics are a bit jank, leveling is too easy in the main game for veteran JRPG players, and the quests all start to feel a bit samey by last quarter of the game. The port from controller to keyboard is playable, but not great. And lastly, while many of the English voice actors kill their parts, others fall short to the point of some dialogue being a bit cringey.

But I don't want to downplay the immense strengths that this game has. Some parts have aged poorly, but the polished parts of this game may shine even brighter than they did in the last generations of gaming. This game still has much to offer as we reach the 2020's. 

Firstly, the combat system is very smooth and somewhat depthy. At first glance and even for an entire first playthrough, the combat may seem repetitive and button-mashy. A first time player can definitely complete the main game without too much haggling with or practice of the combat system. But the rewards of learning the proper mechanics are big. The game rewards players with clean combat mechanics GRADE points which among other things can be used to purchase in-game items. GRADE can be saved and accumulated to provide perks for repeat playthroughs. Each character has a unique battle style, and your friends can play multiplayer with you by controlling one of the members of your party. The weapon system is essentially as basic as it gets - as you get stronger and go to places with higher level enemies you find better weapons for members of your party. Weapons don't have a modification system per se, but lower tier weapons can be combined with crafting items to create higher level weapons. Leveling is straightforward and easy, you can't ever run out of enemies to battle and while in some places it may be necessary to grind levels, in general I rarely had to farm experience. For the the average RPGer, this game probably won't be the biggest challenge.

As far as other mechanics, the item system is easy to learn and straight forward. RPG veterans will pick it up without thinking about it much and new players to the genre will find the learning curve gentle. Simplicity isn't bad, but the whole "the next city in the story will have a shop with better items" formula is definitely dated and may feel jarring to those accustomed to the large-scale open-world games out today. Symphonia is most definitely an open-world game, but it takes a good amount of time to be able to freely explore the world as you please.

The world-building and story progression happen at excellent paces. The game lays a fairly linear path for the first half of the game, then lets the player run wild over the world maps for the second half. While the overworld itself has some mechanical issues the maps each feel like unique worlds. As said above some of the dialogue isn't the greatest, but the overarching main story and the underlying individual character stories are mostly excellent. The themes vary from light and comedic to grim and violent. While the darkest pieces of the story are insinuated, adult players will see the many shades of grey this story takes, most especially in the second half of the story. In some stories the player or reader is given much more information than the characters in the story are given. But in Tales Of Symphonia the player mostly learns information at the same time the characters themselves do. This helps the story feel personal and like you are effecting change in the game. The blend between fantasy and sci-fi is introduced elegantly and far better than any other attempt at such a crossover I've seen. The world does change as you play, sometimes abrubtly and drastically, sometimes subtly. Many NPCs have different things to say at different points in the game. The setting changes drastically many times in the game but in ways that make sense to the story.

Graphically this game isn't a powerhouse and it wasn't intended to be. It's the first 3D title this developer ever made, I believe. But the style is bright and charismatic. The 2D cutscenes are fairly few and far between but are absolutely beautiful, just watching the intro cutscene before the start menu is impressive. Symphonia enemies have awesome character models and are wildly different types of creatures from start to finish. Enemies have unique looks and styles. Each city and village also has its own style and all feel separate from each other. The art style is very colorful and pleasing to look at. I particularly love the artstyle of one late-game area.

Lastly, the soundtrack. While not showered in the accolades that Final Fantasy, Zelda, Elder Scrolls, and other RPGs receive for their soundtracks, this is a supremely outstanding soundtrack. There's 4 entire hours of themes and songs in this soundtrack. The music always sets the tone of the setting well. The character themes are simply excellent and do well to capture the personalities of each character. Even though lots of different instruments and styles of music are used at different times, the soundtrack sounds like one cohesive whole when played standalone. One piece I love from the soundtrack is this one: https://youtu.be/o_PCgbplpj4?t=3885

I'll end this already-too-long review quickly. Tales Of Symphonia impacted me a lot when I was growing up, and it impacted me again when I replayed it last year. I'm about to dive into another playthrough, and I know there will be details I hadn't noticed before in the many times I've completed it. I love this game, even with its age and its minor flaws. It would be a shame to miss out on this one.

I would not have paid money for this game; luckily I got it free on Steam with the purchase of a good Tales game (I think it was Zestiria). Fortunately, I believe few would seize on this offering if they hadn’t experienced all the inanity of the original. I can’t hate; I’m a sucker for nostalgic gaming, even when it was obvious at the time that it wasn’t all it was cracked up to be. 15 years later, this game is a museum exhibit, and mostly appeals to gamers of a certain age.

The port is whack, but Kalaiden’s fix works well. It looks passable for a GameCube port to PS3 port to Windows port. The plot is straight garbage, yet there are equally terrible games that I would pay real money for, even a ridiculous low-quality, back alley hooker port like this. 

The people who dug this game originally should give suitable thanks, and I’ve given it a thumbs up here because I admire the big brass balls it takes to dump this mediocre game on the universe of nostalgic Tales hippies with such a tragically abysmal port. 

Highly recommended.

Los retos en los calabozos son buenos, las batallas de jefes son divertidas y tienes que jugar de forma inteligente o morirás más de una vez; además las batallas de campo abierto igual te obligan a andar con cuidado porque de un momento a otro la dificultad se pude disparar abruptamente.
Lo mejor son los personajes, sus motivaciones y resoluciones; ese es el mejor motivo de entre una gran variedad de grandes motivos para comprar este juego.

54167642.review:
The Good:

+++++Story
+++Characters

The meh:

Combat system

Starts challenging in the beginning gets really tedious not long after that and devolves into button mashing. Raising difficulty only increases enemy hp which only prolongs the unskippable fights with countless mobs waay below your level.

The bad:

-unskippable cutscenes, fights, stuff

---music, graphics

its an old game limited by technicality of the times

------overworld exploration

Extremly tedious with a lot of backtracking and poor camera movement. Especially on the car-boat thing were you need to move....then if you want to turn you need to stop...sloowly turn...then you can move again.....

--------------title grinding

give up without guide, titles are earned through gimmicy stuff like "talk to all the dogs in game as Colette" if you miss one dog good luck in new game+

the ugly:


---------------------------------Fucking puzzles

The most boring, tedious, artifically prolonged puzzles ive ever seen in rpg game.Go 10 rooms, fight 10 enemies. flip a switch. backtrack. fight 10 enemies again. flip a switch. go back fight 10 enemies flip the first switch off. go to another room. flip a switch. backtrack. rinse and repeat. 

finishing some dungeons take literally hours because of that. and that's me playing with a guide telling me exactly what to flip in what order so that i dont have to waste my time through trial and error. And there are also gimmicky in puzzle mechanics like extremly slow moving platforms you have to get on, or dark rooms that you need to illuminate every 2 seconds else you fall and be teleported to the beginning of dungeon(yeah dungeon, not dark room).

oh and you can't just save any time you want in a puzzle dungeon, you have to save of course only in savepoint. but to activate a save point so that you can save the game you need a memory gem. which is randomly dropped by some enemy in the dungeon. if you are unlucky then yeah gl saving the game. 



if i knew what im getting into id not get into it in the first place. everyone was praising the story of the game, correctly, but no one mentioned the crappy dungeons and overworld which are the most dated and boring and stressful parts of the game.

54138775.review: Tales of Symphonia is worth the time investment. Clocking in at at least 40 hours of play time, it can get sluggish at several points through the story. That being said, the instances where the story is firing on all cylinders, it has an undeniably fun groove to it. The protagonist is likable. Some of the supporting cast are great and some of them are pretty annoying. The combat has a lot of depth to it, allowing for a bit of experimentation. I would encourage trying out all of the different party members and getting familiar with how the combat systems function, as the game has a lot of battle in it, and some of the fights can be really challenging. All in all, I'd recommend the game, though it isn't without its fair share of issues. Mostly as a result of the game being nearly 20 years old.
