52629144.review:
I love this game, a bit of that maybe nostalgia, as I played through years ago on the gamecube, but here we go...

The graphics are actually alright even considering it's age. The style makes it hold up pretty well.

The sound is used well to create mood for certain areas, but it is similar to fantasy rpg music of it's era.

The gameplay, including the menu and UI, does not mesh well with keyboard, but plug an xbox controller in and you'll be good to go. It is fun, but depending on how much you grind to overlevel, or avoid fighting, really makes the difficulty. Grind a lot, it's easy, grind less, it's harder. In summary though, the gameplay is action based, and is quite fun when you figure out the combo mechanics. Add in that you get a list of allies to experiment with, and can play local co-op with friends, and it's top notch.

The story, and characters are where the game shines. Running jokes, albeit simple ones, the characters and the way they evolve, it's all just done extremely well.

If you are the type of person to get immersed in the story of a world, I would definitely say this would be the game for you.

As a final note, this is probably one of my personal top 10 games of all time.

52620139.review:
First I'll get to the goods and the bads.

Goods: 
   -Good story.
   -Nice balance in the difficulty settings; you can make the game easy or hard enough for you. 
   -Great mechanics and battle system.
   -Charming visuals if you're into cell-shading.
   -Replayability and post-game are quite extensive.
   -Hours of gameplay, tons of them.
   -Incredible soundtrack.
Bads:
   -Sometimes it's easy to break; making you reload saves that might be far away.
   -Not all the mechanics and items are as easy to pick up as someone might expect.
   -Quite a bad port, textures aren't great and framerate is capped, problems with V-Sync. Granted, it's an old game, but still not a good port.
   -Maybe a bit on the lenghty side without guides.

So, now, with my opinions. 

This is the game of my childhood, so I'm extremely biased. I loved it, every single time I played it, and ended up completing it 15 times on the GameCube, 3 of them being 100% which is quite challenging. Characters are great, they are constantly evolving in what in my opinion is a great story line. The visuals were nice back in the day, although now a bit of an overhaul is absolutely needed (There are texture packs for the game if you so desire). The soundtrack is incredible, maybe a bit too synth-y, but absolutely a masterpiece. I ended up spending about 2k hours on the game on the gamecube alone and I'm absolutely going to spend at least 200 more now that I have it on Steam. 
It's a classic. One of the best JRPG's that we've ever seen in my opinion.

51938259.review:
Tales of symphonia es un juego buenísimo, pero hay que tener en cuenta que es antiguo, de 2003. El aspecto visual se puede disfrutar, pero no esperes una obra maestra. Además, está lockeado a 30fps, así que si no puedes soportarlo no es tu juego. Es recomendable jugar en mando por comodidad, aunque en teclado se puede pasar bien igualmente.

Como todos los tales of, es un juego que evoca emociones y, mediante una increíble historia, te hace reflexionar sobre temas profundos. Empieza lento pero luego se pone muy interesante, y hay muchos giros inesperados, dolorosos y una trama extremadamente buena, muchísimo más compleja de lo que parece en un principio.

El sistema de combate es divertido y puedes usar a 9 personajes distintos, por lo que nunca acaba cansando. Es fácil jugar, pero difícil hacerlo bien manejando tácticas y dando órdenes a los personajes. Tiene un sistema de combate en tiempo real en el que te puedes mover en línea recta hacia el enemigo que has fijado en una zona que sí es 3D. La dificultad es bastante elevada, pero en novato puede pasarlo cualquiera. En general no hace falta farmear experiencia ni dinero excepto para alguna misión secundaria.

En definitiva, si te gustan los JRPGs, historias que te invitan a pensar y te hacen sentir emociones y no te dan miedo unos gráficos buenos pero de hace años, cómpralo. Vale la pena.

51283638.review:
I'm relatively new to the series, as my first experience was Tales of Vesperia. After that game I set my eyes out on Symphonia and eventually tried it out. The battle system is different and a bit more challenging, since there's no free run in this game. However it makes jumping useful, adding a layer of strategy to it. At the end of the game my party was just under level 75. It was a lot more grind heavy than I expected, as the EXP gained is much less than Vesperia's. This was my first playthrough though, so I haven't done NG+ yet to make things a lot easier. Some of the dungeons are a tad too short in my opinion, specifically the early game dungeons. However I do like that the Sorcerer's Ring in this game got a lot more functionality, and the dungeons take advantage of it instead of just stunning enemies. This made some of the puzzles more interesting. The story was pretty good, albeit kind of predictable, though it dealt with more serious topics which I liked a lot. The main cast was really likable and well-integrated into the story. 

This game is too good to pass up on Steam so it's well worth the 20 bucks for 60-70+ hours of content. Despite this game not meeting the minimum requirements for my PC it still ran pretty smoothly.

I wish it ran at 60fps instead of 30 fps with INSANE amounts of stutter. Yes you can use an online fix and bump up the fps to 40. but the game doesn't feel right as it is running 33% faster. I can't recommend this to anyone, even a fan. Buy the Gamecube one and play that on the Dolphin emulator. You're not missing out on much here anyways.

50075826.review:
I received this game for free as part of the Tales of Zestiria pre-order rewards, and only got around to playing it recently.

I love the Tales of series, and I heard so many positive things about Tales of Symphonia, but I never got to play it because I did not own a GameCube. I tried to keep my expectations in check going into this game, just so I would not end up disappointed, and I sure as hell wasn't!

The battle system in ToS is pretty basic compared to more recent Tales of games, but its simplicity is what makes it good. I guess the only compliment I can pay it is that after 40+ hours of gameplay, I made it to the final dungeon and I did NOT try to avoid any battles.
The best thing about ToS has to be the characters, which are VERY well fleshed out throughout the journey, due in no small part to the fantastic skits. The interactions between the party members were very well done, and the skits helped provide an insight into the party members' different personalities and their perspectives on various events and characters. 

The plot was pretty solid and there were quite a few major twists that I did not see coming. Fair warning: ToS's dialogue can be extremely cheesy at times. But the aforementioned pros made it easier for me to digest.

I definitely missed out on some sidequests, but I'm sure completionists can manage to squeeze 60+ hours out of this game.

Thank you, Bandai Namco for bringing ToS to Steam. Now please port the rest of the Tales of series to PC!

50057811.review:
This is the first time I actually play this game. I started my infatuation to Tales series with Tales of Destiny, but never got to lay it because I couldn't afford a GC. To be honest, after playing the more modern Tales games, I have to admit I needed some time re-adjusting to the older linear motion battle system, especially since this game's LiMBS does not have movement freedom, and battle actually runs at a 2.5D plane.
Still, this game has its charm. I kinda understand why fans of the series love this particular title. I like the characters and the flow of the story. Even though I haven't finished it, I have to say that this game has the best story among all other Tales games (Okay, Abyss also has a great story). 
Execution-wise, this port is all over the place. Not that it is BAD, bad, but I would STRONGLY suggest you install Kaldaien's mod.
I have no trouble recommending this game, but do note, this is an old game, needs some time to getting used to, especially if you come from more modern Tales titles.

49865729.review:
While everyone else is busy dismantling the PC port

I enjoyed this game through and through.

The story might be rough in the beginning, but for it's time it takes a trope and turns it on it's head so hard it puts other games that use similar excuses for storytelling in games and puts them to shame.

While it's dated and has mechanical flaws that are better or just different in the titles that follow, it does a lot to improve on the issues and complaints many people might have when getting into the JRPG scene. Party Shared EXP, no Random Encounters (Opting for a more Legend of Zelda 2 style of encounter, but actually done right) and minimalizing the management to a more workable level, great for newcomers to the genre. It focuses on realtime action battles, story, and characters that will grow on you by the very moment you surpass 20 odd minutes of gameplay.

This has been my gateway into becoming the first tales game I ever played, and beat, the 2nd JRPG I've beaten, and has ignited a fire inside me to go seek out more tales games in the series.


-----My Port Rant----- 

The port only runs at 30fps.. but it never strayed for me.. 720P? even at 2k @27in I never felt that to really harm my immersion in the game (The world traversal being dated does that more then the graphics and port) 

I'd rather stick to the graphics I have as mods don't do a whole lot and seem to create more issues then they fix.

Between sound issues and translation issues.. I must be blind and deaf.. because it only took up maybe 2hr of my entire gameplay in seperate bite sized pieces worth of minor issues.. 2hr/100hrs plus (less then maybe 2% of my gameplay had issues only seeing 3 minor sound issues that really wasn't a deal breaker for me)

suriously this isn't Saints Row fuckin' 2 people.. just because the port isn't the Mona Lisa by Leonardo da Vinci doesn't mean it's terrible and should be disreguarded as trash. I know these PC master race guys wanna believe that everything has to be perfection or it's unholy rubbish. But in it's current state, I enjoyed it.

All issues could be fixed by simply alt-tabbing, waiting a moment or just having patience.. the game it's self requires that form the player so if you can't breath a little already the game might not be for you.




--------





on a side note, if I had to complain about anything.. it's that this and Abyss don't have English voiced skits and at least this title has odd times where it chooses to voice something vs not.. it'll choose an oddly unimportant scene to voice fully, and then a scene where you're talking to someone of power or government, someone pretty freakin' big.. and they aren't voiced in any language.

And the graphical art style and repetitive music that can get corny or a little too silly for my taste here kinda clash with the dark tones of the story going on here. I'm excited to see Abyss's art direction looks more up my alley. 

But you can write this off by saying it's the first 3D game in the series and cemented it as a classic to build off of.. ~~unlike many games that opted into 3D and fell on their face...~~

49742688.review: I am a huge fan of the Tales series. My first experience with the Tales series was actually this game's sequel Tales of Symphonia: Dawn of the New World for wii (which I adored as a child, but I completely understand why a lot of people don't really care for it) so when I found out that the first game was on Gamecube I was ecstatic. I picked it up and originally played through to completion on the Gamecube and instantly fell in love. The characters, the story, the combat, the soundtrack, and everything else about this game was amazing. As this title came to PC I had to play through it again and everything is beautifully transferred over onto the PC platform. The music is clear and the combat isn't clunky or choppy, it's just as smooth as ever. This JRPG is a gem of its genre and anyone that is a fan of RPGs or JRPGs must have this game in their arsenal. The only problem I could find for the PC port is that I ran into occasional typos within the dialogue which included a missing space in between words or a misspelled word by one or two letters. Overall nothing major. If you are on the fence about buying ToS then I would recommend waiting for a sale, otherwise it is completely worth the original price. I personally would give this game a 8.5/10.

TLDR: Can run it on a skeleton and it's enjoyable. Just need to get past the story.

SYSTEM: A low power Celeron Thinkpad. Able to run it at nearly full HD. Not that I think it looks any better over DVD (720). Studders some on "cut scenes" but is completely playable.

STORY: So far is bargain basement garbage. Most of the characters are shallow, typical and light on interest. Example of some dialogue: “There is NO WAY I can continue living in a village that has a treaty with them!” … next toon: “Yah. … “So can you come to the village tomorrow?” I LOLed.

GAME PLAY: Seems simplistic. Run there press A, run over there press A. Fighting is a sequence of spamming A, but there does look to be some potential with it. The movement controls seem to add a little bit of freedom and the targeting system is decent on the controller. But the basic mechanics still seem pretty weak. 

VOICE ACTING: Pretty great! I'm kinda shocked that such a silly story got such good actors. Every time they show up it is worth it. They delivered the above line I quote perfectly. First actor was passionate. Second actor totally nailed the “yah” whatevs.

GRAPHICS: Better than I was expecting on this low graphical machine. An intel HD 3000 would do better than my little laptop that I'm running this on for a review. But the game holds up. Beter than pixal graphics which is a welcome relief.

MUSIC: Changes up but is pretty typical fair for Zelda like RPGs.

47818720.review:
Tales of Symphonia es volver al rpg clásico japonés que casi no se encuentra en la actualidad.

es un juego que está bien si estuviésemos a finales de los 90s o principios del 2000. En la actualidad envejeció mal, es lento y peca de aburrido en más de una ocasión. El recurso fácil del ida y vuelta a nivel argumental para tener que ir y volver cada rato a todos lados es insufrible. Demasiados deus ex machinas y coincidencias argumentales cansan. 
El sistema de pelea y la forma de armar tu grupo, maximizar stats y demases es buena.
Entrenar es aburrido y falta un sistema de grindeo que te empuje a querer hacerlo.
Los quests y demases no justifican para nada querer jugar de nuevo con las ventajitas que te da el new game +. En nivel 70 se termina fácil el juego. Los personajes tienen buen trasfondo y desarrollo. Los gráficos no son la gran cosa.

Aun así lo recomiendo pero solo si te gusta mucho el género J-Rpg. caso contrario, no caigas porque te vas a aburrir rápido.

45674572.review:
I have played a lot of games without enjoying them just to finish the story or fill in a trilogy but this game killed my ambition pretty quick. The fight sequence is pretty choppy and a poor evolution from the original Tales game. Healing in the beginning is non-existent making just a little money grinding a difficult feat. They pit some out of balance mobs at you throughout various sequences of the game. For example snakes that poison you often in an area that gives 20-40 gald per battle. The movement and camera angles are horrid but on par for the time. And there are small glitches and bugs which should have been polished out of a game being ported a decade later.

The story is by far cliche and the characters are developed badly from the beginning and showed no signs of getting better. The Japanese voices made things a little better but only barely. I do appreciate the lack of over-blown conversation but believe that again was just a thing of the time since these days half the game could easily be nothing but conversaion and/or cutscenes. Don't even get me started on the bad walking animations which make everyone looks like their moonwalking everywhere.

Though choppy the battle was fun though unfair. Biggest annnoyance was only the computer could change axis while my biggest compliment was smooth combo to tech transitioning for the most part. Though cliche I was hoping they would deviate from the typical story due to certain characteristics of your party. I wont mention others to avoid spoiling but my favorite character aspect was Lloyd being very savvy and intelligent despite being a typical school drop out character. He can forge ex-sphere runes and disarm bombs, I found him a very useful main character... only to be outclassed by the BS which was Collettes characters.... omg have not disliked a heroine more (not her personally just the way she was written).

Can not thumbs up a game I could not come back to... and believe me, after quitting two times, I really tried to come back to finish it on the third attempt only to be foiled by how flawed thie game was. And for 2003 I would expect a little better.

45364267.review:
Most people are critical of this game's port rather then the game itself. As I only came late into playing this port, I have not really experienced any problems with it and so it was generally fine by me. My problems with the game are with the game itself.

Let's start with the story and characters. The overarching story of the game is delivered slowly. It trickles out like molasses and its delivery slows the further in as you progress. I won't go into specifics with the story except to say it was quite mundane and not all that compelling. It is a fairly typical save the world plot that tries to do plots twists, but they generally fall flat because it simply isn't an interesting world and the characters do not have strong enough personalities to hammer any real drama home. And as exposition slows down between gameplay segments later in the game, it becomes excruciating because the few crumbs you get to push you along in the game just stop coming in fast enough to justify continuing. 

The aforementioned flat characters are not bad per se, but they are not interesting either.  I didn't hate the characters, but I did not love them either. There's nothing memorable about them. None of the characters have intriguing relationships with each other. And none of them experience arcs that are all that compelling either. The whole experience just feels very rote and cliche. It is like every JRPG ever was distilled into one homogenous, uninteresting blob of a game. 

The gameplay, however, is where the game shifts from being just average to being dull and bad. The game relies extremely heavily on padding itself out with lots of traveling, lots of tedious exploration of uninteresting locales, and puzzles. Oh, gods, the puzzles just never ended. I feel like the puzzles had puzzles in this game. The first 1/3rd to 1/2th of the game wasn't so bad. The story beats came fast enough and the dungeons moved quickly enough that it was easy enough to overcome them; however, around those marks, the game just becomes such a grind. Each dungeon got longer and longer. The puzzles became more and more obtuse and vexing. When I thought the latest dungeon was bad and nothing could be worse, another dungeon would show up and prove how wrong I was. The combat is as uninspired and uninteresting as the rest of the game. It just devolves into mindless repetition of the same attacks in similar orders all the time. Just a beat 'em up that's even less compelling because it is a game that never ends. It just goes on and on and on

And the world map? One of the worst implementations of a world map I've ever seen in a game. It is horrifically bad. And whoever designed it should have never went near game design again. And this isn't hyperbole. It's that bad.

I couldn't beat the game because I had to stop. I couldn't stand it any more. I reached a dungeon that broke any desire I had to continue. I was about 80% of the way through the game and I could not do it any more. I really recommend against playing this game.

45064125.review:
Well this is worth my money, time and mabey even my life.
Takes some time to get used to the keybored but if you have a controler your good. Either way this game has some of the best story, gameplay and replayability in any JRPG I have played. The short review is a 9/10 for making me play for over 700 hours.

Pros: Solid 30fps even on an week GPU like mine.
-The game is long even just the story, but not to long.
- English and japanese options.
-Can make over 100 save files, so feel free to save before a boss to fight them again later if you want. (Just be careful not to save or your other saves)
-The story and characters are amazing.
-Soundtrack is amazing
-Story will change in small (or in one rare case, large) ways deppending on your choices .
-Characters gain xp even if they did not participate in the battle. So no one fall behind in level.
-Each character has 2 diffrent paths of what skills/attacks they will learn depending on the ex-gems you use. So you can play the game with diffrent skills and attacks a second time if you wish.
-No level requiremnents for any story component. (so no nessasry grinding)
-No less than 10 titles for each charater to obtain. (titles are like achivements, one can be used at a time per character for a small buff or costume change)
-Costumes for dressing up. (because why not)
-The grade points you get after every battle can be spent on a new-game+ to start over again with buffes or debuffes to change the game. (Including a free mania difficulty for those who want to go through hell)


Cons: No fps options, it's locked at 30
-Graphycs have not aged to well and look a little odd in cutscens. Battles look great though.
-Cutscenes cannot be skiped and there are alot of them, ok the first time but on a second playthrough your just waiting for them to be over.
-Many of the compound unison attacks have audio problems and the voices are hard to hear.
-Early game is tuff with the lack of hp, sp and attacks you have. (You will die alot.)
-Some titles give stats and others give cosmetics but you can't have both at once.
-Many of the temple puzzles are slow or just suck. (Some are good)
-The few sidequest the game has are fun for the most part and have unique bosses and tittles. However these quests and even the 2 best ones (Niflheim and The devil arms) can only be done after opening the door to the final boss chamber and are extreamly easy to overlook. You will need a guide.
-The casino is needed to get... a crappy costumes that glitches and clips (for me at least), a useless item so you can fill your item list, and 1 of the 9 devel arms. 3 shitty items that take either 10min or 10hours of gambling to get.
-Each character has a special tittle that only one of witch be gotten per playthrough. (so to get every tittle you would have to play the game 8 times assumeing you dont miss any of the others) This game is hell on completionists.
-The mystic arts look amazing are a super strong but will almost never be used unless you are trying and going out of your way to pull one off. This makes them unpractical for combat.


I got this on on sale for 10 dollars and god damn it was worth it.

44469739.review:
[b]Disclaimer: I never played this game on any other support before. This is my first experience[/b]

This game is pretty enjoyable. 

Each characters are charismatic in their own way, the musics are nice, the GUI is almost cute by itself. 

Unlike most RPGs (I'm mostly thinking about Final Fantasy), this isn't a turn-by-turn fight. You actually have to move toward your opponents, attack them, combo them, and dodge their attacks. 

The main plot and the different stories you see in the game are treating about interesting real life subjects (I always like games which are more than about "you're the good people, just beat the bad guys", it reminds me of the good old Snes RPGs). 

Although I read that people who already played this game on Game Cube and/or Playstation are extremely disappointed, I find the game to be pretty enjoyable, despite some minor glitches on some points. 

If you already have this game on another support, I suggest you don't buy it since people said it's of a poor quality in comparison. However, if you never played it and can't play it on another support (and you don't want to play it on an emulator/you already played it on an emulator but want to give your money), then you should buy it definitely.

44199296.review:
I first played this game on the GameCube as a little kid, and I found this on the Steam store on sale, so I had to buy it. To be completely honest, I see no issue with some of the things people have complaints with, it has a compelling story (i think), the fight scenes are good, the fight mechanics are pretty decent (especially for an older game), and it is one of my favorite games of all time. There are times when you have played the game too many times that some points get repetitive or boring, but it took me a long time to get to that point. There is also a fairly long story, and if  you play all of the side quests it will easily take anywhere from 50 to 100 hours, but every minute is fun. So overall, I really reccomend this game.

43886584.review:
[h1]Pre-(R)amble[/h1]

It's been a while since I played through a JRPG to completion which I hadn't completed before. I must say there is a lot to like about Tales of Symphonia, but also quite a few niggling details which undermined my appreciation of the game. This is my second Tales game that I've ever played, with Tales of Phantasia being the first, so I'm fairly new to the series, but I like what I see so far.

[h1]Graphics/Art Style[/h1]

Tales of Symphonia was originally a GameCube game, but I think it looks pretty darn good. It has a cartoonish look to it, but the colors are vibrant, the important characters "pop" visually in my opinion, and everything just works pretty well. It's graphically fairly ugly, but quite pretty in terms of art style, which I think makes up for the lack of graphical capabilities at the time the game was originally made. The user interface was very nice for the menus in and out of combat, text was easy to read, and yeah...just quite nice. There are 2D full-on anime cutscenes, but they are [i]extremly[/i] rare. Those look great! Oh, and towns are visually wonderful, in my opinion. No two towns looked similar to me, which is really saying something in a JRPG from more than a decade ago.

[h1]Music\Sound[/h1]

The music in this game is pretty great. I don't normally go for anime songs, but I will confess that I watched the opening music video/intro to this game at least a dozen times and still adore it. I will likely go back sometime in the near future and listen through the whole soundtrack on YouTube.

Voice acting is wonderful here, in my opinion. Although it's disappointing that there are a lot of unvoiced lines, most plot-relevant dialog is generally voice-acted, and I think that the actors they got for each character worked just great. The main protagonist is basically Robin's voice from Teen Titans (yes, it's that voice actor), and I think it works excellently with the character. The characters seemed more cartoonish than like "real people" in regard to their voicing, but given the plot and art design for the characters, I think the voices chosen were a great fit.

[h1]Controls[/h1]

Despite originally being released on console, this game has been brought to PC with customizable controls! Bless their hearts. 10/10 on that front. Everything was very responsive and I'm wholly satisfied concerning ToS' controls.

[h1]Story/Characters[/h1]

Story-wise, I was fairly pleased with ToS. Sadly, it goes the route of having "hope" have actual power at one point, and other such sappy, eye-rolling stuff. However, the majority of the time, the game uses logic and reason, and its characters even go into detail while talking with one another about making rational decisions rather than emotional ones, because the main protagonist means well but is so eager to rush to a solution that he might take dumb risks when a different approach is ideal. He is certainly a highly moral idealist steeped in naivete and good intentions, but he is no "Gary Stu" (a too-perfect character), as his anger and rushing is a clear weakness, and he isn't all that smart.

Darnit, I'm drifting into talking about the characters. I'm having a difficult time resisting! Back on the story first, though, it's pretty good, but a lot of odd lore that isn't focused on long enough to feel fleshed out or make a lot of sense to me was in there, and several parts of the storyline felt like "padding" just to add to the length of the game. I liked quite a bit of the plot, but fair amounts did put me off.

Okay, back to the characters. This is the pinnacle of the game for me: its protagonists and their interactions. There are little dialogs/skits between your characters which you can trigger by pushing a button when prompted (it stays available to press for quite a while). In it, your characters make little anime facial expressions like laughing, pouting, being snarky, etc., and they talk about whatever is in their minds, such as the quest at hand, a piece of lore, or even just slice-of-life stuff like messing with one another or talking about their values. If I had to pick a favorite thing in the game, these dialogs/skits between characters are it. I think more games need dialog like this between its characters to make them feel more like people and less like simply tools for combat.

Moreover, I really liked the characters themselves and they had great dialog and chemistry together. I didn't really like Presea or Regal at all, aside from their usefulness in fights, as they were the least fun to me in the dialogs/skits, and Regal gimps the party's combat efficiency because he's pouty (he literally refuses to use his hands in fights in favor of his feet, out of remorse for something he did, even though he is jeopardizing the fate of every living being in the world by doing so.

The main villain is largely well-written. Of course, the villain inevitably does some rather mustache-twirling cliche evil stuff that cheapened the villain some, but over all, I was really pleased here, because when taking into consideration what the villain has been through, then subtracting almost all morality based on those experiences and a loss of "humanity" over time, a lot of the villain's intentions and goals actually made sense...really messed up and evil sense. No "I want to kill everyone because I'm evil." There are reasons for the killing and the things the villain wants to do, even if it will ruin and/or end lives.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Combat is kinda 2.5D. By that, I mean it's on a 2D axis, but characters can move behind one another and be angled a bit on a Z axis around enemies, etc. It plays very much like Tales of Phantasia, which I found kinda fun. You slash enemies, cast spells (character-dependent), have four characters and can set whomever you like to automatically do certain types of tasks in fights...it works well, for the most part. I will say one gripe: Zelos will not use his tier 2 combat skills (non-spells) automatically, no matter what strategies you set him to. You have to manually instruct him each time you want him to use one, which is pretty invasive. That said, I whooped the game just fine without him using those and he was usually in my combat party.

Boss fights were surprisingly easy for me. Block a bunch, have a bunch of healers in your party, set them to prioritize healing, chip away at the boss' health, and use ridiculously cheap restorative items to refill TP (basically mana/MP). A few were challenging, but that was rare. There are higher difficulties that will make you bleed, supposedly, so no worries if you do want a challenge. I only did grinding a couple of times here and there, and it largely doesn't seem to be needed. Killing every enemy you see at every possible chance (including on the world map) seems like it would do the trick.

Other than padding out the plot, I believe that the game's dungeons were its biggest padding problem. While a few dungeons were just wander-around-and-find-treasure-chests-or-go-to-your-goal, which is A-OK (and preferred by me, like in Chrono Trigger!), the majority of them have puzzles that can take a frustrating amount of time to solve. These added many hours to my play time. I love the Portal games, I had fun with Zelda games back in the day, and lots of other puzzles have delighted me, but these really got under my skin and padded out my play time. I would estimate that a good 8 hours was spent wandering around trying to solve puzzles...probably more, really. I never enjoyed the puzzles and I eventually got so tired of them that I finally just used a walkthrough for every dungeon in the last third of the game. It spoiled some things but was worth it to me as I had gotten very bored.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Almost out of room! Awful and excessive dungeons, a few weak plot points, but everything else was GREAT. I'm glad I played through this one time (doubt I'll touch it again) for $4.99 on sale. Most characters are great. <3

43702538.review:
Story:

Tales of Symphonia for me was an interesting 50+ hour journey. I enjoyed the game from the very beginning and have enjoyed it to the end (except for one section that stressed me out). The story follows Lloyd Irving, a human boy who has been raised by a dwarf for the majority of his life. During his time at school, he would also meet Genis Sage, an elf and is the smart one of the trio, and Colette Brunel, a clumsy girl, and is also the current Chosen of Regeneration, who would go on an adventure to regenerate the world (which is basically saving the world). Along the way, you'll meet more allies along the way, each one being unique in their own ways, like their specialties and many other aspects, which you'll learn as you progress through the game.

Gameplay:

When you're in combat against the monsters of the game, you'll be in a 3D field. However, when locking into an enemy, you'll only have 2D movement, so you can only move left and right (away and towards the enemy). During combat, you can do the following things:

-Attack: Be able to do a simple combo attack (which can range from 3 to 6 hits max)
-Guard: Block most physical attacks (besides magic attacks)
-Techs: Moves that use up TP to allow you to use powerful attacks, magic and defensive moves
-Menu: Allows you to pause combat to equip items, use items, change formations, change tech bindings or choose techs for your allies to use and to escape combat (besides boss battles)

Outside of combat, you will be in an open-world environment, where you can encounter enemies and travel to different towns, dungeons and other locations across Sylvarant, where you can go to towns to stock up on items and weapons, sleep in inns to restore your HP and TP (for a price, of course) and sometimes, for plot reasons. 

Pros and Cons:

Pros:

+Simple to learn, but hard to master combat system
+Unique and interesting cast of characters that are memorable, each one having a deep story
+Good soundtrack, especially in boss battles
+Lots of locations that can offer you many things to do

Cons:

-Restriction to only 30 fps
-Movement on keyboard can be cumbersome in 3D Environment
-Unable to change key binding to other keys
-No markers on where to go next, which can leave new players confused
-No way of knowing about things like Side Quests and progress on them

Conclusion:

In the end of my first playthrough of the game, I loved the game to bits. I had some issues here and there sometimes, but I was able to overcome them in the end (sometimes by looking through a guide). I still remember the characters, even after weeks after playing it, showing how well the characters were handled and how invested one can be on the main cast, even the Antagonists as well.

I do see that a lot of people do recommend that you should try the GameCube version, but I will say that just choose which version you want to play and well, just play that version. 

I hope that this review will help people choose to either buy the game and invest themselves in a possible 50-60+ hour game, or to avoid it, and possibly play the more recent Tales of games, like Berseria and in the future, Tales of Vesperia, which is coming out at some point this year (if I got that correct).

43436909.review:
Muy buenas gente!

Vamos un tanto al grano, este grandioso juego de JRPG es una de las maravillas que he jugado, no lo hacía desde que tengo la versión de GameCube. Es una verdadera joya, eso si, le tendrás que invertir horas y horas para descubrir sus secretos si quieres terminarlo al 100%

Una cosa es clara, la paciencia es la que necesitarás para jugar, las primeras 10 horas de juego son un deleite, la historia está muy bien estructurada, no tiene pierde a la hora de jugarlo, personajes con carisma, seriedad e humor, en este apartado nada que reprocharle, es un juego que está a la altura de un Final Fantasy o incluso podría estar a la par de Chrono Trigger, lo cuál es mucho decir. El juego te entretiene bastante, como ya he dicho, lo he jugado teniendo la GameCube que a mi parecer es una de las mejores versiones aparte de que el intro de la canción en esta versión, es la japonesa, una pena que no incluyan la del GameCube, pues va más acorde pero cada quien supongo.

El sistema de combate es excelente, puedes manejarlo de manera manual, semi autómatico o automático e incluso puede jugar con un compañero, obviamente cada uno con su control, jugar con el teclado no lo recomiendo para nada, es complejo jugar con teclado y mouse, en el juego ya te van diciendo como es el sistema de combate y de qué maneras vas desbloqueando habilidades.

Ahora bien, este juego cuenta con demasiados secretos e incluso misiones opcionales que no son para nada aburridos, es más es un plus para dar descanso a la trama principal, ya que te dan beneficios, uno de los apartados es que al principio del juego puedes seguir la trama de los primeros sellos (calabozos) en el orden que quieras a partir del segundo sello, esto no altera para nada la trama al contrario, te beneficia.

Puntos en contra, la traducción al español de españa para los subtitulos, es un asco, no corresponde a lo que están diciendo salvo que una que otra ocasión si lo hace pero si, es un asco la traducción que se hace en este apartado.

Los gráficos podrían no ser los mejores dadao que es un juego que salió hace mucho y este es un port directo de la versión de PlayStation por lo que el intro suena con la música japonesa, lo cuál no está nada mal pero la versión de GameCube quedaba mejor.

Este punto es dudoso pero tengo que mencionar la cámara cuando vas explorando al mundo abierto, si no mal recuerdo, la camara no me daba tantos problemas en GameCube, extrañamente en esta versión si le encuentro un fallo, no la siento tan igual como en la versión del cubo pero como dije, es dudoso porque no me acuerdo bien.

Salvo por esos dos puntos en contra, todo lo demás, música, combates, personajes memorables, escenario abierto, objetos por encontrar y varias misiones opcionales, es un juego que te va a entretener por horas y horas, pero le tienes que invertir, no es un JRPG que acabes en una semana a no ser que de verdad tengas mucho tiempo libre, la historia es un verdadero deleite. Sin embargo, sugiero comprar este juego en épocas de rebajas, ya que, a pesar de ser una gran joya, su precio es poquito caro.

En fin, si lo vas comprar, disfruta el juego, explora y diviertete.

43361149.review:
If there was ever a game that was marred by being too close to its original release, this would be it.  Dont get me wrong, the game is good, but it isnt any better than its Gamecube release.  There is higher resolutions and some small graphics options, but the game still looks very similar to the original release. 
The game itself was brilliant for its time.  JRPG game, but in a beat 'em-up action format.  This game helped push the popularity of Cel Shaded graphics along with LOZ: Wind Waker and Viewtiful Joe.

TOS is an action JRPG.  It is a blend of Cell shaded and 3d graphics.  The story is about yourself and a few loyal friends that have to travel to take the Chosen to her Destination so she can perform a ritual to save the world from the forces of evil.  The story is good, but it does meander at times.  Some twists and turns are pretty far-fetched, but hey, JRPG. 

Combat is done in side scrolling format.  Somewhat like the brawlers of old - Streets of Rage and Double Dragon.  There is a combination of button mashing and special actions when engaging the enemy.  There are different armour and weapons you can aquire through battles or quests. The weapons asthetics change, but the look of your character is the look of your character.  The character progression is good, but not really that deep.  

Overall Conclusion - If you loved playing TOS the first time, this should bring back those warm memories of the PS2 or Gamecube.  Without the glow of nostalgia, this game really doesnt shine that bright.  

I still recommend it due to it being a faithful recreation, but for new players, there are much better JRPG's to sink your time into. 

6.5/10

43070706.review:
"Me despido de mi sombra, de aquel que aguarda al final del camino que elegí no seguir"

Tales of Symphonia nos narra la  historia de las moribundas tierras de  Sylvarant y su lucha por el maná que da la vida a todos los seres, y en como cada cierto tiempo al perderse el maná  aparecen más enemigos que asolan la tierra y la vida se vuelve difícil, por ello es enviada una persona elegida para que con su peregrinación el mundo y el maná sean regenerados.

Como premisa básica ToS es un juego que en sus primeras horas parecerá una trama cliché, pero de forma extraordinaria sabe cambiar de rumbo en el momento adecuado y hacerse impredecible, haciendo que de un momento a otro te sientas enganchado en la trama, no tengo que mencionar que la trama como tal está muy bien construida y argumentalmente todos los personajes que se ven tienen un peso y valor siendo no solamente "decorados", aclaro que para quien guste de este tipo de tramas, también tiene un trasfondo filosófico como conceptos como la igualdad y demás, es una trama extensa así que prepara unas palomitas y tírate unos días pasando esta joya...

Mecánicamente hay poco que pueda hablar siendo muy técnico pues mi experiencia con juegos del genero JRPG y similares tales como Zelda es poca, sin embargo he escuchado muchas comparativas al momento de hablar de mazmorras, algunos combates y demás... pues así hablaré desde mi punto de vista.
Destaco enormemente el sistema de combate y puzzles pues son los que más resaltan al momento de jugar, el combate es un sistema similar a un hack n slash pero un tanto más automatizado, y el sistema de puzzles funciona de manera similar que en otros juegos, apelando más a la exploración,  si bien gran parte de estos se llevan a cabo como ya he dicho en mazmorras su elaboración es magistral dando paso a que mecánicamente todos estos elementos congenian bien, 

En relación al port, tengo poco que hablar, tuve algunos problemas de fps al principio pero al mover ajustes de tarjeta gráfica el juego iba a 60 fps estables, sin embargo es un juego que visualmente ha envejecido un tanto mal no de forma total pues algunos detalles como los personajes están muy pulidos mientras que el mapa y otros entornos están muy pobremente terminados (Siempre entendiendo que estaba sujeto a la sexta generación y sus limitantes) aunque es un detalle que en horas de juego pasa desapercibido, por lo que a lo demás respecta el juego tiene gráficos propios de su generación y que con su toque anime da buen aspecto.

En relación a la banda sonora o efectos de sonido, resalto que el juego tiene música en casi cualquier momento y está muy bien  colocada, desde música de aspecto medieval hasta completas "sinfonías", por no hablar de que siempre tiene ese toque oriental en sus melodías, para mayor resumen el tema de Land of Sylvarant: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uFwsQ50Au4k 
Que te acompañará en gran parte de la aventura.

A grandes rasgos es un videojuego de rol japonés el cual es difícil encontrar un fallo pese a su tiempo en el mercado, pues cuenta con grandes virtudes, y por ello es un videojuego que enteramente es recomendable tanto para fans del género y temática así como para nuevos jugadores y experimentadores, prometiendo no solo una cantidad enorme de horas de juego, sino un guion rico en trama y personajes, así como una gran banda sonora.

Precio: ■■■■■■■■■■
Mecánicas/Gameplay ■■■■■■■■■□
Trama: ■■■■■■■■■□
OST/Sonoro: ■■■■■■■■■□
Gráficos: ■■■■■■■□□□

42960541.review:
This is the first "Tales" game I have played, so my review doesn't compare this one to any other titles in the series. In this game you play as a young man named Lloyd who starts the game living in a country village and ends up going on a journey with his friends to attempt to "regenerate" the dying planet. Here is an overview of some notes I took while playing.

PROS:
+ Fun combat system. It's fast paced with free movement. Build combo attacks, counter attack and spend a lot of time blocking,
+ I enjoyed all the cities and villages I encountered. Lots of people to speak to and interact with.
+ The characters are interesting. Lloyd is a fun protagonist to play as because of his youthful immaturity sometimes.
+ The voice overs are good, I just wish there was more of them.
+ The story is not fantastic, but it is solid enough to keep me interested and moving forward. The synopsis of the story and events that you can view in-game is a good feature and I used it a lot.
+ The game can take anywhere between 50-90 hours to beat depending on how much you wish to complete.
+ You can get this game on sale for $5. That is a steal for a game of this quality.

CONS:
- The graphics aren't fantastic but the game was originally made back in 2004 for the Nintendo Gamecube so I didn't punish it too much for that.
- By the end of the game, the combat will feel repetitive. You will start actively trying to avoid some fights, at least I did.
- I had to use a strategy guide a good amount while playing because I did not know where I had to go next. There are two worlds and a lot of locations within them so sometimes I forgot where certain places were located. I kinda wished they would have marked locations on the map better. Maybe I'm just lazy I guess.
- I was disappointed in the small amount of anime cut scenes in the game. I was expecting more than there actually were. There are only about 6 of them and the majority are near the end of the game.

Overall I would rate this game a 7.5 out of 10. It is a fun JRPG with fast paced combat. Pay attention to the story to avoid getting lost and always keep a healer in your party. Also, learn to block early in the game. You will absolutely spam it during boss fights so get used to it.

Es genial poder volver a jugar a un juego que marcó tanto mi infancia.

Es un juego que se plantea de forma muy típica (muy similar a las de Final Fantasy), pero con una trama capaz de dar un giro que lo deja todo patas arriba, dando lugar casi a un juego totalmente nuevo. A pesar del aspecto infantil del juego, la trama se vuelve bastante enresevesada, muy superior a la media de RPG’s de aquella época; y no podemos no mencionar el mensaje secundario de la tolerancia y la no discriminación entre razas, muy presente en todo el juego.

Quizás como pega se podría señalar que la trama en ocasiones se hace algo densa y se desarrolla de forma lenta, con demasiadas mazmorras entre medias, pero no por ello el juego empeora.

En cuanto a jugabilidad, ya veríamos algo parecido en la saga Tales con juegos como Tales Of Eternia, pero siempre es algo bastante sencillo e intuitivo; y en cuanto a los gráficos... bueno, personalmente, a mí me enamora esa estética manga/manhwa, y las animaciones estilo anime que hay en el juego son también estupendas.

En definitiva, un juego bastante entretenido y con una trama muy buena, capaz de engancharte fácilmente y hacer que le eches unas cuantas horitas.

42555201.review:
The game which introduced me to the amazing Tales series, this remains one of my favorites both in the series and overall.

Gameplay: 8/10 Solid, with no glaring problems but nothing truly innovative. Fun and intuitive without being shallow. Any game with no frustrating or damaging glitches - or features - earns an above average score from me, due to the high number of games which fail to meet even that low standard. This goes a bit beyond that to remain engaging throughout the playthrough.

Story: 8/10 It looks to be incredibly cliche at the start of the game, but after a few hours you'll notice it beginning to slowly veer away in another direction. Without giving anything away, there are definitely cliche components to it throughout, but the way they are strung together and the way it's handled makes this a great experience. A few genuinely unexpected plot twists certainly help keep things fresh and interesting. It's not a dark story by any means, even if there are a few things which could get really dark if you think about them too much, but it also isn't a sugery-sweet frolic through a meadow. The ultimate theme seems to be racism, but it's glossed over to keep things light and shouldn't be approached with intellectual expectations. Feels primarily like a high-fantasy adventure.

Characters: 6/10 It pains me to give them such a low rating because I like them so much, but they really aren't unique in any way in terms of writing quality. A bit cliche at times, but it's no worse than the standard fare for the genre and better than many games I've played. Doing lots of sidequests will flesh out their personalities nicely, but most of the characters aren't especially deep. There is definitely some character development however, so don't expect them to remain static.

Music: 6.5/10 Lots of distinct tracks which work well in context, but very few pieces which are fun to listen to in their own right. Raine's, Kratos' and Mithos' themes are notable for their quality and/or versatility in use.

Graphics: 6/10 The effects work well with each other, but they're outdated graphics by now and they're too cartoony to hold up over time. They weren't anything special upon release either. Not awful but certainly not up to par anymore.

Length: 8/10 The shortest playthrough I've ever done was 36 hours, and that was with a walkthrough to help me maximize my efficiency. The game feels neither too short nor too long, though the Boring RPG Intro Segment could certainly use some trimming to help it hit its stride earlier. Intro Section lasts 2-3 hours before getting into the real meat of the game.

Overall: 7/10 Enjoyable, engaging, pretty enough for its age, but not the best entry in the series. An excellent choice if you're new to JRPGs.

42216884.review:
So the description for this game on it's Steam page is a little misleading. It claims that this is based off of the PS3 port of the gamecube version. That's only mostly true. It *is* the PC port of the PS3 version, but the PS3 version was based off of the PS2 port of the Gamecube version. So that means that while it has all the extra little goodies that the PS2 version had (some minor additions like some sidequests, costumes, somewhat updated secret dungeon, etc), it has a downgraded visual fidelity (battles run at 30fps instead of the Gamecube version's 60, cel-shading isn't as good, textures are a bit rougher, etc) and it lacks local co-op (where up to four players could play during the battle scenes, one player controling one of the active party members).

Still, it's a (mostly) good port - it works and doesn't have any major problems.

41560450.review:
This game.. wow i mean really WOW!! Tales series are the best for a reason.

TL;DR;
Grapicshly outdated and not flawless port, there are few glitch here and there but overall it has a freaking awsome story and the game is loooooong minimum 30-40 hours guranteed and if you like take your time like i did ending up with 53.4h gameplay hours.

And now let the longer review begin:
Keep in mind i write these stuff as they get in my mind.. im lazy to sort them in sections sorry.

The game is old but old doesnt mean thrash. I would say old but gold. The grapics is outdated compared to Tales of Berseria and it doesnt feel like an anime-ish because the characters more like small characters so i would say chibi-ish but it's cute. Voice actors are nice but some text doesnt have voice acting (like random NPC's in towns but the story is 100% VA'ed)

The story is good, it starts intresting but it gets really really repeative after making the 4-5th pact with the spirits. There is a little cutscene what to do and you have a little diary which sums up the story what happend so far so if you read it thru you can get a small hint where you need to go but otherwise you will spend a LOT of time by searching where to go next so take my advice and download the world's map from the web so you will know exactly where is the town you seek for.

Characters are well worked. The tales series stronges point beside the great story is the character design imo and i loved them all in the anime. Sheena is the best waifu for me from the series and Colette was cute tho. The humor is there, the characters like to make fun of each others back and forth durring their adventure which is always nice. You can read/watch the funny skits for it.

The music is not that good but not that bad..average altho i liked some of the tracks.

Big cons was for me the clunky movement around the world. My character was keep stucking in everything!! If you moved too close to the wall you got stuck to it and you had to move backward to unstuck yourself which was frustrating as hell especially navigating in small place dungeons or corridors. Also big cons was what i mentioned above the game doesnt give clear information where to go what to do and the game is freaking long so even if i use google or watch walkthru i was not sure if i already did something or not (you dont have to do the quests in order to proceed your adventure). Some puzzles was really unnecesary and annoying like the "infinite labrynth mazes" but most of the puzzles felt rewarding.

City design was useless in the game i mean the exploration had zero reward. Some city was unnecessary huge and it was not worth to explore it because you got nothing useful information from the NPC's and you cant collect any items in towns like opening chests or investigating objects there was just 0 interaction in towns beside talking to useless npcs. Every town has a item shop, inn, weapon and armor shop and a special cat expedition shop.

I played the game on normal difficulty i guess and on some point it was really hard. I cant imagine how "hard mode" looks like. My characters was Lv 60-65+ at the end boss and i had to use nearly all of my items from my inventory which was 100% full with all kinds of heals and buffs potions.

There was always a nice twist in the story which kept the game going and when it felt it's going to finnaly end guess what.. it doesnt and it keep happened over and over again. By the end i was like: "Pleeaase game, let me finish you already!!" After i finnaly ended the game lots of questions was unanserwed so i was sad about it but after the credits rolls up it anserwed everything how the characters future will be, one question left unaserwed but google anserwed me that.

Do i recommend this game for you?
- Hell yes! Its worth to beat it one time and it often goes on 75-80% sales.
Would i replay it?
- I don't think so or not anytime soon. maybe after years i'll give another go.
You complain a lot about this game. is it really good?
- As i said it has its cons which can be frustrating but for the story and characters it's really worth the struggle.

For fans i recommend the anime series too but before you watch the show you MUST complete the game because you wont understand the anime's plot and who does something and why does that, where they going and why etc. Game story knowledge is STRONGLY recommended before the show. PS: the show animation is freaking gorgeous!!

Rate: 7.5 out of 10

41462920.review:
One of my first rpgs, my first Tales of, and my most played gamecube game (800+ hours playing through multiple times with my sister when we were kids).

It has its issues, but hey, I'm awash in nostalgia.

The ps2 version (which the ps3 and steam versions are based off) adds more costumes, and a few more skills, sidequests and post-game content. It also removed some fun glitches and exploits. My big negative with this version is that it slaps [b]huge[/b], gaudy subtitles over the [b][i]center[/i][/b] of the victory screen. This occurs regardless of your selected language, and can't be turned off without muting voices entirely. This sucks, and it bugs me more than it should.


If you've never played [i]this[/i] Tales game, and don't mind the dated gameplay, I'd say toss a coin. The story's not bad, but not enough on its own to warrant a purchase.

If you've never played [i]any[/i] Tales game, I'd instead recommend Tales of Abyss (mind the terrible MC for the first 1/3 of the game), or Tales of Graces F. Sadly, neither of these titles are available on Steam. Or Tales of Vesperia, though I've never played it (seriously, bring over an english ps3 version already... Zestria is garbage and Berseria is still a step down I feel).

41344835.review:
Symphonia; any of the medieval musical instruments as the hurdy gurdy. This was what I found when I did a dictionary search as I was wondering how the name was even related to the game. However, a WIKI period article highlighted a theological view which speaks to the theory where Orthodox  Christian theological and political thought are to complement one another by establishing mutual respect with neither institution showing dominance over one another.
I leave that thought with you as I highlight the positives and negatives of this brilliant JRPG especially in light of finding out the meaning of symphonia.

                                                                                         Positives
Characters
Each character positions itself as a prime representation of a symphonian system. Therefore, they really fitted crucial roles while being overall enjoyable with an shounen feel to it. The protagonist is the normative portrayal of what most lovers of the anime shounen genre liked; not too bright but with a fierce position on justice and doing the right thing despite the consequences with of course the downright incredulous personality. With that set, prepare for an amalgation of all different personality types woven together to create a team that gets the job done. Based on when this was made, in the early 2000s, characters were an A plus.

Plot
I have already set you up with an introduction that explains the subtleness and yet brilliance of the creators of this game. It further highlights that each work of art and creative ventures, no matter the format, expresses the thoughts of its creator. The plot was engaging and encompasses a great deal of humanity’s strengths and perils particularly in the area of standing up for what is right with the opposite of the coin being that you add more fuel to the fire instead of achieving the justice you think should have been the outcome. Should you intervene or not? It is an ethical and moral issue that in our day to day lives we pay least attention to however it poses a great necessity in achieving a moral society. Plot is an A

Gameplay for PC
Gameplay was fluid, I encountered little to no difficulty, however it can get a bit repetitive but that is one of the “usual” for JRPGs. The one thing that irked me a bit was that controls weren’t sufficiently explained and for the longest while I had no BLOODY idea how to switch characters in battle and when I did it without knowing after my main control died…let’s just say I was busy watching the battle. Also, what is the purpose of manual control for characters; to allow them to stand and get pummeled? That makes no sense, don’t put an option that won’t work how you intend it to. A minus for gameplay.

Media
Excellent OSTs and voice acting. There was no interruption of lines or talking before subtitles. Furthermore, they used excellent voice actors such as Alucard’s and Robin’s voice actors. I really enjoyed hearing them talk. The only thing I would have wanted is more spoken dialogues, but I’ll take what I can get. A for media.

                                                                                  Negatives
Explanation:
There needs to be a comprehensive translation for whatever games you are putting into production for another language. I struggled a bit with understanding what was the premise of certain instructions and how could I replicate those actions on PC. The training manual, still a bit over my head with combos and other things, maybe it works better for console. Also, what would have been bloody fantastic is to save the combos that we did so that at least I know what I did to get them. Also, it would be good to give some indication of how we could combine, I’ve gotten two out of I don’t even know….  Lastly, certain puzzles are lost in translation and so the difficulty became tenfold that I had to seek online assistance to solve the statues…. Whatever.
   
Glitches
The damn glitches with the blocks in the sewers and minor ones in other places… and the bloody aumm shadow pieces. How on earth was I supposed to know that the save point with allow them to stay one place. I won’t even tell how that frustrating aspect hindered my progress for a while and I knew how to solve it.

Finality/ Climax
I am just a bit meh about the ending, but a suppose it is due to the fact that it is a prelude of what is to come, but I felt as if the climax didn’t come off as strong as it could have. Nonetheless, it was satisfying. 

Final Score : 9/10
Overall, the conception was brilliant and well executed considering the minor shortcomings. I would recommend anyone to purchase it.

Ps. It was worth my purchase, I believe I got in on sale for around $10 and it took me about 75 hours to complete my first playthrough, I think that is definitely a steal.

41065655.review:
Still the amazing Gamecube Classic it was all those years ago.
I remember when this game came out back in 2003. I was a small boy and it was my first entry in the Tales of series and the start of my journey as a longtime fan. All these years later, and this game still holds up! The story is still very engaging with its cast of diverse character personalities and the length of the story will keep you playing and getting your money's worth. The combat, while stiffer compared to the newer games, still holds up as well. This was the series' first big transition to 3D after all, and it still completely playable and enjoyable. The soundtrack, composed by the amazing Motoi Sakuraba is still as amazing as it was then.  A really solid port and a great way to replay this classic JRPG of my childhood. 

The only con of this port is that while the original GC version ran at 60 fps, this port of the ps3 version is locked at 30. Which personally isn't too big of a deal to me, but still doesn't make much sense when it's on the better hardware. But it's all up to preference.

I hope this leads to ports of more games on Steam. I'd love to see Tales of the Abyss on here some day. It's my favorite in the series and I'd totally play through it another 2 or 3 times on Steam.

In short, the series might have dipped in quality the past couple titles, but that is no reason to pass up this gem. It was amazing then and it's amazing now. It's one of my favorite games of all time and I hope it can be for you too.

39358004.review:
Few JRPGs have such a well-paced story with so many interesting twists and turns. I've always been a big fan of how the game starts with the traditional "chosen hero" trope and spins off organically into a much deeper, more complex narrative. Genre veterans may find the twists somewhat clichéd, however.

The battle system has plenty of depth in terms of number of moves (Techs) available, EX Skill combinations, and party members to keep combat interesting for several playthroughs.

Note that this game predates the Free Run mechanic from later Tales games, which means that movement is locked on a linear plane while in combat despite the battle arena being in 3D. However, I find there's a certain charm in learning how to work around the limitations of the battle system.

Although this is the definitive version of the game in terms of available content and options, there are unfortunately still several cutscenes containing wrong or missing dialogue sprinkled throughout the game, including a very early part of the main story. This kills my body and absorbs my consciousness.

39194363.review:
Not the best game of all time, but still a classic. As others have said, the story is a bit cliché but that doesn't mean its not well-written. In fact, I think its rather charming and teaches some important life lessons. The cutscenes are always interesting, the characters are loveable and the gameplay is super fun.

I played the GameCube release in the early 2000's and probably clocked over 150 hours on it. There's a lot more content than you might expect in a game from 2003 and you'll likely play for up to 60 hours before fighting the final boss. To top that off, the sale price for Tales of Symphonia is usually less than £4 GBP, and I consider that an absolute steal.

The graphics are no better than they were on Gamecube, but that's to be expected - its a port of a port rather than a remake. They won't be winning any awards in 2018, but don't let them put you off. There's plenty of other beautiful art in the game, such as the anime-style cutscenes. Music is lovely too.

One of the main problems with the PC port is that the keyboard controls are incredibly clunky, so you might want to stay away from this release if you don't have a controller. Also, its far too easy to get lost and spend hours navigating the map, but that isn't new.

Final thoughts? Flawed, but delightful and will last you a while.

PS you will likely want an X-Box Controller to play.

38849469.review:
Still a true classic.
While its not the best port, its flaws kind of fade away when you can get it for $5. I still feel the Gamecube original is still a tiny bit better.

There's no random battles and no turn based combat, if those usally turn you away from JRPGs.

Theres a few things added not in the Gamecube original; extra artes and costumes are nice, the casino is just sort of there. But wierdly enough theres some typos and missing spaces later on in the game, even tho' this game has been in english twice now. But they did use a far better font than what the Gamecube had.

The graphics still ooze charm and look great thanks to a stellar art direction. The colors seem a tad richer in the PC version, tho' I'm not sure if it has more to do with the S-video connection I use for my Gamecube. While some may be put off at the rather stiff cutscene animations, they have always stuck with me and I love the narminess they bring.

The audio is from the Gamecube original cept for a few new lines for the new moves that were wierdly low in volume. They are just as compressed sounding as they were on the Gamecube with the early voice lines sounding very hissy and even some occasional pops. Eventually you get use to it and barely notice cept on some of Colette's lines.

The port was rather terrible early on, but after a couple patches, it plays a LOT better now. I felt no need to use the fan patch. This port was originally capped at 30 FPS and it felt extremely slow and sluggish in the combat. They have since bumped it up to 40FPS which made it feel much better. It doesn't feel AS smooth as the 60 FPS Gamecube original, but close enough. The bump to 40 also seems to cause some earlier cutscenes dialog to be cut a bit short.

I can admit to being a bit nostalgia blind to it, but everytime I play it I'm always finding something new. Even replaying the game to see the PC port, I've never noticed just how well all the systems for the combat played with each other. Even the cooking plays a decent roll for it, from keeping your HP and TP topped off to increasing the likelihood to go into Over limit. Still wish the costume titles would be separate equippables.

If you never played it, I would highly reccomend getting it.

This game will always remain near and dear to my heart.

Anywho enough complaints aside. The game overall is just as good as the original, though i never played it beyond the gamecube.

I will say though, I feel that if you can get the gamecube version it might be worth it emulating the game over buying this, especially if your buying it outright at full price.

The port itself, when it runs, runs well with the right mods (4K texture support, stable FPS fix, cel shading outlines), but when it works, it works. The problem is the game will work fine for the first 10 or so hours, and after that, it will refuse to load. I've tried uninstalling it and reinstalling it, verifying cache integrity, and it won't work. I don't recommend this to anyone, thank goodness I only spent 5 bucks on it when it was 75% off, no way would I recommend paying full price for this rushed port.


Edit: I figured out the source of the problem, the game can be very finnicky about how admin rights are used (in the properties settings), and uninstalling and reinstalling the TOS Fix gets around it.  Keeping a close eye, but yeah. Updating it to barely "recommended" for now.

38655492.review:
Tales of Symphonia es, sin lugar a dudas, uno de los JRPG con mejor historia y narrativa de los últimos 20 años. Transmite valores, hace crecer como persona y enseña a luchar incansablemente por tus objetivos.
El apartado audiovisual es bastante bueno. La estética anime le queda como anillo al dedo, y su banda sonora tiene piezas que se te quedaran en la memoria para muchos años. 

Eso sí, no todo es perfecto. El juego en la versión de PC está capado a 30 fps y tiene un uso excesivo de la CPU.  
Y aunque no es tan importante en este género como en otros, la jugabilidad en los combates se ve algo empañada y añadiendo que de por sí el sistema de combate es algo tosco. En este sentido se nota que es un juego de hace 15 años.

Ya para finalizar, Tales of Symphonia es un videojuego que absolutamente todos los fans del género deberían jugar. Con todas las misiones secundarias su duración puede superar las 100 horas de lejos, y todas a un gran nivel.

Hay pocos juegos que te hagan saltar alguna lagrimilla, ¿no es así?

38610151.review:
Still my favourite JRPG to date. Awesome characters (Kratos is badass), and a cliché, but loveable story. Plot twists galore. Really taught me a lot of important lessons when I played this as a kid. This was my first Tales game and I found it to be a good entry point to the series for those who are unfamiliar with it. 

PC port has notable problems though. There are some missing voicelines. One scene in particular, mostly involving Presea, Regal and another character, (minor spoilers?) had several of Presea's voicelines missing and replaced with previous lines and voice from the other character (???), making the end of the scene make no sense. There are some instances where characters will say one thing, but the caption on screen says something different (happens in several boss battles during the fight intro). New voice lines that were added in to the English version aren't audio synced properly, being much quieter than the rest of the voice acting.

Overall, it's still absolutely worth buying in my opinion, despite the shoddy PC port. It was one of the best games for the GameCube and that hasn't changed with this version. If you haven't played it, give it a shot.

38437814.review:
SPOILERS WARNING
Please disregard the "thumbs down" for now. I don't mean it so harshly. I'm sorry ToS, forgive me. :(

So I only recommend this game if you really like JRPGs, have played every quality JRPG out there, and you must play something else to hold you over until some other, higher-quality JRPG comes out. This game has an average story, with almost entirely bland characters, a dated mechanics and gameplay, and a decent soundtrack. It's by no means terrible. I've encountered no glitches and I had fun during my 100ish hours playthrough+post-game (I played this on gamecube console a year ago). But I wanted to wait a while before I wrote a review. I've reflected on my time invested in ToS. I've also played a bit of Tales of Berseria, and I have changed my stance on this game from "an above-average JRPG, but nothing too special" to "Yeah, I mean, it's alright, certainly nothing special. I just think there are like, I don't know, maybefifty other things that would be more fulfilling than playing ToS. Want to experience a great story? Read Infinite Jest or The Metamorphosis,  play Undertale or Xenoblade Chronicles, or watch Your Lie in April. Want a fun experience? Watch Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood,  Made in Abyss, or Assassination Classroom or read Infinite Jest. Want to experience aesthetically pleasing art? Read Lolita or play Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons or Journey.


Just a quick note on the story, I gagged at how poorly written an executed this story is. I burst out laughing at how blatent the foreshadowing is, and how poorly developed the themes of friendship are. Antagonists and enemies, with the exception of Kratos (see, I said spoilers) and Mithos are all just unambiguously bad.The one part I will praise is how ToS deals with discrimination. 

My point is ToS is is no way bad. Yet it fails to justify the 60-80+ hour investment. It's mediocre in terms of fun, story, or aestetic appeal. In fact, it's just another  "meh" JRPG. There is an abundance of other media that would so what ToS does better, either in terms of the components of the story (art, music, gameplay, etc.), or as a whole. Xenoblade Chronicles is a better game in every aspect.

38068178.review:
The first jrpg I've played in quite a while and I thoroughly enjoyed my time with it.

The combat being not your usual turn based thing is the initial thing that drew me to the game and it was pretty good. At first I thought it a bit simple but once I actually bothered to look into the games combat systems it opened up.

Overall I really liked the story. It starts off as your standard 'save the world' thing but does open up into some deeper themes even if it does deal with those themes a little heavy handed at times. The story keeps going (my save file showed 33 hours) as well but not in a bad way, there was multiple times I thought it was going to end but something else happened. I guess looking back on it some of those times could be viewed as padding but it certainly didn't feel like it during my playtime.
Looking at the wiki there was also some side stuff I missed which would have extended my time by quite a bit if I wanted to do everything (maybe I will in ng+).

Some of the later puzzles dragged on a bit but I was more than willing to push through them as I was invested in the story and characters.

Thanks to this game I'm going to be looking into grabbing some other games of the same type.
