38025436.review:
Like many of the people here, I played this game back when it was on the Gamecube. And BOY did I play that thing to death... it was easily my go-to RPG (that and KotOR, but hey, gotta give some love to the PC). So when they announced the game was being put on Steam, I just about flipped my lid in excitement. Then it came out and everyone was up in arms about the frame drop and other issues, and since my old computer could not even open the game, let alone run it, I had to pass it up. However, it died and I was able to procure a new one, and immediately bought this game.

I have to be blunt, this plays FAR better than it did on the PS3 - I really can't tell any difference between this and the Gamecube version (text aside) because it plays just as smoothly on it. I even put the graphics settings on the highest settings possible and didn't experience any issues. Maybe it's just because the game was patched at some point between then and now (I haven't seen any news since March/April) but this has far too many 'not recommended'  settings. And my computer is just an average one; the components are not top-of-the-line, nor did they cost an arm and a leg. Now all I need is a Gamecube controller adapter... XD

The game has all of the content of not just the GC/PS2 but the additions of the ToSC release for the PS3, including the unlockable costumes that reference other games in the series. Lloyd and Genis, for example, get the outfits of Guy and Luke, respectively, from Tales of the Abyss. The mechanics work exactly the same as they did in the GC version, which can be a bit jarring if you're used to the mechanics from the more recent games - this game does not have a 'free run' mode that allows you to circle around your enemies. Even back when I had both this and Abyss, I'd find myself trying to free-run but not being able to, but that didn't diminish my enjoyment of the game.

In short, if you can at least meet the minimum requirements for the game, I highly recommend picking up this classic. There's a reason it stands alongside the likes of Paper Mario: The Thousand-Year Door, Metroid Prime, and The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess as the best games of the Gamecube.

37979810.review:
"Tales" series is less well known than Final Fantasy, but I've always liked it a bit more. And Tales of Symphonia is my favorite one (though arguably Vesperia might be better in many ways).

The story, and characters, are every JRPG cliché ever condensed into one game. But clichés aren't a bad thing in and of itself, there's a reason they exist, reason for them to be, well clichés. Symphonia executes all of them so well, you barely realize they're there. It's like you're watching the best 90's anime ever made. Think Lethal Weapon and buddycop clichés.

Normal JRPGs have the screen shatter, music start blasting, and you're moved into turn based combat. From the beginning, Tales did something different, you're moved into real time combat, with fighting game style moves. Think Soul Calibur or whatever. You have your team of four people, each with their own very specific gameplay. You control one of them, usually the main character Lloyd (heaviest hitter + decent mobility + second most HP + most moves). The gameplay is really satisfying even when it sometimes might get repetitive.

It's a world that pulls you in. Characters that you love more and more. Open field that opens just the right amounts for you to explore more and more. It's MWAHHH, it's perfect.

This PC port is honestly kind of shit though, even if elevated by the game itself. It's from the Play Station 2 version, the worse version (even though it has some additional content). It should have been made the best of both worlds, GameCube version with PS2's added outfits etc. The fighting UI and everything is just better on GC. There's a bunch of other changes that should have been made as well; 30fps doesn't bother me, 16:9 1080p with humongous UI elements blocking half the screen do.
BUT. If you do not own any other version, please try this one. It's worth whatever dollaridoos it is, even at full price.

37793349.review:
I played this game for the first time back in 2004 when it was released for the Gamecube and I loved it. Now, thirteen years later I played it again and I have to say it is still a great game. 

Pros:
- Great real time battle system.
- Lengthy story (40+ hours).
- Nice selection of characters.
- Local Co-op mode. 

Cons:
- Generic story.
- Graphics hasn't aged that well. 

Altough story can be a tad generic, there are some twists that keep it fresh. Voice acting is mediocre and combat is a blast (local co-op mode is a really nice addition for this kind of game). It's a decent port and would recommend it to any jrpgs fan that likes games such as Grandia or Skies of Arcadia.

Score: 8/10
